IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transgender and gender diverse (TGD) people experience a range of mental health disparities largely understood in the context of gender minority stress. We propose to develop a culturally sensitive, multidimensional measure of TGD resilience, and to use our scale to investigate the role of resilience in buffering the effect of minority stressors in a longitudinal study. The proposed project is poised to broaden our conceptualization and measurement practices for TGD Resilience, reframe the overall approach to TGD health-disparities research to incorporate a strengths-based focus, and inform the development of targeted mental health interventions to bolster TGD resilience.

PHR: Narrative This proposal will examine the efficacy of novel bone-directed therapies blocking key interactions of cancer cells with the tumor microenvironment to decrease tumor growth, control dormant cancer cells, repair damaged bone, and circumvent unwanted systemic toxic effects in multiple myeloma. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The objective of this research is to develop, validate, and implement advanced computational tumor phenotyping strategies to characterize treatment response of head and neck cancer and evaluate the role of the immune system in therapeutic resistance. Our approach involves the high-throughput analysis of quantitative features from both radiology images (i.e., radiomics) and digital pathology images (i.e., pathomics) to generate tumor- specific computational fingerprints of disease at the macroscopic-scale and microscopic-scale, respectively. We hypothesize that by leveraging innovative computing strategies, novel clinical trial data, and complementary mechanistic experiments, we can link radiopathomic expression patterns to biological processes driving treatment resistance, which may guide improved treatment approaches for this urgent and unmet clinical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Postpartum depression (PPD) is a common and often devastating complication of childbirth that disproportionately affects black, indigenous, people of color (BIPOC) mothers. Expanding our existing MomGenes Fight PPD study will allow us to collect robust phenotypes and biological samples for a large number of BIPOC women to more completely understand PPD risk factors. Our examination of genetic, adverse life events, and discrimination burden can lead to actionable findings that aid all women suffering from PPD.

PHR: Project Narrative Throughout development, microRNAs are used to regulate gene expression, and cancers can form throughout the body when that control is lost. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human spermatogonial stem cells (SSCs) are at the foundation of spermatogenesis and may have applications for treating certain groups of infertile patients. However, progress translating stem cell methods to the human fertility clinic are hampered by our limited knowledge of the regulatory mechanisms of SSC functions in the human testis and lack of tools to isolate, manipulate and expand stem cells for basic research or therapeutic applications. Our proposed work will provide much needed insights into the functional interplay between stem cells and their surrounding microenvironment, which will be crucial to the development of methods to maintain and expand human SSCs in long-term culture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Narrative  The goal is to develop an integrated deep learning model to optimize 5'UTR, codon usage, and 3'UTR at same time that enables users to design the optimal mRNA sequence to enhance protein expression level, thus to improve the efficacy of mRNA medicines. mRNA based therapies hold great promise for the treatment of various types of diseases, but this therapeutic approach suffers from multiple challenges including the short half- life of exogenously administered mRNA and subsequent protein production. Our proposed studies will address the challenges in design of mRNA sequence to enhance mRNA stability and translation efficiency, and thus provide important information for the development and optimization of mRNA vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Administrative Core)  The primary function of the Administrative Core (AC) of the RCHDR is to provide oversight of all RCMI  program activities including fiscal, budgetary, organizational, planning, evaluation, infrastructure development,  and technology transfer. The AC is responsible for the general administration and coordination of all  programmatic activities and the efficient operation of Research Infrastructure Core, Community Engagement  Core, and Investigator Development Core. The AC is also responsible for coordinating the activities of both  internal and external advisory committees, conducting regular assessments to evaluate the Center and identify  needs and opportunities, and creating an integrated work environment that fosters the development and  implementation of innovative research aimed at improving minority health and reducing health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Research Infrastructure Core)  In this U54 grant proposal, we propose the consolidation of existing multiuser core laboratories to create a  comprehensive Research Infrastructure Core (RIC) that will accelerate discoveries in basic, clinical and/or  translational sciences, in an effort to address important health disparity issues of concern to minorities and  underserved communities. The proposed RIC will provide RCHDR investigators and the scientific community  at JSU with a robust, collaborative, and standardized resource for the efficient implementation of their  biomedical research projects. This strategic plan fully supports the RCHDR vision of developing a state-of-the-  art biomedical infrastructure that enables JSU investigators to become more competitive in obtaining research  grants from NIH and/or other funding agencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (IDC)  The major goal of RCMI-CHDR Investigator Development Core (IDC) is to provide early stage investigators  (ESI) with the necessary resources and support mechanisms to facilitate their transition to independent  researchers. The IDC will implement an effective Pilot Project Program (PPP) that will catalyze the scientific  growth and professional development of ESI by: (1) supplying pilot funding for the implementation of basic  science, behavioral and/or clinical research aimed at improving minority health and reducing environmental  health disparities; and (2) engaging ESI in a rigorous biomedical research-training program that fosters  mentoring and academic career development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (CEC)  The RCMI Center Health Disparities Research (RCHDR) Community Engagement Core (CEC) plays a critical  role in ensuring the bidirectional communication between investigators and the various advocacy groups and  community organizations in order to implement cost-effective strategies to address critical health disparities  issues in the tri-county area (Hinds, Madison and Rankin counties) surrounding the capital city of Jackson,  Mississippi. It is a community-university partnership designed to improve minority health and reduce health  disparities. The establishment of a Community Advisory Board (CAB) composed of community leaders,  scientists, government officials and state agencies, faith-based organizations, and several grassroots health  organizations creates a supportive framework to achieve this goal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinx adolescents are disproportionately at risk for poor depression and suicidality and are exposed to adversity, stress, and discrimination experiences. There remains a need for research understanding the effect of laws and policies on Latinx youth mental health to broaden the scope of prevention and intervention focused on upstream factors. The proposed study fills this gap by using rigorous methodology to examine the influence of macrolevel policies on Latinx youth mental health and to inform effective community-engaged strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Involuntary commitment is a legal and health intervention used to mandate treatment for people with behavioral health problems who are thought to be at imminent risk for harming themselves or others. The process often relies upon law enforcement officers to apprehend the person of concern from the community, so that treatment can be initiated. Our proposal will examine the use and consequences of law enforcement mediated involuntary commitment and its possible role in exacerbating or mitigating racial disparities in overdose, self-harm, and justice-involvement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cervical cancer is one of the most preventable cancers and when diagnosed early and appropriately treated, the likelihood of survival is close to 100%. Despite this, urban, underserved minority women in the US have lower rates of follow-up regimens after an abnormal test result compared to White women and this has been linked to the disparities in cervical cancer cases among this population. The proposed study will develop and evaluate a novel, theory-based mHealth intervention available in both English and Spanish consisting of patient- focused text-based barriers counseling and as-needed telephone health coaching thereby increasing long-term follow-up rates among urban, underserved minority women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is uniformly lethal and is the most common malignant primary brain tumor; current therapy is incapacitating and produces a median overall survival (OS) of less than 2 years. We have published on an innovate method for preconditioning a vaccine site with recall antigens that boost the migration of dendritic cells carrying tumor-specific antigen to the lymph nodes, resulting in increased overall survival of patients with newly diagnosed GBM. Since this publication we have identified the primary driver of this enhanced immunity to be the chemokine CCL3, and we propose to mechanistically examine the role of CCL3 as a novel developmental therapeutic treating brain cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Urinary stone disease (USD) is on the rise and represents the second most costly urologic condition in the US, with a healthcare cost over $10 billion per year. Despite the growing clinical enthusiasm and rapid development of new technologies in laser lithotripsy (LL), which is the current treatment of choice for surgical management of USD, the fundamental theory about cavitations in LL has been lacking, hindering the efforts to reduce procedure time and improve clinical outcome. In this project, we propose to develop the 3D super- resolution passive cavitation mapping technology for real-time analysis of the cavitation activities during LL, which will provide valuable information on optimizing the LL treatment strategy for USD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our project aims to transform early detection and screening methods for Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma (PDAC) by developing a 'fair' fusion model, “PRECISE” (PancREas Cancer multImodal riSk prEdiction), which integrates imaging and non-imaging biomarkers from multisite cohorts. The model leverages deep learning and adversarial debiasing techniques to incorporate diverse clinical data, enabling more effective risk predictions, especially for minority subgroups. Through a scalable automated risk stratification, we aspire to provide opportunistic screening to patients undergoing routine abdominopelvic CT exams, aiming for an early and accurate prediction of future PDAC risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE The Eating Disorders Genetics Initiative 2 (EDGI2) unites existing and exceptionally productive and collaborative sites globally to advance genetic discovery across all eating disorders (anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, binge-eating disorder, and avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder). We will apply both novel and established methods to optimize discovery in our diverse and severely ill sample, culminating in a clinical translation summit. Our goal is to identify biologically, clinically, culturally, and therapeutically meaningful and actionable insights and rapidly transition the field from discovery to clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The burden of cognitive dementias has rapidly increased, estimated to affect 152 million people by 2050. Despite this projection, there has been limited progress in understanding how best to prevent, treat, and manage dementias. The objective of the proposed study is to identify trajectories of key risk factors and their combinations that predict or protect against early and severe cognitive decline and to increase understanding of the modifiable social, behavioral and environmental factors that prevent or reduce the burden of age-related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Behavioral, psychological, and social factors contribute to the development of cardiovascular diseases and their unequal distribution across populations. To address the public health burden of cardiovascular diseases, the Strategic Vision of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute has underscored the need to train a diverse workforce of translational scientists who conduct rigorous, interdisciplinary research on the behavioral, psychological, and social factors in cardiovascular disease risk and resilience. Our T32 program has been dedicated to addressing this need for nearly 40 years by providing state-of-the-art training in cardiovascular behavioral medicine research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will investigate injury to the brain during heart surgery using subcellular, cellular, and large animal models. Our laboratory has extensive experience with these mechanisms and models and has demonstrated some of the mechanistic pathways that underlie this brain injury. Additional pathways of injury remain unknown. By improving the knowledge of these mechanisms of injury and testing them in models that can be translated to human trials, this proposal has the potential to help hundreds of thousands of patients who suffer from cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This grant proposal is to understand genetic and epigenetic regulations of hemangiogenesis, blood and blood vessel formation, in the developing mouse embryo. Notably, we will investigate if expression levels of Etv2, an essential ETS transcription factor for hematopoietic and endothelial cell development, dictate hemangiogenic versus smooth muscle lineage outcome. We will also delineate ETV2 mediated enhancer switching mechanisms of Flk1 expression and the interplay between ETV2 and the BAF155, a subunit of the mammalian SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling BAF (BRG1/BRM associated factor) complex, in chromatin remodeling of the ETV2 target gene loci. This study's outcome is highly relevant to basic research and regenerative medicine of the hematopoietic and cardiovascular systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative: We will investigate how membrane curvature regulates biochemical signals that are transmitted through the cell-matrix interface by using nanotechnology-based precision engineering. The knowledge gained will help to guide the design of biomaterials and biodevices for better integration with cells. We will also develop nanoscale electrodes to accurately record intracellular action potentials, which impact our understanding of membrane resealing in heart cells, as well as impact biotechnology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Senescent cells are growth arrested cells that are highly associated with aging and chronic diseases and could be targeted to slow the aging process. The transcriptomic signatures of senescent cells are not well defined which has implications for designing treatments to treat aging related diseases. This proposal will leverage single nucleus RNA-sequencing techniques in order to understand the molecular markers that define senescent cells and may lead to the development of more efficacious therapies to target senescent cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE People living with HIV (PLWH) have a high burden of pain, and most commonly experience neuropathic pain, for which there are few treatments. Medical cannabis has emerged as a possible treatment even though there is a dearth of information about its mechanism of analgesia and potential adverse events. This proposal will shed light on these gaps in our knowledge by examining how medical cannabis affects pain, inflammation, and adverse events in PLWH with chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) is a serious, and unfortunately common, complication of allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (allo-HCT). Although allo-HCT can potentially be curative for a variety of malignant (e.g. leukemia, lymphoma) and non-malignant (e.g. anemia, immunodeficiencies) diseases, continued research is critical for the development of novel methods of mitigating the debilitating consequences of GvHD. This proposal builds on the discovery I made using mouse models that Galectin-3 from donor and host cells protects normal tissues from GvHD resulting in decreased severity and mortality and may determine the therapeutic potential and cellular mechanisms by which Galectin-3 inhibits GvHD following allo-HCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Discerning neurodegenerative disease pathomechanisms have been challenging due to disease polygenicity, largely unknown etiology, and the involvement of multiple cell types. This proposal implements multispectral imaging (MSI) as a feasible, innovative, and unbiased approach to investigating the cellular physiology of neurodegenerative diseases in disease-relevant cell types. Applying this systems-level approach to neurons and astrocytes will enhance our understanding of TDP-43 proteinopathies, namely frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed study will investigate the functional role and lineage contribution of a novel population of blood vessel progenitor cells which we have identified in zebrafish embryos. These cells contribute to vascular growth by a novel mechanism of intercalation into existing vasculature. The acquired knowledge will promote development of new therapeutic strategies aimed at repairing damaged vessels in multiple vascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed clinical trial will determine whether a daily-caloric restriction-based weight loss intervention can slow kidney growth in adults with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease who are overweight or obese. The study will also evaluate changes in abdominal fat by magnetic resonance imaging. Blood and fat samples will provide insight into biological changes that may contribute to any observed benefits of the intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The neurobiological basis of socioemotional symptoms, a debilitating feature of many neurological and psychiatric disorders, is not well understood. The brain and autonomic nervous system cohesively interact to support socioemotional well-being, and cutting-edge analytical techniques can now reveal the rich dynamic properties of these systems. By leveraging behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia, a neurodegenerative disease of socioemotional deficits that targets these systems, the goal of the proposed project is to determine how autonomic and functional brain network dynamics shape human emotions and social behavior in healthy and clinical populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The biomedical research landscape is changing rapidly, becoming increasingly cross-disciplinary and team- oriented, and broadening its presence beyond the academy. The goal of the proposed renewal is to expand and distribute our successful profession development program, The Whole Scientist, to reach a broader audience. By delivering the program’s benefits to trainees more broadly, we anticipate a diverse scientific workforce that is prepared for the demands of the modern biomedical research landscape. This, in turn, will further strengthen productivity and innovation in both the public and private science and technology sectors and ensure the US remains a leader in biomedical discovery for the benefit of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Doxorubicin (Dox) is among the most effective and widely used drugs for treatment of human cancers. Our studies aim to understand the key factors that cause this problem and understanding these processes will allow development of new drugs to treat the problem in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Discoid lupus erythematosus is a chronic autoimmune skin disease characterized by a complex immune infiltration and current treatments are often ineffective. We will perform translational immunologic research including spatial proteomics and spatial transcriptomics to delineate the key cells and inflammatory pathways that drive disease development in both humans and mice, with particular emphasis on immune inhibitory receptors. This wok will advance our understanding of discoid lupus and help identify additional targeted strategies for treating this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose a three-year bioengineering undergraduate research training program that will expose a diverse population of students from underrepresented backgrounds to existing research opportunities, facilitate multiple positive interactions with participating faculty, as well as build the trainee’s cultural capital and sense of community through our six-semester one-credit required course and three-year research experience in the laboratories of our faculty mentors. Our goal is to use evidence-based best practices to prepare our trainees for a career in biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, we will investigate the determinants of venous endotheliopathy and thrombosis in COVID19 patients. We will accomplish this objective by deploying a novel Vein-Chip technology that comprises of the human vascular cells within a native composition and geometry of a typical human vein and exposed to physiological hemodynamic forces that could regulate the responses to the SARS-CoV-2 viral infection. The Vein-Chip is expected play a critical role in our development and optimization of life-saving therapies for COVID19 patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Black people experience among the highest rates of negative alcohol-related consequences and severity of disordered use compared to other racial/ethnic groups, highlighting the need for effective alcohol treatment for Black drinkers. The objective of this proposal is to identify the impact of stressors related to the Black experience, most notably, race-related stress, on alcohol craving among Black people to inform culturally tailoring treatment for this group. Acknowledging race-related stressors and other factors unique to the Black experience in alcohol treatment may help Black people with AUD to feel understood by their clinicians thus enhancing treatment satisfaction, retention, and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cervical dystonia is a rare but debilitating neurologic disorder that involves abnormal positions and/or movements of the head. Many patients do not get satisfactory benefit from current treatment options, and the conventional methods for evaluating the impact of new treatments have several limitations. This project will evaluate new methods for measuring treatment impact based on computer analyses of video recordings of patients, thereby optimizing the potential for evaluating the outcome of multi-site clinical trials of future treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  A single mutation (C134W) in the forkhead transcription factor FOXL2 is universally associated with adult type granulosa cell tumors, yet the molecular basis underlying the oncogenic effect of FOXL2C134W is unclear. We have mapped putative oncologic dependencies using combined in vitro and bioinformatic methods. Using a novel, inducible, spontaneous genetically-representative model, we will investigate the mechanisms by which FOXL2C134W impacts granulosa cell function and tumorigenesis. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatic steatosis is highly associated with obesity, diabetes and atherosclerosis, and has few available pharmacologic interventions. The liver is a major contributor to whole body metabolic homeostasis and a validated target for metabolic drugs, as shown from the great efficacy of statins. In my proposal, I will elucidate the role of the novel protein BASIC in liver physiology, thus advancing our understanding of fundamental mechanisms controlling hepatic lipid droplet morphology which will lead to opportunities for therapeutic intervention in metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will investigate catalytic, stereoselective dearomatization reactions of heteroarenes to synthesize non-aromatic heterocycles. These non-aromatic heterocycles are among the most common structural motifs in active pharmaceutical ingredients. Thus, enabling their efficient synthesis will allow rapid and cost-effective access to pharmaceuticals that greatly benefit the society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Controversy exists over the risk to benefit ratio of medical marijuana for adults with chronic non-cancer pain (CNCP) on chronic opioid therapy (COT). The primary goal of this proposal is to assess whether medical marijuana, when added to a behavioral prescription opioid taper support program, improves pain and reduces opioid dose in adults on COT for CNCP more so than the behavioral intervention alone. This information is critical to better inform patients and clinicians about the extent to which medical marijuana use may be beneficial or harmful to this patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Evidence suggests that Alzheimer’s disease (AD), the most common cause of dementia, also affects the gut. The proposed research will identify critical pathophysiological pathways that affect the gut and precede cognitive decline. The study will identify targets in the microbiota and gut immune cells that will inform novel prevention and intervention strategies for AD and aging-associated dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The UTEP FIRST program will operationalize strategic Diversity, Equity and Inclusion [DEI] initiatives that will provide an integrative and cohesive theme for addressing the defined FIRST program goals of: (1) fostering sustainable institutional culture change; (2) promoting institutional inclusive excellence by hiring a diverse cohort of new faculty; and (3) supporting faculty development, mentoring, sponsorship, and promotion. A novel, interdisciplinary, and multi-factorial mentoring model will support minority and underrepresented faculty hired and mentored in a cohort and cluster model. This program will provide a framework for investigators to significantly impact Hispanic health disparities by driving institutional excellence in inclusiveness, diverse and underrepresented faculty development, and cutting-edge research in Hispanic health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Retinoblastoma (Rb) is a developmental tumor of the retina and a significant contributor to childhood cancer death worldwide. For many patients, the only life-saving treatment option is removal of the affected eye. A major obstacle to the development of targeted therapies that spare the normal tissues in the eye is the lack of laboratory models in which these tumors can be studied. Emerging 3-Dimensional organoid culture techniques, tissue engineering applications, gene editing, and single-cell resolution genetic analysis have the potential to create platforms in which Rb tumor pathobiology can be fully elucidated. We have developed a 3D Retinal Organoid platform which incorporates all of these new technologies and is capable of recapitulating the biological nuances of human retinoblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hematopoietic stem cells, which are the source of all blood cells throughout our lifetime, form in the embryo. The goal of this research is to identify important molecules that regulate the formation of hematopoietic stem cells in the embryo. The research may ultimately guide the design of new protocols for generating hematopoietic stem cells from other cell sources for use in transplantation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric traumatic injury (PTI) is a public health priority, with nearly 300,000 children experiencing injuries that require hospitalization each year. These children, and their caregivers, are affected in many ways that may affect quality of life, emotional and behavioral health, physical recovery, family roles and routines, and academic functioning; yet, US trauma centers do not adequately address these outcomes and a scalable national model of care for these families is needed. The present research will develop, evaluate, and test CAARE (Caregivers’ Aid to Accelerate Recovery after pediatric Emergencies), an intervention that was informed by, and designed for, caregivers of young children after PTI to address the behavioral and emotional needs of caregivers and children through education, self-monitoring, and coping resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Early identification of individuals at-risk to develop Alzheimer’s disease (AD) at the earliest pathological stages, prior to the onset of the first clinical symptoms, holds the potential to transform the diagnosis and management of this debilitating neurodegenerative disease, reducing disease burden on millions of patients and caregivers worldwide. The retina can serve as a non-invasive ‘window to the brain’ and can be imaged using standard optometry and ophthalmology techniques, allowing for screening for AD risk at routine eye exams in older adults, and subsequent referral for more extensive AD risk evaluation. This study proposes to investigate and validate AD risk screening biomarkers in the retina against standard brain imaging biomarkers, and then explore the utility of combining retinal with blood biomarkers to generate an AD risk detection algorithm for cost-efficient, wide- spread population-based screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unabated exposure to psychosocial stress changes the immune system and predisposes individuals to increased risk for bowel disease and infection but the biological factors are not fully defined. This project focuses on understanding how cells that line the intestine (epithelial cells) interact with the resident microbes that are harbored in the gut (the gut microbiota) in response to stress. We hypothesize that changes to epithelial cell physiology sets off a cascade of host-gut microbiota interactions that predispose individuals to increased risk for infectious and immune-mediated colitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the present application, we propose to build on recent accomplishments in which we identified and characterized pressure transducing ion channels in trabecular meshwork cells. We will establish their role in regulation of intraocular pressure using new mouse models of glaucoma and characterize the molecular rules that underlie dysfunctional sensing and regulation of pressure sensing in glaucoma. Results from the project are expected to lead towards novel IOP-lowering strategies that will protecting ocular cells from mechanical stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A growing number of diseases—such as cystic fibrosis, Parkinson’s, Alzheimer’s, and Huntington’s— arise because proteins fail to fold to their native, functional states, which may lead to loss of the function of the protein and/or pathological aggregation of the misfolded protein. Cells deploy a protein homeostasis network to maintain the health of their proteomes, and Hsp70 molecular chaperones are central hubs in these networks. The proposed research will reveal the fundamental mechanisms whereby Hsp70s carry out their many functions and how it might be possible to therapeutically target them for disease treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing a new and alternative strategy to treat idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis by targeting lactate metabolism through the inhibition of lactate transporters. Once the molecular mechanisms mediating the beneficial effects of these drugs have been identi- fied, there is the potential for a significant advance in therapy for patients with the disease. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NHLBI mission to enable the translation of basic discoveries into clinical practice for the treatment of heart and lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Diabetic retinopathy is a leading cause of visual disability worldwide. Current therapies are costly, short-lived, limited to late stages of disease, and ineffective in a sizable number of patients. This application has the potential to improve public health by adding to our understanding of how diabetes affects retinal metabolism, how such changes contribute to early abnormalities in vision, and how they can be corrected to produce new treatments.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Globally there is an increasing number of HIV-exposed but uninfected children and adolescents (HEU). We propose to evaluate HEU in Kenya, spanning from infancy to adolescence using different epidemiologic approaches to determine whether HEU have increased risk of adverse neurodevelopmental or mental health outcomes. We plan to screen a large population of HEU nationally and work collaboratively with stakeholders to review this data to inform approaches to screen, identify, and refer HEU with adverse outcomes, that could be used programmatically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE / PROJECT NARRATIVE SARS-CoV-2 infection in immunosuppressed individuals with HIV can lead to intra-host emergence of multi- mutational SARS-CoV-2 variants, some at sites linked to immune evasion or cell-receptor binding, especially in case of persistent infection. Phylodynamic and artificial intelligence can consider the evolutionary scenarios of SARS-CoV-2 variants emergence within HIV infection and assess the probability for increased strain infectivity and/or pathogenicity, thus providing a tool for planning and implementing public health measures before transmission occurs in the general population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Epidemiological studies identify that nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), a cell death and inflammation- associated nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), is the leading cause of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and end-stage liver failure worldwide. The goal of this study is to investigate the role of the innate immune sensor cGAMP synthase (cGAS) in limiting tissue injury, improving tissue microenvironment homeostasis, and thus preventing nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. Identification of new drug targets and elucidating their mechanisms of action are critical for developing effective therapeutic treatment for liver metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This proposal will study regulation of osteoblasts by the adrenal-stimulating hormone, adrenocorticotropic hormone, and by vascular endothelial growth factor, which is produced in new bone in response to adrenocorticotropic hormone. In bone, vascular endothelial growth factor promotes formation and support of blood vessels and prevents tissue death (osteonecrosis), including osteonecrosis in response to corticosterod treatment, which is a common clinical problem. Specifically, the work will determine the concentrations and time course by which adrenocorticotrophic hormone supports vascular endothelial growth factor production. This will be studied in living rabbits, and in human bone cell cultures in tissue culture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many gene mutations have been identified as causing cardiac diseases, but this information is of limited use without a detailed understanding of the mechanisms that relate genotype and phenotype. As an example of how these types of gaps can be bridged, we are developing biophysically detailed multiscale models that predict the impact of actin thin filament mutations on cardiac cell hypertrophy. These predictions will be validated against experiments and refined to create a robust tool for classifying pathogenicity of novel sarcomeric variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Work proposed here will explore the activity of a promising metabolic inhibitor against the amoebae, defining the suspected cellular target, testing new analogs of the parent inhibitor, and assessing the impact of the agent in a rodent model of disease. The described work is the first step in maturing the compounds into treatment of pathogenic free-living amoebae Naegleria fowleri infection. We will use a combination of biochemical, medicinal chemical, and model animal experiments to score the impact of enolase inhibitors developed for use in humans against the amoebae and to assess the role of the immune system in the treatment regime.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The treatment of severe infections caused by methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) has undergone an important paradigm shift since cefazolin is now considered, by many, the front-line antibiotic. However, therapeutic success of severe MSSA infections treated with cefazolin may be affected by the cefazolin inoculum (CzIE) effect, leading to poor outcomes. Our proposal seeks to determine the clinical impact of the CzIE and provide clinically relevant novel diagnostic tools to identify this phenotype with the objective of optimizing the treatment of life-threatening MSSA infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because pancreatic cancer patients have a dismal chance of survival secondary to tumor resistance to standard chemo and immunotherapies because of the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment. In this proposal, we will determine how an epigenetic regulator, KMT2D, regulates the tumor microenvironment via activin A and contributes to pancreatic cancer progression. Our project will contribute to impactful new knowledge on the influence of tumor cell-intrinsic epigenetic signaling on tumor microenvironment and tumor progression, which will pave the way for the clinical development of novel tumor microenvironment-targeting treatment in combination with chemo or immunotherapies for pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Histone deacetylase (HDAC) enzymes are key components regulating gene expression in response to life experience and have recently being associated with the development and maintenance of pain. We propose to use a newly developed PET radiotracer, [11C]Martinostat, to quantify the distribution and availability of HDACs in the brain of chronic low back pain patients with and without taking prescription opioids and to evaluate sex differences. We will clarify HDAC enzymes as a relevant target relating to chronic pain and opioid use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Decline in NAD+ levels contributes to the progression of heart failure. SARM1 NAD+ hydrolase is known as an executor of axonal degeneration, but its role in the heart has not been described. This proposal will determine the mechanistic roles of SARM1 activation in NAD+ decline and mitophagy during metabolic cardiomyopathy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cystic fibrosis (CF)-related liver disease (CFLD) is the third-leading cause of mortality in CF, an autosomal genetic disease caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Despite the clinical importance, the neural mechanisms of abnormal mechanosensation associated with dry eyes or contact lens wear remain unknown due to a lack of knowledge about primary mechanosensitive fibers involved. This proposal will characterize the role of MrgprD-expressing sensory fibers in mediating ocular mechanosensation and their regulation of lacrimation. These studies will not only advance our understanding of ocular sensation of dryness at the molecular and cellular levels, but will also provide a new neuronal target for promoting lacrimation under dry eye conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low oxygen tension, despite being a distinguishing trait of solid tumors, is rarely recapitulated in preclinical cancer research leading to the investigation of less-representative signaling pathways and the omission of hypoxia induced sensitivities and resistances to pharmalogical intervention. This proposal describes completed and ongoing pre-doctoral efforts to uncover actionable targets of tyrosine kinase signaling pathways that emerge during hypoxia and in hypoxic metastatic niches, as well as future post-doctoral efforts to investigate the impact of hypoxia induced tyrosine phosphatase (PTP) inactivation. Further, since PTPs restrain cellular signaling, identification of emergent sensitivities due to the loss of PTP activity may result in the identification of biological mechanisms amenable to therapeutic exploitation that have been not captured in previous normoxic efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Eating disorders and substance abuse are significant health risks that involve brain reward circuitry; tying these together is our discovery that insulin, a recognized regulator of satiety and metabolism, is also a reward signal in the brain. This project will assess mechanisms underlying increased release of acetylcholine and dopamine in striatal slices and in vivo, evaluate nutrient learning behaviors that are reinforced by insulin and blunted by a high-fat high-sugar diet, and combine these approaches to assess insulin-dependent synaptic plasticity. Proposed studies will show how the nutritive value of what we eat affects striatal cells and circuits to influence future food choices, and investigate the potential of new pharmacological targets that could be used to break the cycle of over-eating and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Pregnant women and their fetuses are exposed to multiple environmental insults during gestation, a very influential period for the fetal developing brain; prenatal exposures have been linked to increased cognitive, behavioral, and emotional problems including self-regulation, attention, conduct, and substance use problems, and psychotic experiences. Using a cognitive neuroscience approach, we seek to understand how in utero exposure to complex environmental mixtures alters the function of brain circuits that support cognitive control and reward processing, and gives rise to a range of behaviors that commonly emerge in late childhood and adolescence, a period that has been largely understudied with respect to the effects of prenatal exposures on neurodevelopmental outcomes. Our findings will allow public health interventions to improve the quality of children's perinatal environment and the development of novel circuit-specific intervention tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Heart disease is the leading cause of mortality worldwide and disruption of transcription in the heart contributes to the progression of heart disease. This application will investigate basic mechanisms of transcription in the heart by determining how transcriptional complexes work and how mutations in these complexes contribute to development of heart disease. Consequently, a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms governing cardiac gene expression will provide new insight into therapeutic strategies to restore cardiac function during disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: New therapeutics are needed to decrease the burden of acute respiratory distress syndrome. The tRNA methyltransferase TRMT1 is a critical regulator of the innate immune response to bacterial infection through the modification of tRNA. In these experiments we examine the molecular regulation of TRMT1 and the role of tRNA methylation during the inflammatory response, a mechanism that has not been studied in lung injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative T helper type 2 (Th2) cells are a type of effector CD4T cells that plays a crucial role in allergic diseases as well as in host protection against parasitic pathogens, but how they develop from naive CD4T cells upon encountering an allergen or parasitic antigen remains unclear. CD301b+ dendritic cells (DCs) are both necessary and sufficient for inducing Th2 differentiation of antigen-specific CD4T cells, and our data suggest contact-dependent interaction between these two cell types as the key mechanism for the Th2 fate decision by CD4T cells. To understand the mechanism of Th2 cell differentiation, this grant application proposes to precisely characterize the mechanisms and consequences of the interaction between CD301b+DCs and CD4T cells, which overall would help us to understand the basic mechanism of adaptive immunity and to improve our strategies for treating allergic diseases and developing effective vaccines for infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Millions of individuals suffer from pain and loss of function due to conditions like stroke, osteoarthritis, low back pain, cerebral palsy, and age-related frailty. Rehabilitation can improve function and quality of life, but current rehabilitation practice requires in-person guidance by a skilled clinician, increasing expense and limiting access. This project will provide vital research infrastructure and training opportunities, bringing together researchers from rehabilitation medicine, computer science, and bioengineering who are applying mobile technology to revolutionize how we diagnose, monitor, and treat mobility limitations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma is a common, chronic disease in both children and adults that is characterized by wheezing, shortness of breath, and coughing. Treatments for asthma are designed to control symptoms by relaxation of airway smooth muscle. Our work focuses on understanding how G protein coupled receptor signaling pathways coordinate airway smooth muscle functions with the long term goal of identifying new targets for treatment of this important clinical problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Cells must coordinate multiple independent processes during division to ensure that each daughter cell faithfully inherits the genome and all essential compartments to maintain viability. This proposal aims to study the novel role of the separase pathway, essential for chromosome segregation, in the regulation of cortical granule exocytosis in C. elegans oocytes. The control of disparate processes by core cell cycle regulators enables cells to synchronize mitotic events to maintain the fidelity of cell division.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Associations between the senses of smell and taste (i.e., flavors) are an essential factor in determining which foods we choose to eat; however, the neural mechanisms underlying the multisensory integration of odors and tastes remain unclear. We use a combination of behaving electrophysiology and optogenetics to investigate how interactions between the olfactory and gustatory cortices contribute to multisensory integration of smell and taste. These results will provide new insight into the circuit mechanisms underlying the perception of flavor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired energy homeostasis contributes to cardiomyocyte damage and adverse cardiovascular outcomes after myocardial infarction or circulatory arrest. We have discovered a new mechanistic pathway that controls cardiac glucose metabolism under ischemic stress. This project will delineate critical molecular aspects of the pathway and its role in the pathogenesis of ischemic heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our long-term goal is to develop and implement a novel biophotonics imaging tool for intraoperative detection of positive tumor margins during breast conserving surgery. The imaging device we propose to develop will be practically designed and validated for use in a surgical setting. The imaging device is significantly relevant to public health in that it will significantly reduce the unnecessary additional surgery for women who undergo breast conserving surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: || NARRATIVE Endothelial cells line the inside of blood vessels and provide barrier integrity to regulate the amount of fluid that moves between the inside and outside of blood vessels. Fluid leakage out of the vasculature is a major complication of inflammation that often leads to a lethal systemic bacterial infection known as sepsis. Fluid leak occurs mostly in veins, where most of the blood resides. We will study how inflammatory signals induce changes in proteins that regulate the veinous endothelial barrier to identify targets with the ability to control sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The consequences resulting from trauma to older adults are magnified when compared to younger age groups, however very few high-quality studies have been conducted to describe the long-term experience of trauma from the perspective of these patients and their respective caregivers. This study will characterize the experience of older adult trauma patients and their family caregivers using a qualitative approach through concept elicitation interviews over time. The results from this study will lead to innovative intervention strategies designed to improve quality of life for older adults with traumatic injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will: 1) identify motivation, emotion, and health behavior pathways through which a core psychological resource (perceived control) supports cognitive functioning, and 2) determine the extent to which the protective influence of perceived control on cognition is more pronounced for populations with limited socioeconomic resources who are at increased risk of cognitive decline. We will use micro- and macro- longitudinal data to systematically test the proposed pathways linking perceived control to changes in cognitive functioning across multiple timescales (days, months, and years). Our project will identify the mechanistic pathways and socioeconomic populations for whom perceived control buffers against cognitive declines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell death is an obligate consequence of tissue injury and fibroblasts are important cells during tissue repair. This proposal tests the hypothesis that fibroblast recognition of dead cells, termed cell corpses, promotes fibroblast repair capacity by triggering elevation of polyamine synthesis and hypusination of eiF5a, which drives fibroblast proliferation and synthesis of collagen proteins. Achieving the aims of this proposal will enhance our understanding of fibroblast-corpse interactions and the role of hypusine-eiF5a in fibroblasts and pave the way for development of novel approaches to promote lung repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Polyploidization, which increases the number of chromosome sets, is an alternative to cell division during tissue development and regeneration. This project aims to understand the mechanisms that mediate the cell cycle decision between division and polyploidization during epicardial regeneration. It has important, generalizable implications for how polyploidy can be controlled to improve the efficacy of the therapeutic repair of human tissues like the heart and for the treatment of diseases like cancer and acute kidney injury that involve polyploidy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Failure to disassemble or degrade RNA and protein complexes in cells has been associated with cellular dysfunction. Evidence suggests this may influence the progression and onset of various cancers and neurodegenerative diseases such as Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS). Understanding how cells can clear potentially toxic accumulations of proteins and RNA, and developing a means to boost such clearance processes, may be crucial to developing new therapeutic strategies in these disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Zoonotic viruses (those transmitted from animals to humans) pose a significant threat to global public health. Traditionally, researchers have taken a retrospective approach to studying zoonosis—only after a virus has emerged in humans have we started to dissect what genetic barriers the virus faced during zoonotic transmission, and how the animal virus adapted to overcome those barriers. The goal of this proposal is to take a prospective approach to studying zoonosis, by taking a virus family of high zoonotic potential and assessing their relative risk for zoonosis using a novel experimental framework.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposed research is relevant to public health because drug abuse among HIV-infected individuals poses a significant health burden to the Society. One of the hallmark features of morphine abuse is augmented astrocyte activation in the setting of HIV infection. Herein, we proposed to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying the effects of both HIV and morphine on astrocyte activation in the context of NLRP6 inflammasome signaling using various state-of-the-art approaches that could have ramifications for the future development of novel therapeutic approaches to mitigate central nervous system complications of NeuroHIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NUAIR T32 Fellowship program is designed for MD, MD/PhD and/or PhD trainees with an interest in advanced training in translational research in the field of Allergy-Immunology. Projects of trainees have both clinical and laboratory components, and trainees have access to renowned mentors in both clinical and basic departments in order to develop a mentoring team with expertise in both realms to successfully complete projects and training. NUAIR is highly compliant with scientific, programmatic and social initiatives of the NIAID and the NIH, and has been very successful in training academic investigators during its first two funding periods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative ROS and RNS production play an important role in various physiological processes (e.g. immune response, vascular regulation, neural functions) and in numerous pathological conditions. This study will provide a mechanistic understanding of how the remodeling of cellular metabolism powers up RONS production by NOXs and NOSs, and how their production causes downstream effects in metabolism and cell physiology. Such knowledge will provide a foundation to develop strategies to control RONS production or target the mechanisms for its downstream effects, which can modulate a broad range of physiological processes across tissues involving RONS production and improve the treatment of a variety of related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project examines experiences of health and economic challenges during the COVID-19 pandemic across generations of American families and how families responded to these challenges. The project creates a contextual database with information on multiple domains linked to two nationally-representative surveys of extended families to describe the degree to which family members shared the same challenges during the pandemic and how this affected their ability to help each other with time, money, and shared housing. The project focuses on the pandemic’s immediate and intermediate effects on health, whether it exacerbated health disparities, and if family support mitigated negative health effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Available treatment modalities for glaucoma rely on lowering intraocular pressure, which is insufficient to prevent progressive neurodegeneration in a significant number of patients. Building upon our previous studies, this proposal seeks to characterize the mechanism behind glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor (GLP-1R) agonist- mediated retinal ganglion cell rescue in ocular hypertension, and to model the GLP-1R agonist NLY01 as a disease modifying agent in mouse models of glaucoma. Results will advance our understanding of glaucoma pathogenesis, identify the mechanisms driving GLP-1R agonist-mediated neural rescue, and elucidate the potential for GLP-1R agonists as a novel IOP-independent treatment for glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative XMAN will be the first of its kind to provide a realistic and complete simulation of patient imaging and motions in the entire RT workflow, providing essential tools to evaluate and optimize the motion management strategies. Patient-specific XMAN unlocks the potential to move from current population-based heuristic approaches into high-precision patient-specific motion management. Overall, XMAN can lead to a paradigm shift in our motion management of liver SBRT to significantly advance its precision and clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE The severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) has infected over 233 million people globally. The US alone has reported ~126,000 corona virus disease-19 (COVID-19) cases in pregnant individuals, not including many asymptomatic and unconfirmed cases. Thus, potentially millions of children worldwide may be impacted by the sequelae of prenatal SARS-CoV-2 exposure. In this project, we will investigate the association of prenatal exposure to SARS-CoV-2 infection and the COVID-19 vaccines with behavior, cognition, and brain functioning in the child at 3 years of age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death worldwide and exposure to environmental chemicals including plastic-associated chemicals has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. This proposal will study how exposure to environmental chemicals increases atherosclerosis in the adults and their offspring. Results from the proposed studies will establish a novel therapeutic target for chemical-induced cardiovascular disease and will also have the potential to revolutionize our understanding of the etiology of many chronic human diseases originating from chemical-elicited intergenerational effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRITIVE STATEMENT Digital inequities, or the differential use of digital solutions based on demographic and socioeconomic status, limit the promise of mHealth and further divide the US population in terms of access and outcomes. The current proposal with develop RAE cHealth, a digital platform to facilitate peer-based recovery models into substance use disorder treatment programs, tailored to patients who are socioeconomically disadvantaged. The ultimate goal of RAE cHealth is to leverage a user-friendly interface to identify barriers to technology engagement and recovery, connect users with their peer recovery coach and other critical support systems, and empower users to be self-sufficient drivers of their own recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Patients with disorders in arousal, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), are particularly susceptible to developing alcohol use disorders (AUD). In this application, I will study the novel role of astrocyte-neuron networks in the prefrontal cortex and their modulation by arousal-induced noradrenergic release while mice actively drink alcohol. These longitudinal studies of the relationship between astrocyte-neuron dynamics and arousal during alcohol consumption will provide important information on arousal disorders, such as PTSD and AUD, and may provide clinical hallmarks or therapeutic avenues for the treatment of these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Neural circuits determine our ability to locate and identify the objects that give rise to a visual scene. The breakdown of this ability can be observed in a number of neurological syndromes including visual agnosia. Studying how specific circuits and cell types contribute to normal visual perception will inform efforts to develop better diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The human cytochrome P450 enzymes P450 27A1, 27B1, and 27C1 are involved in the metabolism of endogenous hormones and vitamins. There is little known about the structures of these enzymes and how these structures change during the reactions the enzymes catalyze, making it difficult to develop clinical therapies that alter the activity of these enzymes. This research project seeks to enable the design of new and safer therapies for various diseases effected by hormone or vitamin levels by providing a more thorough description of how the structure of these enzymes affects their function.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: OVERALL: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE - NARRATIVE Child maltreatment is a public health crisis impacting more than 12% of US children. Unfortunately, this crisis has not fully benefitted from evidence-driven legislative action that is geared toward prevention and intervention to the same extent as other serious public health issues (e.g., smoking, obesity). Phase 2 of the Translational Center for Child Maltreatment Studies (TCCMS) will continue to conduct high-quality, high-impact science; translate and package this science into messages that resonate with community providers, policy makers and the general public; and traverse the Research-to-Policy Bridge by communicating these packages to legislative leaders. The TCCMS will continue to be a key national resource for conducting and rapidly disseminating impactful new science that can change health and development trajectories for survivors, mobilize public investment in child maltreatment prevention and treatment, accelerate science to practice, spark dynamic system-wide solutions, and support and inspire future generations to do the same.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is increasingly being applied to effectively treat mental illness, however efforts to quantify the effects of TMS on the network architecture of the brain have largely been limited in scope and tied to specific neurologic and psychiatric disorders. The objective of the current work is to build and validate a whole-brain, domain-general model of brain connectivity changes following TMS, based on physical models of the current distribution at the cortex. PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: This work is relevant to public health because it will provide direct evidence that brain connectivity changes following neuromodulatory TMS vary as a function of the current density at the cortex, which can be used to predict psychiatric symptom change following neuromodulatory TMS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV treatment programs throughout sub-Saharan Africa are adopting dolutegravir (DTG)-based regimens as first-line antiretroviral therapy (ART) despite early evidence that this agent is associated with excess weight gain. In this proposal, I will evaluate the behavioral correlates of weight change and glucose intolerance associated with DTG-based ART, apply these findings in developing contextually appropriate interventions to prevent weight gain and diabetes in people with HIV (PWH) and then assess these interventions in a factorial- randomized feasibility pilot study. This research is of high public health relevance given the widespread use of DTG globally, including up to 20 million PWH in sub-Saharan Africa, the background obesity epidemic in the region and the excellent platform offered by HIV treatment programs, through which interventions to prevent obesity can be delivered.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All humans are exposed to environmental endocrine-disrupting chemicals (EDCs) from industry, agriculture, and plastics. Experimental animal studies and epidemiological data in humans show that EDC exposures during hormone-sensitive periods early in life can change how the brain develops, and at the same time, affect future generations through actions on the germline (precursors to sperm and eggs). By identifying the molecular mechanisms by which developmental EDC exposures cause epigenetic changes in exposed individuals and their descendants, the proposed work has the potential to inform interventions for exposed humans and their offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application addresses the critical challenge of uptake, retention and equity in medications for opioid use disorder among adults with disabilities, assessing the factors associated with treatment patterns; impact on clinical outcomes including overdoses; and strategies for reducing disparities. We will utilize national Medicare data for 2008-2025 linked with the National Death Index, Medicaid claims, formulary policies, and other data sources to assess how policy, community, provider and patient factors interact to shape MOUD initiation and retention, and in turn overdose and other clinical outcomes, including differential uptake and outcomes associated with Medicare policy changes affecting tele-health reimbursement and formulary policies for MOUD. Results of this innovative and comprehensive assessment of the multi-level factors shaping MOUD uptake and outcomes among MDBs will have important implications for policy and practice across payers and health care systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance The newly emerging areas of stem cell biology, cell based therapies, gene therapy, cellular immunology, recombinant cytokines, and improving the safety and efficacy of transfused blood components have potential for the improvement of transfusion practices and the management of hematologic diseases. Thus, it is critical to train the next generation of investigators who can conduct basic, translational, and clinical research in Immunohematology and Transfusion Medicine. This proposed program renewal, with a 20 year successful history, aims to accomplish these goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this Specialized Innovation Program is to identify and overcome barriers that impede the translational science of rapid genomic medicine discoveries at the point of care by assembling the infrastructure, technology, and strategies to design and develop a rapid genomic diagnostic platform, using the newborn intensive care unit as our laboratory. We will design and develop an innovative, collaborative, patient- focused, and electronic health record-interfaced translational platform that efficiently integrates rapid genomic medicine at the point of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a leading cause of early-onset dementia, and loss-of-function mutations in progranulin (GRN) are one of three main genetic causes. Patients with FTD-GRN have activity deficits of neuronal β-glucocerebrosidase (GCase), a lysosomal enzyme implicated in Parkinson disease and Gaucher disease. This proposal seeks to determine if progranulin facilitates GCase trafficking and if loss of GCase activity contributes to lysosomal and behavioral abnormalities caused by progranulin deficiency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Small molecule based drugs continue to be a vital avenue for treating human disease. Requiring a chemical landscape that is persistently increasing in complexity, the discovery and development of these pharmaceuticals necessitates continued innovation in the synthetic chemistry involved in their construction if we are to solve outstanding problems in human health. The proposed work will develop new methods for the selective synthesis of a range of nitrogen-containing compounds, especially amines, streamlining and improving routes while also providing access to new chemical landscapes that are comprised of these medicinally proven scaffolds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Pain is a major public health problem that is common among older adults, especially women, yet women’s pain is frequently underdiagnosed and undertreated. Untreated pain is a potentially modifiable risk factor that may contribute to the gender disparity in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). Better understanding of these gender disparities is critical to improving the health of older adults, especially as women live longer than men and make up a larger proportion of older adults with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) is a globally significant threat to public health caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. Myeloid derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) are associated with increased disease severity and may contribute to TB pathogenesis but their functions at the site of disease and whether they can host Mtb remain to be elucidated. This project combines mechanistic and translational studies to investigate pathologic and potentially protective MDSC functions in TB to assess their suitability as targets for host-directed therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Primary age-related tauopathy (PART) is a pathology commonly observed in the brains of aged individuals de- scribed by the presences neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) and the in the absence of amyloid (Aβ) plaques. Here, we propose three independent approaches to understand the genetic, clinical, morphological, and transcriptomic architecture of PART to identify underlying mechanisms of tauopathy. The methods described here will bridge the current knowledge gap by providing an advanced understanding of the drivers of PART and distinguish disease pathogenesis and progression from normal aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria provide the fuel for cellular activities, and are frequently damaged in cardiovascular disorders, due to becoming overloaded with calcium. The main pathway for calcium to enter the mitochondria is through a channel known as the mitochondrial calcium uniporter. In this proposal, we will examine whether regulation of this channel can be exploited for new therapies targeting calcium overload.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efficient sensory processing relies on the development of precise connectivity and deficits in sensory processing are common in many neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs). However, the mechanisms underlying circuit development and the etiology of sensory deficits in NDDs are poorly understood, precluding the development of effective therapies. In this proposal, we will use a combination of in vivo anatomic, electrophysiologic, and environmental modification techniques in transgenic and knockout mouse models to elucidate the mechanisms by which proper connectivity is established in the developing visual system and how these processes are disrupted in NDDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide and overdose are at record levels and continue to rise; opioid use disorders (OUD) and mental illness are major contributors to both. Emergency Departments (ED) are a key location in which to engage patients. This study will inform the development of an adaptive intervention that is optimally effective in increasing buprenorphine use for adults presenting to the ED with an OUD-related event.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many older Americans who might like to work are unable to do so because of health-related functional limitations. This project develops a new way of measuring functional abilities that enables direct comparison with occupational requirements. We will use the new measures to identify whether it might be possible to design interventions to restore lost work capacity to individuals whose functional abilities have declined, through accommodation, rehabilitation or retraining.

PHR: Narrative:  Human immunodeficiency virus 1 (HIV-1) causing AIDS is currently treatable but not curable because the HIV virus cannot be eradicated from its reservoir organs like GALT. Our new Microfold-cell based nanodrug formulation can fulfill this dual aim by introducing the concept of smart nano-technology with targeted drug delivery to GALT and potential reduction of HIV reservoir. These efforts can accelerate the discovery of novel agent targeting existing viral reservoirs with a long-term suppressive antiviral activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Anemia of prematurity occurs in nearly all very low birth weight (VLBW; birth weight < 1,500 grams) infants who survive the initial postnatal course, and its main cause is blood loss from routine phlebotomy for its diagnosis. The proposed research project will develop a new image analysis algorithm (IAA) that analyzes full structural information of clinical pallor in fingernail photos to enable accurate, non-invasive prediction of blood hemoglobin level and anemia risk among VLBW infants. We will develop various data-driven tools that leverage longitudinal, patient-specific clinical data and IAA predictions to achieve the overarching clinical goal of minimizing the number of invasive blood sampling procedures throughout the care continuum for VLBW infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Mindfulness-based smartphone apps have surged in popularity in recent years (e.g., the Headspace app has over 42 million users). An estimated 11% of U.S. adolescents have used mindfulness apps as a means of coping with symptoms of depression and anxiety, which increase substantially during the adolescent years, and which have been repeatedly linked to rumination in youth. The research activities of the proposed R01 will investigate the underlying neural and cognitive mechanisms that account for the beneficial effects of these apps on rumination, and a machine learning algorithm will be developed to predict which specific adolescents are expected to benefit from app-based mindfulness training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is much controversy surrounding breast cancer screening guidelines, resulting in women making individual choices regarding their screening, in consultation with their physician. Unfortunately, there is insufficient information available to women as to the benefit of screening mammography for them as an individual. Our research goal is to develop a near-term mammography-detectable breast cancer risk marker using a new image transformation, deep learning, and statistical approach for longitudinal data on serial mammograms that will help women choose their own personalized protocol in consultation with their doctor.
