IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The goal of this project is to streamline access to pharmacologically relevant compounds by developing new catalytic methods for organic synthesis. In particular, this project focuses on controlling the reactivity and selectivity of transition metal catalysts with carbon-heteroatom bonds in the context of cross-coupling reactions. These new methods have the potential to make small molecule synthesis more efficient, thereby decreasing the cost of lead identification and optimization in the drug discovery process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The need for surgeries in patients with cirrhosis is increasing, however predicting their surgical risk is complex. Current tools are inadequate as they are not specifically designed to predict surgical risk, do not incorporate important variables such as surgery type, and are poorly calibrated. This proposal will use population-level data to derive and validate a novel cirrhosis surgical risk calculator, incorporate key stakeholder feedback to implement a web application, and use decision analysis to demonstrate the application of the tool in practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Acquired and genetic hemolytic disease states present significant levels of free heme and cell-free hemoglobin in the circulation. In this proposal, we propose to engineer a novel dual functional heme and hemoglobin scavenger complex consisting of apohemoglobin-haptoglobin that can reduce the side-effects associated with in vivo exposure to heme and hemoglobin. This work is significant since it proposes a novel therapeutic agent that can be used to treat the side-effects associated with various hemolytic disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-genetic changes in gene expression promote melanoma progression and metastasis; however, whether aberrant miRNA sequestration by competitive endogenous RNAs (ceRNAs) is involved in this process is unknown. We have discovered a cluster of ceRNA genes located on the frequently gained chromosome 1q region, and found that the mRNA with the greatest predicted ceRNA potential, CEP170, promotes melanoma migration/invasion in vitro and metastasis in vivo. We propose to define the miRNA-dependent oncogenic potential of CEP170 and characterize how the deregulation of downstream miRNAs and ceRNA effectors provokes melanoma metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current project reflects the NIDA priority to address the real-world complexities of substance use through a focus on the high-risk and complex phenomenon of polysubstance use; a behavior that substantially increases the risk of overdose mortality. The goal of this application is to use a rigorous mixed-method approach to develop and validate a novel polysubstance use assessment tool for use with vulnerable subpopulations (i.e., justice-involved, persons who inject drugs) and identify correlates and motivations of polysubstance use behaviors among this population to inform the development of future targeted interventions. The ability to accurately measure polysubstance use among high-risk populations is a critical step towards developing effective strategies for improving substance-related health outcomes of this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Einstein Aging Study will apply novel methods to increase understanding of modifiable risk factors for Alzheimer’s disease and associated dementias (ADRD) by examining their effects on cognitive performance and decline prior to ADRD onset. The project will provide new information regarding mechanisms linking exposures to cognitive outcomes and will inform future targeted interventions. The diverse cohort will advance understanding of ADRD disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The Administrative Core is responsible for coordinating administrative, scientific, and fiscal activities of the Einstein Aging Study (EAS) Program Project. The cohort is a systematic sample of our diverse Bronx Community. A major strength of this Core is its ability to facilitate efficient and effective sharing of data from the EAS through internal and external collaborations. These collaborations expand the utility of this valuable database by increasing the availability to the broader aging research community as well as to the communities represented by our participants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This revised proposal will greatly augment our collective understanding of the mechanisms governing the basic etiology and pathobiology of breast cancer following mitophagic induction and its relationship to proliferation and migration. This R03 grant application will establish feasibility and proof of concept that mitostatin is a fundamental tumor suppressor gene that robustly inhibits breast cancer growth and metastasis by evoking mitophagy. The expected outcomes and scientific knowledge collected and gleaned from our detailed studies have the potential to establish mitostatin as a prime candidate for novel therapeutic approaches to combat primary and metastatic breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE CLINICAL CORE The CC performs the essential role of rigorous clinical characterization of study participants to create a common foundation for use by the other Cores and Projects, including baseline assessment of cognitive status and progression over time. It is innovative in its use of both conventional and ambulatory methods to elucidate risk factors and cognitive outcomes in individuals’ natural environments. The CC has a strong track-record utilizing multiple modes of data collection, including telephone evaluations, in-person and virtual visits, ambulatory assessments, and at-home surveys to characterize participants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative: Sporadic frontotemporal lobar degeneration (sFTLD) and sporadic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (sALS) are two progressive and incurable neurodegenerative disorders along a spectrum of diseases related the RNA/DNA binding protein TAR DNA-binding Protein of 43 kDa (TDP-43). We have generated a novel mouse model of endogenous TDP-43 proteinopathy and sFTLD-ALS that recapitulates key disease hallmarks, thereby providing a platform to interrogate pathogenic mechanisms in sporadic disease. This project will investigate the role of an aberrant TDP-43 species in age-dependent neurodegeneration and impaired protein homeostasis, with the long- term goal of elucidating opportunities for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE BIOMARKER CORE The Biomarker Core will evaluate blood-based biomarkers that assess: 1) Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias(ADRD) including amyloid, tau and neurodegeneration, 2) genetics, 3) blood chemistry, and 4) autophagy. In addition, a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) sub-study will be conducted to provide cross- sectional measures of brain structure and physiology. Biomarkers will be used to improve diagnostic accuracy and inform the assessment of pathways linking novel risk factors to conventional and intensively measured cognitive outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related mortality in the United States, leading to more deaths than the next three cancers combined. Among patients with metastatic disease, median survival is less than 1.5 years, and less than 6% of patients are alive after 5 years. Rational, novel, therapeutic approaches combining in situ vaccination with immune checkpoint blockade offer the possibility of significant improvements in outcomes for patients with lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Impaired intramembranous bone regeneration can lead to failure of orhopaedic implants or delayed fracture healing. This project will elucidate molecular and therapeutic strategies with important translational implications for patients that undergo orthopaedic procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human cancer genome sequencing efforts have delivered an enormous amount of data on the genetic changes that occur during the process of carcinogenesis. Mathematical extraction of the complex data set reveals about 80 distinctive “mutational signatures” that hint at, but do not definitively prove, the molecular events that convert normal cells into cancer cells. Utilizing unique chemical and biological reagents, this proposal takes a bottom up approach to construct complex mutational signatures out of component parts, each of which is mechanistically well understood. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poor sleep health, low levels of physical activity and excessive sedentary behavior are common and modifiable factors that may be associated with increased risk for cognitive decline and Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias (ADRD), but they have not been studied together. We will use ambulatory methods to study the joint effects of these behaviors on cognitive performance, decline and impairment in a diverse community sample of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Doxorubicin alone or its combination with kinase inhibitor are highly effective strategies for treatment of breast cancer but their utility is limited due to a major side effect involving heart failure. Currently there is no effective therapy available to reduce or eliminate the risk of heart failure in cancer patients treated with these agents. We propose to study a novel combination of phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitor, sildenafil (Viagra) and the potent anti-rejection drug, rapamycin to reduce cardiac side effects and improve the efficacy of breast cancer treatment with doxorubicin and doxorubicin with the kinase inhibitor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Statement of Public Health Past research has identified depression, inflammation, and accelerated biological aging as independent risk factors for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD); however, because these factors have typically not been investigated at the same time, it is unclear how they intersect to confer risk. This project will investigate the unique, cumulative, and interactive impact of depression, inflammation, and biological aging on cognitive decline and ADRD risk, and will help unpack the underpinnings of racial disparities. Ultimately, this project will pave the way for tailored preventative interventions to reduce risk of cognitive aging and decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Type 2 diabetes is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, vascular dementia, mild cognitive impairment and accelerated cognitive decline. We proposed to expand the scope of science by incorporating continuous glucose monitoring paired with ambulatory cognitive assessments by smartphone to rigorously assess the relationships between blood glucose regulation and cognitive function in a racially and ethnically diverse at-risk population of older adults. This work will inform clinical care and the development of innovative interventions to optimize cognitive function for adults with type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Infants are the highest risk pediatric group for severe morbidity and mortality related to influenza and require unique interventions to protect them. Maternal influenza immunization reduces infections in these children, but research is needed to better understand how maternal vaccine protects infants and how it may be optimized to reduce infant infections. By comprehensively studying the role of maternal influenza immunization in the protection of infants against influenza, this project will directly inform efforts to improve delivery of influenza vaccine to pregnant women and influenza-related outcomes for infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: THE TRUSTEES OF THE STEVENS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY
PHR: Project Narrative Detection of clinical diabetic retinopathy (DR) can take several years from the onset of diabetes; hence, the long preclinical phase should provide a window to apply interventions that can slow or prevent progression to clinical endpoint (mild to severe visual impairment). Since the retinal vessels are early and prevalent targets of diabetic damage, sensitive identifiers of blood vessel changes hold great potential as biomarkers. Using a novel dynamic tracer kinetic model to quantitatively measure retinal vascular permeability and blood flow changes based on the fluorescein video-angiography imaging modality, the goal of this study is to demonstrate that the proposed dynamic tracer kinetic model can detect preclinical DR with a higher sensitivity and specificity than other retinal imaging modalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Overall Component, RFA-CA-22-040) We propose to develop a blood-based test whose indicated use is to complement mammography in the early detection of breast cancers. Using a novel biomarker discovery approach leveraging human-in-mouse breast cancer patient-derived xenograft models and state-of-the-art mass spectrometry methods, we previously prioritized 162 candidate blood-based breast cancer protein biomarkers for validation studies. This project will perform EDRN Phase 2 biomarker validation studies of our prioritized 162 candidate plasma protein biomarkers of breast cancer, using clinical grade immuno-MRM assays run in our CLIA Laboratories to analyze strongly unbiased collections of plasma to evaluate the performance metrics of single or multiple protein panels in EDRN phase 2 case-control validation studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  To meet the increasing demands for safer, yet effective medicines, scientists are using deuterated small molecules to develop novel therapeutics. Despite the tremendous advantages and recent success of deuterated medicines, highly selective chemical reactions to access novel deuterated small molecules and the analytical spectroscopic techniques to support developing these reactions are severely lagging. The proposed research is designed to modernize the synthesis of deuterated small molecules and to advance the field of regioselective aryl alkyne hydrofunctionalization chemistry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative This project develops statistical foundations necessary for understanding how the interaction of sketching techniques and molecular evolution affects the accuracy of commonly used algorithms for sequencing data. These foundations allow us to quantify uncertainty when studying communities of microorganisms and both identify the taxa present in biological samples and identify samples that possess a large fraction of novel genetic material. We also develop new functionality that captures uncertainty in sequence alignment, one of the most ubiquitous computational techniques in biomedicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: His-Bundle Corrective Pacing in Heart Failure Heart failure patients with right bundle branch block (RBBB) ECG morphology have been shown to have a suboptimal response to biventricular cardiac resynchronization therapy (BIV-CRT), necessitating the identification of improved treatment strategies. His-bundle corrective pacing for cardiac resynchronization therapy (His-CRT) is an emerging innovative technology that provides more physiologic resynchronization than BIV-CRT, and could better treat patients with RBBB. In this randomized clinical trial, we will prospectively evaluate the efficacy and the mechanism of benefit of His-CRT vs. BIV-CRT by evaluating changes in ECG biomarkers, NT-proBNP, and echo biomarkers at 6 months, and by assessing the temporal changes in ECG biomarkers, NT- proBNP, functional status and quality of life at 6, 12, and 24 months of follow-up in 120 HF patients with right bundle branch block (RBBB) ECG morphology.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Children who are HIV-exposed uninfected (HEU), i.e. children who do not acquire HIV infection despite HIV infection in their mothers, have a higher risk of mortality, infectious morbidity, and growth deficits than children who are HIV-unexposed uninfected (HUU). We propose to conduct a randomized trial of an intervention which combines human milk oligosaccharides and probiotics in breast-fed HEU infants in South Africa. The aim is to determine whether this intervention can reduce the excess infectious morbidity and growth faltering risks observed in HEU infants.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The Role of Fathering in the Language Development Among Young, Low-Income African American and Latino Children Project Narrative  Recent studies of low-income children have revealed significant variations in the quality of parent-child communication as well as the quantity of parent input is important for successful child language development. However, the majority of this research has focused on mothers, and more research with ethnic minority fathers is critical for the development of preventive interventions to support language development and early academic success. In this study, we will use video-recorded data from an existing study to refine a rating system to capture characteristics of the father-child joint engagement in a sample of low-income African American and Latino fathers and their young children to examine relations between the quality of the father-child joint engagement and language input and later child language development and school readiness using data already being collected as part of the parent longitudinal study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dry eye disease is one of the most common worldwide ophthalmic conditions, affecting at least sixteen million Americans, in addition to millions more undiagnosed cases that will all rise substantially due to the continuing growth of inflammatory disorders and screen time among the population. In this SBIR Phase II project, we propose to continue the successful development of a drug delivery contact lens (DDCL) that administers cyclosporine A (CsA) using a novel formulation of nano-ingredients to resolve key deficiencies of eye drop formulations; for example, limited bioavailability, both from tear wash-out and vehicular compromises required to solubilize the drug ingredient. The Phase II research strategy will culminate in an IND application for clinical study of the DDCL in a human population, while the commercialization strategy's goal is the development of the product for FDA approval in the US, with the support of a licensing agreement and investment from an established industrial partner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will consist of two complementary studies at diverse urban, suburban, and rural primary care practices within Central Indiana and South Florida. The first study Aim will evaluate the predictive performance of the Passive Digital Marker, the Quick Dementia Rating Scale (QDRS) using Patient-reported Outcome (PRO) data embedded within the Electronic Health Records, and the combined approach (Passive + QDRS) in the early detection of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD), compared to the gold standard of diagnoses. The second study Aim will evaluate the practical utility and effect of the Passive Digital Marker, the QDRS, and the combined methods in improving the annual rate of new documented ADRD diagnosis in primary care practices. The project will compare different approaches to early detection of ADRD, crucial to the endeavors to stop dementia progression; it will also evaluate the low-cost combined methods and integrated approach to overcome current barriers to ADRD detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The overall goal of the UC Davis ADAR Scholars Program is to diversify the workforce in aging research by supporting undergraduate competency and completion of MSTEM degrees and increasing the number of diverse students entering graduate study in aging-related MSTEM fields. We have developed a series of activities for underrepresented, socioeconomically disadvantaged, and disabled undergraduates. These activities are designed to help the students develop their scientific identity, kindle interest in aging research, and to facilitate the development of their professional skills in preparation to excel in graduate programs and careers in aging science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research investigates molecular events called exitrons that can change the sequence of genes and spark abnormal cancer-causing proteins. Our goals are to understand the role of exitrons in cancer initiation and progression, determine if exitron expression can be used to identify patients who will respond to immune targeted therapies, and ultimately find novel ways in cancer treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Overall Component Project Narrative The NE-INBRE is designed to increase the biomedical research and training capacity at institutions of higher education and contribute to the development of the scientific workforce in the state. Primarily undergraduate institutions receive funding to enhance their faculty research and establish modern laboratories, thus providing opportunities for undergraduate students to engage in modern research and consider entering a career in research and/or the health professions. Research universities receive funding to support the development of multiuser core facilities that make cutting edge technology available to research programs on these campuses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this project is to create a nucleotide-resolution cis-regulatory map of the human genome to connect disease variants to functions and phenotypes, in collaboration with the IGVF Consortium. We will use our new methods to help interpret common and rare genetic variation, and to identify variants that may contribute to disease. Outputs from the project will include new computational methods, open-source software, and publicly available cis-regulatory maps for diverse cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Relevance: This research aims to develop and validate a technology that will help medical trainees practice their skills using afforable and widely available head-mounted displays for an emerging minimally-invasive procedure for robotic head and neck surgeries. A well-established and safe commercially available neurostimulation device will be used to help the trainees improve their performance. The proposed stimulated simulation training methodology will allow clinicians to learn the procedure in a risk-free manner on computers before application to patients, resulting in lower errors, improved patient outcomes, and reduced treatment costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The Pathways Study is a multi-ethnic prospective cohort study of women diagnosed and treated for breast cancer in the Kaiser Permanente Northern California (KPNC) integrated health care system that is designed to examine multi-level factors to improve the breast cancer experience and outcomes. The study includes patient-reported health and lifestyle behaviors such as food intake, physical activity, and quality of life; molecular and genetic factors from blood specimens; a tumor bank; clinical factors from electronic health records; neighborhood factors from geospatial databases and virtual neighborhood audits; and a Community Advisory Board to help guide infrastructure activities and prioritize research use of this cohort. We propose to enhance this resource in various ways, including continued follow-up, new data linkages with environmental exposure and statewide health care utilization data, and with creation of a complementary data-only cohort of women diagnosed with breast cancer in KPNC from 2006 to 2023, thus cementing this resource as the outstanding setting for epidemiologic studies of breast cancer survivorship and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative This project proposes to understand the nuanced nature of SIRT1 regulation by small molecules and by its own regulatory domains. The findings will provide crucial information to help evaluate off-target effects for SIRT1-targeting therapeutics and to clarify regulation of SIRT1 within the cell. The knowledge gained here can also shed light on the mechanism for regulation of other multidomain post-translational modification enzymes, many of which are integral to human health.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Project Narrative National Biocontainment Laboratories Operational Support ensures the availability of maximum containment laboratories for research that will develop the next generation of therapeutics, diagnostics and vaccines for infectious diseases that can pose a public health risk. It also ensures that high containment labs are available in the event of a public health or bioterrorism emergency. This support is essential due to the high cost of building and maintaining laboratories that protect researchers, ensure the biosecurity of dangerous pathogens, and safeguard the communities where these laboratories are located.

PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences) Voltage-gated sodium channels are important membrane proteins regulating the excitability of many cells, tissues. Based on available atomic structures, my project will uncover the dynamic behaviors of model NavAb and human cardiac Nav1.5 channels in membrane environments with single molecule fluorescence imaging in combination with unnatural amino acid incorporation techniques. Together with functional characterizations, the proposed studies will elucidate the fundamental mechanisms underlying ion permeation, channel gating, and drug modulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the unprecedent success of T cell immunotherapies in treating some previously refractory cancers, terminal exhaustion of chronically stimulated T cells remains a major obstacle to achieving durable protective immune responses. We discovered a novel approach to synergize the efficacy of T cell immunotherapies by modulating microenvironmental signals that regulate T cell-intrinsic epigenetic programs. The goals of this grant are to identify the role of these upstream regulators of the epigenetic programs specific to terminally-exhausted T cells, and to re-route their epigenetic programming toward the functional state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A new tuberculosis (TB) vaccine is urgently needed to bring an end to the deadly TB epidemic, which, only second to COVID-19, kills more people than any other infectious disease in the world. The only effective strategy to meet the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and the WHO End TB strategy is a TB vaccine to stop transmission (8, 9), which would be the single most cost-effective tool in ending the TB epidemic (5). The cutting-edge mRNA platform, recently proven as an effective vaccine technology against COVID- 19, combined with rationally selected Mtb antigens and IAVI’s strong track record for vaccine development, make this approach well-positioned to deliver a meaningful impact on public health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Growing evidence demonstrates that secure attachment in childhood predicts children’s healthy social, biological, and behavioral functioning, whereas insecure attachment predicts behavior problems and physiological dysregulation; thus, efforts to foster secure attachment are crucial for promoting the healthy development of children and families. This proposal describes a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of an innovative intervention program that can be widely implemented designed to foster children’s secure attachment, promote healthy physiological regulation, and reduce the risk for behavior problems: The Circle of Security – Parenting intervention. To this end, we will conduct an RCT with 249 parent-child dyads enrolled in two diverse Early Head Start programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Our nervous system controls such remarkable abilities as learning, speaking, and walking only because our neurons communicate in highly organized networks. The goal of this proposal is to characterize the molecular and biochemical mechanisms that enable neurons to find and connect with one another during development and maintain these proper connections through-out adulthood. Understanding how these connections are assembled, integrated, and maintained will suggest solutions to diminish the burden of mental illness, reveal fundamental mechanisms underlying thought, emotion, and behavior, identify therapeutic strategies for multiple brain diseases and disorders, and contribute to healthy recovery following neural trauma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although metabolic demand from neuronal function has been shown to regulate vascular development in the retina, a detailed mechanistic understanding of how neuronal activity influences angiogenesis and blood-retinal barrier maturation remains unknown. This project will explore how cholinergic and glutamatergic neuronal activities (separately or in combination) regulate retinal angiogenesis and blood-retinal barrier maturation using genetic, molecular and imaging approaches. The knowledge gathered from this project may be of critical importance to understand the pathophysiology of retinal diseases associated with neurodegeneration and develop novel therapeutic interventions for their treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  This project will design and implement a user-friendly, versatile, and computationally efﬁcient R pack- age named TranStat for analyzing infectious disease transmission in close contact groups such as house- holds, classrooms, hospitals, and workplaces. It will provide power and sample size calculation for de- signing observational studies and intervention trials to evaluate control strategies in these settings, and it will include a detailed user manual, vignettes and example data sets. TranStat will allow public health ofﬁcials and researchers to design and analyze longitudinal studies of infectious disease transmission in close contact groups, generating critical insights to inform public health responses to infectious diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative Vascular malformations are a significant contributor to morbidity and are caused by mutations in PIK3CA. We have a unique animal model of PIK3CA-induced vascular malformation and will use this model in combination with other novel animal models and three-dimensional cell-based methods, to elucidate the molecular underpinnings of vascular malformations and effective strategies to treat this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Recent advances in human genetics and genomics have identified a huge number of variations, some of which are responsible for genetically-inherited disorders, but for most, their impact on human health is completely unknown. In the context of the IGVF Consortium, we will functionally characterize the impact of variants for most Mendelian disease genes by comparing variant gene products with their reference gene product using an array of fundamental properties of proteins and phenotypic impacts, including protein stability (expression), subcellular localization, cell viability, cell morphology, and protein interactions. All data will be shared publicly with the IGVF “Genomic Variation and Function” Data and Administrative Coordinating Centers (DACCs) and “Predictive Modeling Projects” to increase the value of the results for the broad scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Mechanical forces play key regulatory roles in biology, with the emergent field of mechanobiology leading to new understandings of diseases such as bleeding disorders, cancer, and infectious diseases. However, discoveries have been impeded by limited access to instrumentation, challenging technical requirements, and constraints of current capabilities. We will solve these problems by developing powerful and accessible new nanoscale approaches that will democratize the fields of mechanobiology and single-molecule manipulation to accelerate the pace of discovery, and apply these approaches to answer key questions in the areas of hemostasis, immunology, and hearing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is a phase I/II clinical trial to assess safety and efficacy of combination immunotherapy (Aim 1) of malignant pleural mesothelioma treated with autologous chimeric antigen receptor T cells genetically engineered to target mesothelin followed by pembrolizumab, an anti–PD-1 checkpoint blockade agent. We will analyze serially collected samples to assess adoptive (Aim 2) and endogenous immunity (Aim 3). Assessing the ability of checkpoint blockade to restore adoptive and endogenous T-cell function will advance our understanding of the immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a serious public health problem, and alcohol-associated cognitive impairments contribute to the progression of AUD. This proposal will evaluate the combination of donepezil and cognitive remediation therapy (donepezil + CRT) as a treatment for AUD. This project has clinical potential to help patients suffering from AUD by improving their cognition and reducing alcohol consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We are collecting genetic data at an ever-increasing rate, driven largely by our success in understanding both rare and common diseases using today’s vast genomic datasets. Our computational methods are lagging far behind, however, and without fundamental improvements in how we store and process genomic data, we may never fully realize the potential health benefits of the data we are gathering. Our project applies the revolutionary “succinct tree sequence” data structure – which has yielded orders-of-magnitude gains in decades-old problems since its recent introduction – to produce further major gains in fundamental genomics algorithms, genome simulation, and inference from genomic data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Injectable therapies for blocking vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) have provided impressive initial benefits to most patients with neovascular age-related macular degeneration (nAMD), though some have a suboptimal response. Another drawback of anti-VEGF therapies is the short duration of action that requires that patients return to the clinic for injections every 1-2 months. Here we describe a novel topical drug delivery strategy for effective, patient-controlled delivery of inhibitors of hypoxia-inducible factor 1 (HIF-1) to provide broad suppression of vasoactive proteins in ocular diseases with neovascular sequelae.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The way how various signaling pathways orchestrate cochlear development may be a key determinant to develop rational strategies in the treatment of hearing loss. We utilize mouse models to identify critical pathways and signaling molecules of the gene regulatory network that contribute to the development of the organ. The findings of this study will enhance our understanding of the developmental process and could lead to novel targets for the treatment of hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Despite the advances in cardiovascular disease prevention and therapeutics, the continued increase in metabolic disorders, such as diabetes and insulin resistance, associated with the obesity epidemic has driven up total mortality rates in the US for the first time in 10 years. To address this, our research is designed to understand how we can maintain an healthy storage of lipids in the adipose tissue to promote functional adipose tissue expansion and remodeling. Our findings will help identify novel strategies for treating metabolically driven cardiovascular heart disease and related complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants with orofacial clefts (‘cleft’) are at high risk of malnutrition in the first months of life, likely due to a host of factors involving the lack of timely care with the appropriate specialists, social determinants of health in the family, source of nutrition (e.g., breastmilk, formula), appropriate resources (e.g., bottles, breast pumps), caregiver factors, and infant health characteristics. This project will develop a predictive model using data from 18,000 US infants to identify infants at high-risk of developing malnutrition and determine the impact of undernutrition on adverse health outcomes including infection, surgical complications, and caregiver stress and reduced quality of life. Our findings will inform the development of tailored, high impact interventions to ensure timely growth and health of US infants with cleft.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eccrine sweat glands are water-secreting exocrine organs that arise from the skin during development and are indispensable components of the human thermoregulatory system. We have identified a novel population of cells in the dermal skin layer that is specified immediately next to each developing human and mouse eccrine gland and have shown that eccrine glands fail to develop when this dermal population is ablated. The proposed aims will define the mechanisms through which this eccrine-associated dermal population forms and directs eccrine gland formation, thereby generating a first-of-its kind recipe of extrinsic factors that can be leveraged in therapeutic efforts to repair and regenerate these essential human skin appendages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Glenohumeral osteoarthritis is a leading cause of shoulder pain and disability, but a lack of investigation of glenohumeral osteoarthritis risk factors has resulted in insufficient insights to guide evidence-based prevention and treatment strategies. Our proposal aims to leverage multiple existing data resources to determine associations of occupational exposures with osteoarthritis-related shoulder arthroplasty risk, identify genetic variants associated with risk of osteoarthritis-related shoulder arthroplasty, and develop prediction models for osteoarthritis-related shoulder arthroplasty. An understanding of glenohumeral osteoarthritis risk factors is critically needed to inform design of prevention approaches, provide new insights into osteoarthritis etiology, and to improve patient counseling in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will combine computational modeling and neuroimaging methods to study social and cognitive computations performed by the posterior cerebellum. The F99 phase will examine how the posterior cerebellum uniquely contributes to monetary and social reward processing, improving our basic scientific understanding of the cerebellum's core algorithmic capabilities and revealing the cerebellum's potential range of neural computations. The K00 phase will explore the cerebellum's mechanistic role in autism spectrum disorder through a reinforcement learning framework, providing insight into how a disruption in these processes may cause the canonical social deficits observed in this disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to develop our understanding of how stimulation of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) influences the amygdala by utilizing a unique combination of invasive and noninvasive stimulation and recording techniques in humans. The findings will contribute to the development of a novel circuit-based strategy for precisely identifying a reliable stimulation site within the DLPFC that can effectively target and modulate the amygdala. This strategy will facilitate the rational design and widespread adoption of amygdala-targeted noninvasive neuromodulatory therapies for psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is widely used to study how the human brain interacts with the world and how regions of the brain function as networks. However, head movement during the experiment – even just a few millimeters – leads to errors in the results and often severely limits research in populations that are likely to move, such as young children. In this project, we will develop comprehensive motion correction software that can be used in existing MRI scanners around the world to rapidly measure and compensate for all the relevant effects caused by head movement to provide stable, high-quality data. Our aim is to enable accurate assessment of functional networks despite being acquired during head motion.

PHR: Elucidating the cellular and molecular underpinnings of liver injury repair may yield improved cures for liver diseases, which remain a global and national health burden. Pittsburgh Liver Research Center was created to address this issue by providing a group of invested established and early stage investigators an opportunity to interact and collaborate as well as have access to the most advanced scientific core facilities. We believe that PLRC will have a major impact on treatment of liver disease patients by enabling innovative discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE The Eating Disorders Genetics Initiative 2 (EDGI2) unites existing and exceptionally productive and collaborative sites globally to advance genetic discovery across all eating disorders (anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, binge-eating disorder, and avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder). We will apply both novel and established methods to optimize discovery in our diverse and severely ill sample, culminating in a clinical translation summit. Our goal is to identify biologically, clinically, culturally, and therapeutically meaningful and actionable insights and rapidly transition the field from discovery to clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Anhedonia, the inability to anticipate or experience pleasure, emerges in adolescence, often heralds the onset of more severe psychopathology such as mood disorders and psychosis, and remains poorly understood. Atypical stress response and related dysregulation of neurobiological mechanisms have been proposed as key contributors to anhedonia. The proposed project will examine the individual and interactive roles of physiological and neural mechanisms associated with acute stress experiences to the severity and maturational trajectory of anhedonia in adolescence, thereby potentially informing the development of novel prevention and intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Viruses and bacteria underlie different human diseases, imposing a major, continual health threat. We propose to develop novel computational methods to detect and quantify microbial genes in human diseases. These methods will unravel new roles of microbes in human diseases and can ultimately lead to biomarker discovery and development of new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will examine the role of phosphate in vascular smooth muscle cell calcification and the potential of protein therapy to reduce calcification. The proposed protein therapy would include reestablish fetuin-A to its native levels to treat smooth muscle cell calcification in patients with the comorbidities of heart disease and chronic kidney disease. Through a collaboration with MSU Extension we will work to increase the diversity of the biomedical workforce while allowing the participants to give back to their communities and help older generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  We discovered that suppressing UNC45A in mouse in vivo syngeneic TNBC tumors triggers a drastic reprogramming of the immune-suppressive tumor microenvironment into a more immune- responsive one. In addition, loss of UNC45A hampers the ability of cancer cells to repair ionizing radiation (IR)-induced DNA damage and sensitizes TNBC models to radiation therapy. In this application, we propose that UNC45A is a promising novel immunotherapeutic target and that its inhibition, in combination with IR therapy, will reduce the TNBC burden.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Few neurological conditions are as complex and devastating as stroke. It is a major cause of disability in the United States and in the aging population of veterans. While there have been important strides taken toward optimizing functional recovery, a substantial proportion of stroke survivors continue to experience long-term motor disability. The goal of this proposal is to develop a better neurophysiological model of the circuit basis of recovery and to use this to test new therapeutic approaches. We hope to use this knowledge to create novel therapies to promote motor recovery. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The processes of learning and memory can be shaped by internal and external contextual cues. State- dependent learning occurs when learning happens while the subject is in a specific internal state (e.g. intoxication) and the memory is only recalled when the subject is in the same internal state. This project aims to develop a molecular understanding of how state is encoded and how it modulates the processes of learning and remembering.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Periodontitis afflicts ~ 50% of the adult population in the United States with substantial socio- economic impacts. Porphyromonas gingivalis has been strongly implicated in periodontitis. The proposed studies will decipher the regulatory role of a novel signaling pathway that controls the lipopolysaccharide driven pathoadaptation and pathogenesis of Pg, contributing to periodontitis progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work will produce a powerful technology platform that opens the door to the study of structure establishment by functional nucleic acids. The technology provides the solution to the unmet need to resolve oligonucleotide structural transformations, co-existing solution structures, and conformer flexibility with ultra-high sensitivity. Unleashing the true potential of structure establishment analyses for functional nucleic acids will have an indelible impact on the development of new therapeutic strategies for diverse diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Congenital disabilites are often linked to defects on the development of the neural crest, a group of migratory stem cells that give rise to the craniofacial skeleton. Studying the molecular mechanisms controlling the formation of these cells can reveal the genetic causes of craniofacial diseases. This knowledge can improve diagnosis, treatments, and guide stem cell differentiation for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to smoke emitted from wildfires has been linked to a variety of health effects, including increased risks associated with respiratory viral infections, thus presenting a critical public health concern. Using human in vivo and in vitro models, the studies in this application will provide a comprehensive characterization of antiviral defense response changes associated with woodsmoke exposure in humans and link mechanistic understanding of respiratory immune dysfunction to these exposures. This cross-disciplinary proposal brings together a diverse skill set to study a unique interface between the chemistry of wildfire smoke and clinically important outcomes of influenza infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study uses AI methods to anonymize the faces and voices of children with ASD in videos while preserving critical information needed for the ASD diagnostic process. We use these methods to develop and test new, anonymized assessment methods based on crowdsourcing and computational prediction. Finally, by co- designing human-in-the-loop tools with parents and clinicians to privatize videos, we develop more usable and mature workflows that can make real-world anonymization a practical reality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: INTERNATIONAL AGENCY FOR RES ON CANCER
PHR: Narrative Over the past two decades, prescription opioid use in the US has sharply risen, with over 17% of Americans now annually using these medications, prompting its classification as a public health emergency. Recently, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classified use of opium (natural source for many opioids) as "carcinogenic to humans" raising concerns on how using prescription opioids may relate to subsequent cancer risk, given their close similarity in composition and mechanisms of action. The Opioid Cohort Consortium (OPICO) project will analyze over 1.7 million people from existing cohort studies in the United States, Europe, and Australia to assess whether use of prescription opioids may increase risk for specific cancers and provide robust evidence that could aim in developing national prevention strategies and targeted early detection policies to mitigate the future burden of the current opioid crisis.

PHR: Project Narrative Placement of orthopaedic implants, such as a K-wires and screws, is a common surgical task, and accurate placement is critical to the success of a wide range of orthopaedic procedures. However, the rate of screw misplacement is highly variable which can lead to poor outcomes. In this proposal we will develop and evaluate a system that should improve the surgeon’s ability to accurately place the screw while minimizing radiation dose to the patient and surgeon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative While platelets are critical for maintaining hemostasis and vascular integrity, there is a significant unmet need in identifying new targets that modulate platelet counts from their precursor cells, megakaryocytes. We recently discovered that membrane polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) in megakaryocyte progenitors regulate megakaryocyte development and platelet production and represent a novel target for modulating megakaryopoiesis and platelet counts. The experiments outlined in this proposal will provide a detailed and actionable roadmap of the mechanisms by which both human and murine megakaryocytes and progenitors accumulate and utilize PUFAs to drive platelet production so that we can ultimately enhance and/or fine tune megakaryocyte and platelet production to improve outcomes for patients with diverse thrombotic and platelet disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Disrupted sleep and circadian patterns are a primary feature of bipolar disorder and may represent a significant mechanistic treatment target. Bipolar Disorder I may be associated with increased sensitivity to light, but this has not been comprehensively assessed with the most direct measure of light sensitivity: the post-illumination pupil response (PIPR). In this study we will compare light sensitivity between people with bipolar disorder I versus healthy controls and determine if light sensitivity drives daily variability in sleep, mood and energy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Patients undergoing pelvic surgeries are confronted with a considerable risk for developing both bladder and erectile dysfunction, despite the utilization of nerve-sparing techniques. With this in mind, the primary objective of this proposal is to examine fundamental mechanisms that contribute to the simultaneous manifestation of these post-surgical urogenital complications. Our central hypothesis posits that an abnormal inflammatory response within the major pelvic ganglia (MPG) serves as a mediator for pelvic organ cross-communication, leading to the synchronized progression of bladder and erectile dysfunction; by exploring this hypothesis, we aim to uncover potential interventions that can modulate this inflammatory response, thus potentially enhancing the post-operative urogenital function outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Several major health organizations have emphasized the need for obesity prevention interventions in early childhood. Parent involvement is critical for effective early childhood interventions, but few programs successfully engage parents. There is evidence that families of young children enjoy participating in playgroups, which are social and educational parent-child groups. Benefits of delivering obesity prevention content via playgroups are they overcome the need for childcare and they offer the opportunity for use of evidence based parenting behavior techniques commonly used by family therapists. This study will test whether a playgroup intervention improves diet and activity behaviors of toddlers to a greater extent than no treatment or standard health education for parents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will evaluate the effects of Healthy Juntos, a family-based digital lifestyle intervention, in preventing increases in body mass index and improving moderate-to-vigorous physical activity, diet quality, and percentage body fat among Hispanic adolescents. It will also examine whether the intervention improves parent weight status and lifestyle behaviors, family functioning and health-related positive parenting practices. The knowledge expected to be gained from this study has the potential to transform the type of obesity and cancer prevention programs that are disseminated to improve the health of US Hispanic families.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drinking water instead of sugared beverages can help prevent obesity and dental caries, two of the most prevalent pediatric diseases, disproportionately impacting marginalized youth. This investigation will partner with schools to conduct a water-promotion intervention, targeting multiple levels of influence on student hydration. Results will determine intervention effectiveness and sustainability, within a district that has newly installed hydration stations and is operating under a policy designed to enhance healthy hydration practices and promote equitable access to water.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a common lung complication in premature infants, impairing their lung development and long-term respiratory health. Our research focuses on mitochondrial dysfunction and specific genetic variations called mtDNA haplogroups, which contribute to the severity of BPD. By investigating the role of mtDNA haplogroups and exploring potential therapeutic interventions, we aim to develop personalized strategies that can mitigate the risk of BPD and improve outcomes for premature infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pharmacotherapy offers promise as an obesity treatment by limiting external drivers of overeating, promoting adherence to healthful lifestyle behaviors involved in energy balance regulation. Phentermine, the most- prescribed anti-obesity medication, is a sympathetic nervous system stimulant, yet its effects on sleep, an established behavioral determinant of diet, activity, and body weight, have not been evaluated. We propose to formally test the impact of phentermine vs. placebo on sleep and explore whether sleep during the intervention period influences the efficacy of phentermine in improving body weight, diet, and physical activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Youth with significant behavioral health needs make more clinical progress when their treatment planning is informed by ongoing quantitative data collection; however, aides often do not collect high quality data consistent with evidence-based practice. This R01 uses a randomized hybrid type 2 effectiveness-implementation pragmatic mixed-methods trial design to test a behavioral-economics informed digital health measurement feedback application (“Footsteps”) to improve implementation of data collection quality and youth mental health outcomes. This will be one of the first studies to examine the effect of theory-informed behavior change mechanisms on data collection in behavioral health care and will advance the science of digital health as a support to practitioners in implementing behavioral health evidence-based practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolic syndrome affects greater than one in three individuals in the United States, increasing risk for pathogenic infections, heart disease, diabetes, and other issues that affect health. The risks associated with metabolic syndrome and the responsiveness to interventions (e.g., dietary interventions) vary substantially among individuals, yet the biological factors driving this variation are poorly understood. The proposed work will employ a manipulative experiment in mice to determine how high-fat diets drive adaptive evolution of gut bacterial species and how bacterial adaptation to high- fat diets affects metabolic traits in hosts, thereby revealing how strains in the microbiome contribute to host metabolic syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Strategies to shift food choices in the US toward a ‘planetary health’ dietary pattern, which is both more environmentally sustainable and healthier, are needed. This research project will use two sequential randomized controlled experiments to determine the degree to which climate-impact menu labels on fast-food restaurant menus influence the healthfulness of restaurant food choices and overall dietary intake. Results will provide critically important, timely, and actionable evidence to inform menu label policy and voluntary interventions to improve dietary quality and diet-related health of Americans while helping to address the urgent threat of climate change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Sepsis, a life-threatening condition triggered by an uncontrolled response to infection, is a leading cause of mortality in intensive care units globally. Liver dysfunction, a common complication in septic patients, significantly affects prognosis and is an independent predictor of mortality. This study uncovers the novel role of liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSECs) in regulating Kupffer cell zonation, bacterial clearance, and hepatic gluconeogenesis during sepsis, offering valuable insights for improving patient outcomes in this critical condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE IgE is an evolutionarily conserved antibody isotype well-known for its deleterious role in allergic disease but poorly characterized in other settings. Using a novel genetic approach, we found that in all conditions tested, IgE reacts to a discrete set of antigens compared to IgG, and that IgE recognition of antigen influences host response to acute inflammatory challenge. By identifying antigenic targets of IgE, we will investigate the fundamental roles played by IgE during homeostasis and host protection from disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative People with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (PALS) have diminished verbal communication abilities that decline due to disease progression and negatively affect quality of life. Current interventions addressing this issue have limited utility in degenerative conditions such as ALS in which the speaker’s abilities continue to decline in spite of intervention. The proposed work evaluates the promise of developing new interventions that leverage communicative interactions to improve verbal communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Risk of death for Black patients with HPV-negative oropharyngeal cancer (OPC) is significantly worse compared to White, Hispanic, and Asian patients even after adjusting for socioeconomic, demographic and disease related effects. Survey data suggests that Black, Hispanic/Latino and White patients agree that non-White patients with cancer are more likely than White patients to receive poor quality care. <5% of the oncology workforce (i.e. medical, surgical, radiation oncology etc.) identifies as an underrepresented minority (URM), which has implications for racial bias, discrimination, and cultural compentency.  The scientific premise of this proposal is based on the integration of spatial transcriptomics and artificial intelligence (AI) pathomics to conduct a differential expression analysis between Black and White patients with HPV-negative OPC. We have previous experience using these approaches as a basis to understand gene expression changes between Black and White patients with HPV-positive OPC, which is a distinct neoplastic entity when compared to HPV-negative OPC. Therefore, we will identify differences in gene expression and stromal and immune cell topology between Black and White patients to identify biologic mechanism(s) that underlies racial disparities with respect to oncologic outcomes. Moreover, within this research proposal, in partnership with minority serving schools, we will create two pathways to address the disparity in the oncology workforce, including translational research. We will address these gaps in the field by pursuing the following specific aims: In Aim 1, we will determine spatial gene expression differences Black vs. White patients with HPV-negative OPC. In Aim 2, we will integrate spatial genomics and AI-guided pathomics between high vs. low pathomic expression within tissue types, controlling for self-reported race. To address the gap in URM in the oncology workforce, in Aim 3 we will work in partnership with City of Medicine Academy and Howard University to provide a longitudinal oncology research experience for high school students and surgical residents. In Aim 4, we will provide a laboratory incubator space in which URM Duke Faculty will be embedded to pursue cancer research, along with mentoring from experienced and committed mentors.  We propose to address these important issues and lack of reliable biomarkers for all patients by integrating state-of-the-art techniques in genomics, pathomics, and AI, in a setting fostering diversity and inclusion. The data generated will be of benefit to all patients with HPV- negative OPCs as we are presently unable to identify poor responders regardless of race.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Medically complex older Veterans are at greater risk for progressive declines in physical function, lower quality of life, and increasing care needs. Additionally, older Veterans experience social isolation and loneliness, and have low levels of physical activity. While the Veterans Health Administration has established programs to address rehabilitation needs, these programs tend to be diagnosis-focused, lack self-management approaches, include low-intensity rehabilitation, and typically require in-person attendance. A MultiComponent TeleRehabilitation (MCTR) program that includes high-intensity rehabilitation and self-management interventions, social support, and telehealth and technology supports may be more effective in improving and sustaining physical function for older Veterans with complex health conditions. Therefore, this project is designed to determine whether the MCTR program improves strength and physical function more effectively than traditional interventions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to create a first-of-its-kind Mother-infant Metabolite-transporter Atlas (MiMA) by generating and integrating information on structure, function, and localization of novel transporter-metabolite pairs that allow maternal infant communication through the mother’s milk→infant gut→infant’s blood-brain-barrier. Although MiMA will generate these insights in the context of mother-infant milk-gut-BBB axis, systems level integration of information is expected to enable the extraction of actionable insights into which metabolites bind to which transporters, to get transported from where to where in diverse contexts, both health and disease. These insights are expected to spur the development of new strategies in precision nutrition and precision medicine relevant for mother and child and in multiple disease domains beyond infant well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: There is a critical unmet need for a globally scalable, biomarker-based diagnostic for Tuberculosis (TB) from non-sputum-based samples. Here we will first develop a multiplexed microfluidic antibody profiling chip and use it, coupled with machine-learning approaches, to define an antibody Fe signature-based TB biomarker. Further, we will develop an inexpensive yet accurate nanoscale approach for detection of this biomarker from a single drop of blood at the point-of-care (POC).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative With public health experts warning us of the increasing prevalence of adolescent mental health problems, it is of critical importance to understand the effects of social supports on mitigating the effects of trauma, particularly for minoritized youth, whose experiences are less understood. By following the same cohort of socio- demographically diverse adolescents in the longitudinal Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development study, we will identify the critical junctures by which trauma and social support impact behavioral functioning. Findings will lend guidance on how to make accessible the specific types of culturally relevant social supports that minimize symptoms of externalizing and internalizing behaviors due to adverse childhood experiences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Approximately 200,000 new cases of ovarian cancer occur per year worldwide, but the overall survival of ovarian cancer has not significantly changed for decades. Nearly 20% of our genome is composed of LINE-1 transposable elements that are tightly silenced in normal tissues but gain expression in cancers, especially ovarian cancer. This project will determine how LINE-1 contributes to ovarian cancer immune evasion, potentially identifying vulnerabilities to novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While effective colorectal cancer (CRC) screening interventions have been tested that use state-of-the art technology and behavior change theory, their implementation into routine primary care settings, and how this works best in different contexts, remains to be tested. This parallel cluster randomized study will test at scale an intervention we have piloted successfully: NPT-PLA, an intervention uses an implementation science framework (normalization process theory -NPT) to inform a participatory health research approach: Participatory Learning in Action (PLA) (10 clinics) vs `usual quality improvement (control) (10 clinics). The goal will be to learn which approach works best to integrate into routine primary care delivery a proven decision- making tool (“I2”) that helps patients choose “how” and “when” to screen; and to translate this into CRC screening completion — providing vital information regarding the effectiveness and utility of NPT-PLA in the context of cancer screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Measles remains one of the 10 most important causes of infectious disease death due to inadequate population coverage with the live attenuated virus vaccine. The vaccine is safe, effective, and is being modified to produce new vaccines and cancer treatments, but the molecular bases of vaccine attenuation and the biological differences between vaccine and virulent wild type strains of measles virus have never been defined. This project will identify how the attenuated virus differs from wild type measles virus with respect to infection of immune cells, infection of non-human primates, long term effects on the immune system and stimulation of a protective immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Dinuclear monooxygenases play essential roles in microbial metabolism and bioactive natural product formation. While many of these enzymes are thought to utilize di-iron cofactors to activate the strong carbon-hydrogen bonds of the cognate substrate, our group has recently characterized an enzyme that strictly requires formation of a mixed manganese/iron cofactor. To expand the context of this discovery and broadly understand uncharacterized monooxygenases present throughout biology, our investigation seeks to discover, characterize and understand an emergent family of manganese-dependent monooxygenases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myxomatous mitral valve prolapse, a potentially life-threatening heart valve condition, specifically affects the valve located between the left atrium and ventricle. Despite some reports on the intricate cellular environments involved, there is a notable scarcity of detailed high-resolution omics data. The objective of this project is to bridge this knowledge gap by utilizing state-of-the-art single-cell and spatial techniques to construct a comprehensive molecular atlas of the tissue affected by mitral valve prolapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Babies who are born extremely prematurely suffer from bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD), a disease that is characterized by respiratory difficulties due to underdeveloped lungs and airways, and is responsible for $13 billion per year in healthcare costs. BPD has several different characteristics (overly dense lungs, overinflated lungs, collapse in various parts of the airway, etc.), and each characteristic may require different treatment, but understanding which characteristics are causing the respiratory difficulties in a specific patient is challenging. This study will calculate the effort that patients with BPD use to breathe (known as the work of breathing) and will determine the contribution of each characteristic of BPD to the work of breathing, revealing which character- istic(s) are the most beneficial to treat in each individual infant with BPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The project aims to develop novel software tools for the quality assessment of the tens of thousands of organelle genomes archived on the nucleotide sequence database GenBank. The tools will enable scientists from various areas of biomedical research to make informed, evidence-based decisions on the reuse of complete organelle genomes and to compile only secure, curated genome sets. The project advances the goal of making high-quality genomic data assets identifiable to the biomedical research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute pancreatitis is a prevalent gastrointestinal disorder that imposes a substantial burden on healthcare systems due to its high hospitalization rates and associated costs, with limited effective therapies currently available, there is an urgent need for research aimed at developing successful treatments. This research proposal aims to dissect the roles of trypsin and coagulation in acute pancreatitis and test the hypothesis that thrombin plays a crucial role in the development of the disease, particularly by influencing the microenvironment through its PAR receptors. By utilizing various models, inhibitors, and imaging technology, this project aims to advance our understanding of the pathophysiology of acute pancreatitis and contribute to the development of targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Chronic infections and cancer result in dysfunction of immune cells, termed “exhaustion”. With this proposal, we will investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms that cause exhaustion and the use of a small non-coding RNA (microRNA-29a; miR-29a) to overcome exhaustion. We will explore the potential of delivering miR-29a to T cells as a novel strategy to improve responses to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Among patients with hematologic malignancy, reported beta-lactam (BL) allergy is associated with excessive antibiotic use and negative clinical outcomes, likely because patients with a BL allergy label more often receive antibiotic therapy that is less effective, overly broad, and/or more toxic. For the great majority of people, reported BL allergies are mischaracterized or have been outgrown. This study will test a novel intervention to assess and, if appropriate, delabel BL allergy in patients hospitalized with hematologic malignancy and determine the effect of this intervention on subsequent antibiotic use and clinical outcomes.

PROJECT_TITLE: Optimizing antibiotic selection in hematologic malignancy patients with reported beta-lactam allergy

PHR: The overarching goal of these studies is to develop and implement tools and technologies to ensure rigor and reproducibility of translational nonhuman primate models for precision genetic and regenerative medicine therapeutics. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Older Veterans with serious mental illness (SMI; schizophrenia-spectrum and bipolar disorders) have reduced physical function (i.e., strength, mobility, endurance) that leads to more falls, hospitalizations, and nursing home admissions. Exercise improves physical function in older Veterans; however, environmental difficulties (e.g., lack of transportation), low motivation from mental health symptoms, and comorbid medical issues make participation in facility-based exercise programs challenging for older Veterans with SMI. This CDA-2 will develop, refine, and feasibility test a home-based exercise program for older Veterans with SMI that targets the established barriers impacting exercise engagement in this population. This study will result in the first exercise program designed specifically to improve strength, mobility, and endurance in older Veterans with SMI. This work has the potential to improve the physical and mental health, quality of life, and independence of a population at tremendous risk for functional decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The IgE antibody provides the antigen specificity for the type 2 immune effector cells it arms, mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils, plays a causal role in allergy, and remains understudied for its fundamental function in defending us against parasites. It has recently been determined that type 2 immunity plays a critical role in an immune phenomenon known as acquired tick resistance, where tick feeding is disrupted by the host immune response, reducing transmission of tick- borne pathogens. Studying tick specific IgE monoclonal antibodies, derived from people who have repeated tick bites and/or alpha-gal syndrome, will allow for the most basic and critical immunologic interactions to be assessed between the human IgE antibody response and tick antigens and will provide new insights into the often pathological but potentially protective aspect of the human adaptive immune system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. The MYC family of transcription factors (TF) are notorious drivers of many cancers but have been resistant to traditional drug discovery strategies. To address this challenge, we have developed a new type of molecule, synthetic transcriptional repressors (STRs)m that specifically bind to the same DNA sequences as MYC proteins, thereby inhibiting MYC function in cancer cells. Here, we will develop next-generation STRs with improved biochemical and pharmacological properties and test their ability to block MYC-dependent gene expression and cell growth in cellular and animal models of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysphagia, or difficulty swallowing, is a common symptom of many neurological diseases but its treatment is not well established or easily accessible. We will systematically examine the comparative efficacy of using a new portable electromyography biofeedback device we have developed as adjunct to a standardized swallow therapy protocol – delivered in-person and via telehealth – in improving health outcomes in patients with stroke or Parkinson’s disease, and determine what patient factors may influence response to treatment; thus, the proposed research is relevant to public health and in line with NIH’s mission to improve the evidence base and accessibility of efficacious rehabilitation strategies for this debilitating health condition.
