IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Normothermic Regional Perfusion (NRP) is a novel organ preservation method with the potential to vastly increase the number of high quality hearts and other organs available for over 100,000 people with end-stage organ failure in the United States waitlisted for transplant. But NRP is the subject of great ethical controversy because it requires restarting circulation inside the donor’s body, which might challenge the determination of the donor’s death. This project aims to assess the potential impact of NRP on public trust in the U.S. organ transplantation system to inform how organ procurement organizations talk to families about NRP, and inform whether transplant programs participate in NRP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research aims to enhance our understanding of the metabolic benefits of glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (GLP-1Ra) in stage 2 type 1 diabetes patients treated with teplizumab. By investigating the insulinotropic and glucagonostatic effects of GLP-1Ra, the study seeks to improve treatment outcomes, slow disease progression, and enhance the quality of life for individuals with type 1 diabetes. The insights gained will have broad implications for the management of diabetes, a major public health concern, contributing to strategies that can extend healthy life and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Development of non-sputum, biomarker-based tests to diagnose tuberculosis (TB) disease, assess disease severity, and monitor responses to treatment would allow clinicians in low-resource, primary care settings to more easily detect TB cases and employ a precision medicine approach to TB treatment. Key knowledge gaps standing in the way of developing rapid, point-of-care tests for TB disease diagnosis and management include a lack of blood-based biomarkers of TB disease and treatment response. This research project will discover immunometabolic plasma biomarker signatures able to identify TB disease and predict TB clearance with potential for translation to point-of-care tests to improve TB diagnosis and treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative By kindergarten entry, children from low-socioeconomic status (SES) backgrounds lag behind their peers from higher SES homes in early literacy and other school readiness skills and these gaps persist through high school. The goal of this study is to determine whether an intervention to support caregivers in engaging with their children while co-using educational media can improve children's early literacy skills, compared to an aligned shared book reading intervention and to no intervention. Given that early literacy skills predict children's later academic learning, this home intervention, which aims to shape the communication patterns surrounding a common, family-friendly activity, has the potential to positively influence the trajectory of low- income children's academic success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Midbrain dopamine neurons densely innervate the striatum, and this projection is thought to be critical for reinforcement learning as well as motor control. This proposal will combine behavioral, computational, circuit perturbation techniques and optical neuromodulatory sensors to test the novel hypothesis that the neuromodulator acetylcholine dynamically gates whether dopamine drives learning or moving. All neuropsychiatric disorders, including schizophrenia and bipolar disorder are thought to reflect dysfunction of the dopamine system, and are characterized by aberrant reward processing and disordered decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Light acts through the retina to regulate the circadian clock. Circadian dysregulation is implicated in cancer, cardiovascular disease, metabolic disorder, and mental illness. We propose to define the normal function of retinal neurons and their signaling to the principal circadian clock, which is located in the brain, to gain insight into the basis of circadian regulation and dysregulation.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a leading cause for cirrhosis and liver transplantation in women, and there is an urgent need to identify nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), its progressive form, before complications have developed. Pregnancyis an opportunity to diagnose,risk-stratify, and intervene before disease progression.This project will prospectively evaluate the association of NAFLD diagnosed in pregnancy with adverse pregnancy outcomes, identify individuals with “at-risk” NASH in the post-pregnancy period, and investigate the NAFLD associated lipid-mediated mechanisms that predict these outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative Older adults have poorer vestibular, or balance, function and the reasons for this are not well understood. This research will examine the natural disease state of age-related changes in the human vestibular system, with an emphases on a novel, sustained stimulation approach to study nonlinear aspects of vestibular reflexes. Information learned from this research will help to better understand basic aspects of human vestibular function as well as underlying causes of balance difficulties in older adults and may help to develop new clinical tools for the diagnosis and monitoring of vestibular disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Children who grow up in low-income homes are at higher risk for poor health and early mortality for their entire lives. It is difficult to study the effects of childhood social conditions on adult health, however, because sometimes these negative impacts are not evident for years or even decades. In this project, we test whether DNA-methylation (a type of epigenetic modification of the human genome) can help researchers see how children’s health is being negatively affected by adverse social conditions, using a unique research design that analyzes epigenetic data previously collected from four cohorts that span early childhood to older adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: In this application we propose to define how a molecular motif, responsible for B cell activation, possesses an intrinsic regulatory function that can prevent or modulate B cell activation. The overarching goal of these studies is to better understand how the earliest events in lymphocyte activation impact the balance of activating and inhibitory signaling, which shape B cell responses and immune tolerance. Gained knowledge has direct translational implications for the design of chimeric antigen receptor for immunotherapies that exploit this molecular motif.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Supporting deimplementation of low-value, preference-sensitive breast cancer surgical care is a public health priority because these operations have limited clinical benefit while having a substantial negative impact on psychosocial, physical and financial outcomes. A critical gap towards supporting deimplementation of low-value preference-sensitive care is our understanding of what happens within patient-surgeon interactions. This project aims to address this gap by analyzing existing audio-recorded breast cancer surgical consultations to understand the relationship between what surgeons and patients say during the consult, and how decisions are made for two low-value, preference-sensitive operations (sentinel lymph node biopsy for women ≥70 years of age and contralateral prophylactic mastectomy).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is a deadly and incurable brain tumor, characterized by high inter-patient heterogeneity and intra-tumoral plasticity, which pose significant challenges in developing effective therapies. Here, we aim to uncover and target central regulatory nodes that govern the GBM programs by focusing on essential non-coding DNA elements, known as enhancers. By building networks of enhancer-gene communication in the context of three-dimesional nucleus, we aim to (i) identify common central nodes across patients and cellular states, (ii) dissect their significance in GBM programs and tumorigenic properties and (iii) expose unique vulnerabilities for future targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will elucidate COVID-19 vaccine responses in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and systemic sclerosis (SSc). Our highly multidisciplinary team will use state-of-the-art technologies and systems biology to analyze longitudinally-collected samples from patients in Stanford’s lupus and scleroderma clinics. Our work could lead to better understanding of vaccine efficacy and vaccine adverse events, and to elucidating molecular underpinnings of autoimmune diseases (AID) more broadly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary muscle tension dysphonia (pMTD) is a functional voice disorder that negatively affects communication, occupation, and quality of life. Although excessive paralaryngeal muscle activity and altered phonatory breathing patterns are thought to underlie symptoms of vocal effort, fatigue, and discomfort in pMTD, there is conflicting evidence for the role of paralaryngeal-respiratory movement patterns in these clinical presentations due to lack of robust methodological tools to study these relationships. We use novel application of motion capture technology to study these movement patterns in patients with and without pMTD and their relationship to pMTD symptomology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Stroke has one of the most striking health disparities in the United States with African Americans at substantially greater risk of having a stroke, having a recurrent stroke, and dying from a stroke. Epigenetics can provide a lens through which to view how the environment, including social and structural determinants of health, and an individual’s unique genetic code interact to influence disease risk and outcomes. The goal of this proposal is to generate epigenetic data and leverage existing genomic and phenotypic data from the REasons for Geographic and Racial Differences in Stroke (REGARDS) study to identify unique and shared determinants of stroke risk and recurrence stroke risk to allow improved personalization of risk assessment and targeted prevention of recurrent strokes, while reducing the stroke disparities using a multiethnic population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will implement and characterize genetic crosses to identify key molecular determinants associated with artemisinin resistance and reduced lumefantrine susceptibility in African Plasmodium falciparum malaria parasites and characterize the impact of these mutations on parasite fitness and transmission. The results will provide robust molecular markers that can be used for molecular surveillance of parasites resistant to this first- line drug in Africa, where the disease burden is by far the greatest in the world. Our findings will help guide strategies to protect artemisinin-based combination therapies, impede the spread and establishment of multidrug resistance, and inform strategies to design more effective antimalarial drug treatments aimed at reducing malaria’s massive impact on global health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project narrative Preeclampsia is a hypertensive pregnancy disorder that increases risk of morbidity and mortality to both mother and baby. The disease symptoms resolve following delivery of placenta, which is the current only definitive treatment, but it can lead to medically necessitated preterm deliveries. Understanding the detailed mechanisms of preeclampsia will allow us to establish better disease interventions, treatments, and preventions, which will improve both mom and the baby’s overall long-term health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unlike normal cells, majority of cancer cells and nearly all of small cell lung cancers activate an enzyme called telomerase to replicate end of the chromosomes to bypass replicative senescence. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have created a novel platform to test drug sensitivity of human cancers using fresh core needle biopsies. It takes into consideration of the tumor microenvironment and provides early readouts of response. Before taking this assay into the clinic, we aim to define the optimal pre- analytical conditions that will allow for reproducible and reliable test performance, including the impact of the type and size of the biopsy needles, tissue handling and storage, culture conditions and dissociation protocols. We will further test our standard operating procedure (SOP) in a pilot study of liver cancers to demonstrate clinical feasibility in preparation for a clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Periodontitis is one of the most common diseases in humans and is caused by increased bacterial accumulation that leads to severe inflammation. This study aims to characterize the systems Treponema denticola, a key periodontal pathogen, uses to sense and respond to environmental stimuli. Understanding the mechanisms that promote T. denticola adaptation and survival is critical to developing novel therapeutics or approaches to prevent periodontitis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Concerns about deteriorating mental health, substance use disorders, early development of chronic conditions, exposure to economic shocks, and to violence---causes that may all lead to premature mortality among adolescents and young adults in the United States, have been rising in recent public discourse. The magnitude and root causes for these developments are poorly understood. In this project we will construct new large-scale datasets on mortality and socio- economic circumstances of adolescents and young adults in the United States, measure how mortality evolved over time and space, and analyze the contribution of social determinants to observed mortality patterns.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project will involve a rigorous randomized control trial to examine the effects of integrating evidence-based practices for attention and reading within a single, unified intervention called Supporting Attention and Reading for Kids (SPARK) for students with co-occurring reading and attention difficulties in Grades 3 - 5. Despite decades of research on reading disabilities, the efficacy of existing interventions for improving reading in upper elementary students (Grades 3 – 5) remains limited and is relatively understudied relative to studies with children in the early elementary grades. The results of this study will have immediate and extensive impact on research and clinical practice (e.g., enhancing the approaches to remediating reading difficulties) for an understudied population, students with co-occurring reading and attention difficulties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE In order to improve the success rate of clinical trials by reducing the dependence on animal testing, we are developing miniature models of human organs on a chip. By using custom robots to place cells in specific starting positions, we have been able to guide them to create a tube-shaped miniature heart that might be more accurate than other sphere shaped miniature hearts. We aim to thoroughly test this new human heart model, and combine it with a similarly generated liver model in order to study interactions between the heart and liver in normal and diseased scenarios.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In the proposed experiments, we will use a novel UCS deflation approach to weaken fear behavior; here, presentations of a weaker version of an unconditional stimulus can produce persistent reductions in fear responding. We will combine behavioral, circuit, cellular, and molecular approaches to gain a detailed understanding of the mechanisms through which weak shock exposure functions to reduce fear behavior and circumvent behavioral responding common to extinction learning. The results from these studies will be immediately applicable to human behavioral treatments aiming to address fear and anxiety behavior long-term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative: Public Health Relevance Four in every five women will have uterine fibroids in their lifetime, over 1.6 million will be diagnosed each year, and over half a million of those will undergo surgery for fibroids. Two-thirds of these women will have invasive surgery to remove their uterus, even though the best surgeons have shown that just over 50,000 of them per year could have minimally invasive uterine-sparing endoscopic interventions if they were fortunate enough to be treated by an elite surgeon. We propose to create a new robot that makes endoscopic fibroid removal easier to perform, so that many more surgeons can offer it to many more women every year.

PHR: Project Narrative This research project aims to utilize quantitative susceptibility mapping (QSM) to establish a clinically feasible, accurate, and robust treatment biomarker for chronic inflammation in multiple sclerosis (MS). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The administration in vivo of fusion proteins composed of an anti-immunoglobulin light chain nanobody, VHHkappa, and a nanobody that recognizes virus-infected cells or tumor cells results in the recruitment to the targeted cell of polyclonal immunoglobulins of all isotypes and of indeterminate specificity. In vivo administration of such fusions eliminates these targeted cells, including tumors. We will define in detail the underlying mechanisms of action and include cytotoxic drugs to further improve the efficacy of such fusions.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Relevance: We hypothesize that changes in the biochemical/metabolic state of the heart in heart failure impair the mechanical pumping ability of the heart. Testing and refining of this hypothesis will lead to a deeper understanding of why and how the function of the heart changes in heart failure and will point to new potential avenues for treatment. Our proposal investigates this hypothesized mechanical-energetic link by using multi-scale computer models to analyze data from human subjects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the key features of asthma is exaggerated airway narrowing by hypercontractile airway smooth muscle. Our group has shown that smooth muscle cells narrow the airway by transmitting force through tethering proteins. The goals of this project are to determine the pathways by which pro-inflammatory signals activate these tethering proteins and to study a specific tethering protein that binds smooth muscle cells to one another, with the hope of identifying new therapeutic targets for the treatment of chronic airways disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A distressingly high number of children in the United States, approximately 2-5%, live with fetal alcohol spectrum disorders, the result of damage to the developing fetus from prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE). Because there are currently no known treatments that can reverse PAE-mediated damage, it is essential that we understand its molecular underpinnings and investigate novel avenues of research such as those defining the role of vascular defects in the developing brain during PAE. This study will uncover novel molecular mechanisms that drive abnormal vascular development in the brain during PAE and reveal potential therapeutic targets for FASD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is consistent with public health goals to reduce patient symptom interference with functioning and family caregiver burden in advanced cancer. Acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) is a novel approach to addressing these public health issues that showed promise in our pilot study with patient- caregiver dyads coping with advanced gastrointestinal cancer. This phase II randomized trial will examine the effect of telephone-delivered ACT on patient fatigue interference and caregiver burden in this population and, following positive trial findings, ACT may be readily integrated into comprehensive clinical care.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Preeclampsia is a serious pregnancy complication with limited diagnostic and treatment options. Our project aims to investigate the role of the vaginal ecosystem - its microbes, metabolites, and the host’s immune system - in preeclampsia, using samples from a large and deeply phenotyped cohort of pregnant women - the nuMoM2b study. Our study will identify new biomarkers for preeclampsia and highlight potential mechanisms underlying it, ultimately paving the way for new diagnostics and therapeutic targets that will improve maternal and neonatal health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Health Relevance Narrative: Loss of mitochondrial function can be debilitating in the nervous system, as evident from its association with numerous neurological diseases and disorders – including forms of Parkinson’s Disease, Leigh Syndrome, or other movement disorders. In order to develop more effective treatments for mitopathies of the nervous system, we need better understanding of the cellular and synaptic consequences of mitochondrial dysfunction. This proposal addresses that problem, using a genetic model of Mitochondrial Complex I dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to explore the mechanisms underlying poly(ADP-ribose)-signaling in IDH mutant gliomas to develop modalities that selectively target these tumors. Our application is relevant to public health because IDH mutant gliomas are common in younger adults, and universally evade the current aggressive therapies and remain lethal, necessitating the identification of novel therapeutic approaches. Relevant to the NCI mission, the objective of this study is to understand sensitivities to specific signaling pathway perturbation, to inform strategies that can improve the efficacy of novel targeted and existing therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Otitis media is the second most common reason children go to the doctor. This project will provide evidence of long-lasting functional listening deficits in children resulting from otitis media after the pathology has resolved. This will have a significant theoretical and translational impact on the early identification and intervention of pediatric hearing loss resulting from otitis media.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 1.3 million new patients are diagnosed each year with conditions that may result in elevated intra- cranial pressure (ICP). In these patients, the limited ability to make accurate, stable pressure measurements with wireless, MRI compatible devices contributes to poor clinical outcomes. It is hypothesized that a novel ul- trasound-based wireless transduction approach combined with an implanted pressure sensitive target has the potential to accurately diagnose shunt failure, improving patient management while reducing cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Small-Molecule Penetration and Efflux in Gram-Negative Bacteria Infections by Gram-negative bacteria pose a growing threat to public health in the U.S. and globally, due to the intrinsic resistance of these pathogens to many antibiotics. A major obstacle to the development of new antibiotics to combat these infections is our poor understanding of the structural requirements for small- molecule drugs to penetrate the Gram-negative cell envelope barrier and to avoid expulsion by efflux pumps. This multidisciplinary project will address this problem by using a comprehensive experimental and computational platform to analyze, model, and predict small-molecule penetration and efflux in three Gram- negative pathogens, thus enabling the development of new Gram-negative antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Highly effective modulator therapy (HEMT) has recently become available for the majority of people with cystic fibrosis (CF). The effects on lung function can be quite dramatic but the effects on the pancreas are minimal, probably due to the fact that the pancreas undergoes fibrosis which is complete by the teen years. In this study, we aim to uncover novel insights into the biological mechanisms driving the natural history of disease progression in CF by revealing how the newest HEMT, Trikafta™, improves pulmonary and pancreatic function in young children, an age with great potential for growth and repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Agroforestry is an age-old agricultural practice that intertwines crops, livestock and forest, serving as an important strategy for climate change mitigation that is being implemented globally. In this study, our aim is to examine how agroforestry, compared to other farming practices, influences the risk of zoonotic mosquito-borne viral infections in humans and livestock in Darien, Panama. Our ultimate goal is to generate insights that will guide public health and agricultural policies, thereby ensuring alignment of climate and health objectives within the context of agroforestry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Aging is the primary risk factor for cardiovascular disease, this in large part due to aging of the arteries. Emerging evidence suggests that CD8+ T cells accumulate around the arteries with age and drive tissue inflammation and dysfunction in these tissues. The results from this proposal will determine how CD8+ T cell aging results in inflammation and dysfunction of the arteries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will seek to develop a novel microfluidic “tumor-on-a-chip” platform for studying peritoneal carcinomatosis – a diffuse spreading pattern of metastasis of the peritoneal cavity and the most lethal form of metastasis of colon and gastric cancer. Colon and gastric cancer are the third and fifth most prevalent cancers worldwide, respectively, and most people who die from the disease do so because of metastases, such as those to the peritoneal cavity. This platform will provide a new tool to help researchers understand this process, and ultimately identify drugs that will effectively treat and prevent this process from happening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hookworm infection is a leading cause of anemia and malnutrition in poor countries, especially sub-Saharan Africa. We will produce the first reference genome for an African strain of Necator americanus hookworms and develop genomic tools to monitor deworming drugs' effect on Ghana's parasite populations. The studies proposed here will add significantly to our understanding of hookworm genomics and provide a bioinformatic foundation for the future development of improved diagnostics, drugs, and vaccines for human infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will identify structural aspects of the health care system that reduce or increase disparities in mental health care by race, ethnicity and disability status. To do so, we will develop a database of provider opening, closing, consolidation, and ownership changes related to mental health care and provide a summary of variations in the provider landscape for mental health care for disadvantaged groups. Our causal analyses will reveal targets for policy interventions to improve the mental health of disadvantaged populations and reduce the disparate impacts of public policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Use of amphetamine and its congeners is currently higher than ever before, surpassing that of all other illicit substances. Substance use disorder, particularly to psychostimulants like amphetamine, is a serious problem in today’s society, compounded by lack of effective therapeutics to treat psychostimulant addiction. This proposal examines the potential of targeting a molecular mechanism, phosphorylation/regulation of the norepinephrine transporter, to reduce the rewarding effects of amphetamine and drug-seeking behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Latino children generally have lower participation in leisure-time physical activity and unhealthy dietary habits and higher rates of overweight and obesity. Effective intervention programs are needed which target improvements in physical activity (PA) and cardiovascular fitness (CVF) rather than focus on weight loss. This study will test the effects of a 12-month community-based, family-centered behavioral intervention to influence improvements in PA and CVF outcomes among underserved Latino families in the U.S.-Mexico border region, while gathering information on program implementation and sustainability.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Urea cycle disorders are serious, but treatable, inherited diseases caused by DNA sequence variants that impair the function of any of eight different proteins in human liver cells. Although timely diagnosis and treatment is key to improving patient outcomes, the lack of sufficiently reliable biochemical tests for several of these diseases has prevented them from being included in newborn screening panels. This project will develop tools to assess a newborn’s genetic risk of developing a severe urea cycle disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: A significant proportion of patients may experience poor outcomes (either refractory or recurrent disease) within 6 weeks after standard antibiotic treatment for bacterial vaginosis (BV). Finding baseline vaginal micro- environmental factors associated with these early adverse outcomes could produce candidate biomarkers for these conditions, and ultimately change clinical practice by identifying patients who may require more aggressive initial therapies. Here, we propose to recruit a cohort of patients initiating therapy for acute BV and follow them over 6 weeks to identify vaginal microenvironmental factors associated with refractory or early recurrent BV resultant specimen repository may also be leveraged for future studies to reveal underlying mechanisms (and ultimately improved treatments) for these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite advancements in clinical awareness, sepsis continues to be a major global cause of death and incurs significant healthcare expenses. The study aims to address the issue of exaggerated immune responses leading to organ dysfunction and mortality by proposing innovative approaches to prevent inflammatory overreactions. The findings from these studies are expected to offer crucial insights for future clinical trials, holding great potential to enhance survival rates and treatment outcomes for septic patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gram-negative bacterial pathogens, particularly Klebsiella pneumoniae, Acinetobacter baumannii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Escherichia coli, and Enterobacter species are associated with life-threatening systemic infections which pose an enormous burden to the public health system. Their ability to rapidly develop drug resistance and propagate as multidrug-resistant, and now pan-resistant pathogens, begs the need for new agents that are not only highly efficacious and safe but able to overcome resistance to existing antibiotics in high-risk patient populations. In an effort to meet this challenge, we propose to develop a new class of antibiotics, the biamyxins, that we recently created as a highly effective countermeasure against this increasingly serious public health threat.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory viral coinfections (RVCIs) are more common in children, particularly with the emergence of SARS- CoV-2, but differentiating between coinfection and codetection remains unclear, hindering clinical understanding. We aim to investigate patient features, coinfecting viruses, microbial contributions, and host responses to determine their impact on disease severity in SARS-COV-2-infected children. With a multidisciplinary team and metagenomic next-generation sequencing, we aim to identify immunologic fingerprints specific to SARS-CoV-2, enabling targeted treatment approaches and advancing our knowledge regarding the clinical implications of finding multiple viruses on respiratory pathogen testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Asthma is a leading cause of childhood morbidity and disparities nationwide and limited provider adoption of and patient adherence to the prevailing evidence-based recommendations for chronic management represent tractable areas for implementation focus. In their 2020 Focused Updates to the National Asthma Management Guidelines, the NHLBI recommended single maintenance and reliever therapy (SMART) - a paradigm-shifting approach to chronic asthma management that combines an immediate-acting reliever and longer-acting maintenance inhaler medications that are generally taken separately - as the preferred chronic management strategy for persistent moderate to severe asthma based on robust efficacy and real-world effectiveness in international settings. Several important barriers, however, hinder current SMART adoption in the US; the proposed project will test two theoretically grounded and empirically supported implementation strategies to improve SMART adoption in pediatric primary care, while also assessing real-world effectiveness in a large health system whose racial demographics mirror US asthma morbidity statistics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE The Eating Disorders Genetics Initiative 2 (EDGI2) unites existing and exceptionally productive and collaborative sites globally to advance genetic discovery across all eating disorders (anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, binge-eating disorder, and avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder). We will apply both novel and established methods to optimize discovery in our diverse and severely ill sample, culminating in a clinical translation summit. Our goal is to identify biologically, clinically, culturally, and therapeutically meaningful and actionable insights and rapidly transition the field from discovery to clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: The opioid epidemic is one of the most challenging public health crises of our time and sleep apnea patients are among the most vulnerable to suffer fatal opioid overdose. The focus of this proposal is two-fold: (1) identify the failing neurocircuitry that underlies sleep apnea-related hypersensitivity to opioid-induced respiratory depression and (2) address the clinical need for treatments that counter central opioid-induced respiratory depression without interrupting the pain-killing action of opioids and while avoiding central withdrawal effects. This research will advance our understanding of novel targets that can improve the clinical safety of opioids, especially in those most at-risk for their lethal consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black adults with cancer have twice the risk of poor cardiovascular disease (CVD) outcomes compared to White adults with cancer; and we hypothesize that social determinants of health (SDOH) such as structural racism and individual-level socio-economic position are partially responsible for this observed Black-White disparity. The goal of this proposed R01 application is to elucidate the role of SDOH including structural racism on CVD outcomes among a Black and White, community-based cohort of nearly 8,000 male and female adults with cancer. Our proposed work will generate new evidence to inform interventions designed to eliminate Black-White disparities in CVD outcomes during survivorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NATHAN S. KLINE INSTITUTE FOR PSYCH RES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The goal of this collaborative study is to investigate the physiological and pathological roles of mitovesicles, a recently discovered subtype of extracellular vesicles of mitochondrial origin in the brain. We will investigate the mechanisms that modulate mitovesicle production and secretion, their intracellular fate once taken up by recipient cells, and the effects of mitovesicles derived from normal brains and from Alzheimer’s disease- relevant mouse models. Our studies aim to identify novel directions for therapeutic strategies that can restore the integrity of mitochondria, minimizing the effects of this pathology in neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Large protein language models have shown their foundational role in biomedical research, but the current models miss critical knowledge about protein structure and functions and lack efficient approaches to be adapted for challenging biomedical tasks. To address these two challenges, we propose to develop structure-function-aware large protein language models and adaptation methods for accurate predictions of protein properties. The success of this project will provide novel large protein language models and fundamental deep learning tools for various biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative The stability of the fluid within your inner ear is crucial for maintaining hearing and balance. Our research will identify how cells communicate to promote development of the ear's pressure control system and how system- wide signals and local forces work to maintain inner ear function. This knowledge will help identify new ways to diagnose and treat hearing and balance disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE While lifesaving, insulin therapy suffers from several shortcomings including the lack of availability of truly monomeric analogs that have a fast onset and offset of action. We recently discovered that venomous cone snails have evolved a diverse set of monomeric insulin analogs, so-called evologs, that provide entirely new opportunities for addressing current challenges in insulin analog design. In this proposal, we will elucidate the full diversity and structure-function of insulin evologs found in nature and utilize this information to design future drug leads for diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Estrogen signaling plays a critical role in the development of endometrial cancer; however, it may not be sufficient to drive tumor formation as endometrial cancer usually arises in the context of common mutations and excess estrogens. The goal of the project is to determine how ARID1A mutations, which are common in endometrial tumors, cooperate with estrogen signaling and explore novel treatment strategies for the majority of endometrial cancers, which have ARID1A alterations and active estrogen signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the current proposal, we plan to employ an integrated genomics-based approach to investigate common cardiometabolic outcomes including five conditions that increase cardiovascular disease risk (abnormal glucose metabolism, obesity, hypertension, hypertriglyceridemia and hypercholesterolemia), and two outcomes of cardiac damage (cardiomyopathy and myocardial infarction) among survivors of childhood and adolescent cancer. Our research framework will address the roles of genetic factors (specifically, rare pathogenic germline variants in multiple relevant pathways), epigenetic factors (specifically, DNA methylation and altered gene expression), as well as multiple biomarkers of aging in cardiometabolic risk within the context of long-term impact from cancer treatment exposures and enduring effects from health behaviors. The successful completion of this project will provide translational pathways towards novel surveillance and intervention strategies for improvement of survivorship care and also generate new hypotheses for future collaborative basic science research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mycophenolic acid (MPA) is a crucial immunosuppressant that prevents acute rejection in kidney transplant recipients but also causes adverse toxicities that threaten its efficacy. Our current understanding of the relationship between gut bacteria and these adverse toxicities is incomplete. Here, we seek to identify the gut microbial enzymes associated with these adverse toxicities and determine whether these microbial enzymes can be used as a predictor of MPA-associated toxicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Plasminogen is a multi-functional protein that transports lipids and small non-coding RNAs. Plasminogen can transfer small RNAs to macrophages and regulate gene expression and immune cell phenotypes. We aim to gain a fundamental understanding of this novel process, and its relationship to systemic cholesterol metabolism and inflammation, to advance hematology research.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The study is essential for understanding the influence of social determinants of health (SDH) on post-acute care (PAC) rehabilitation access and variation in quality-of-care outcomes across the nation. This project will evaluate SDH variables and their association with PAC access across PAC settings, across rural and urban rehabilitation service areas, and how these associations are moderated by racial and ethnic population density and the COVID pandemic as well as how these factors impact readmission and successful community discharge outcomes. The study informs clinicians, researchers, communities, policy debates, and can lead to better PAC outcomes, and allow us to better understand SDH factors that affect quality-of-care.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because preimplantation uterine fluid regulation is crucial for several early pregnancy events and its dysregulation can lead to two important public health problems: infertil- ity and early pregnancy loss. This proposal aims to investigate mechanisms for the temporal uterine fluid ab- sorption during early pregnancy in mouse models and human endometrium under physiological and pathologi- cal conditions. Understanding mechanisms in regulating uterine fluid absorption during early pregnancy will fill in a knowledge gap and provide novel information for future development of approaches to manage uterine fluid to facilitate successful early pregnancy.

PHR: Narrative. Alpha 1-antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency is a hereditary disorder associated with the early onset of emphysema. AAT normally protects the lung from inflammatory enzymes capable of destroying the lung parenchyma. We propose to treat AAT deficiency with a single administration of AAV8hAAT(AVL), a gene therapy that codes for a modified form of AAT that is resistant to oxidant inactivation, which if safe and efficacious, and will protect the lung on a persistent basis.

PHR: Project Narrative Hundreds of mutations to the LMNA gene, which encodes the Lamin A/C proteins, have been linked to more than 10 distinct syndromes, collectively referred to as “laminopathies”. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intimate partner violence is experienced by one-fourth of women globally and linked to poor mental, physical, sexual, and reproductive health, thus underscoring the need for innovative, effective strategies to prevent intimate partner violence. The proposed study examines the impact of a couples-based intervention, “Ghya Bharaari Ekatra,” in preventing intimate partner violence and enhancing reproductive autonomy and mental health among newly married couples in India. The study will provide critical insight on the efficacy of the intervention, its mechanism of effect, contexts that may modify its effects, and the barriers, facilitators, and strategies for its successful future adoption and implementation, thereby enabling rapid scale-up of the intervention across India and similar resource-limited, high-burden settings globally upon study completion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) are at increased risk of muscle loss and decreased physical activity. This proposal will aim to (1) understand the underlying pathologic mechanisms that contribute to muscle loss in PAH, particularly focusing on the role of the fat surrounding the heart, and (2) assess the impact muscle loss has on quality of life, daily physical activity, and hospitalizations in patients with PAH. Finally, in a small pilot study, we will also explore how a low resistance exercise intervention may improve muscle mass for PAH patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alphaviruses are viruses that are spread by mosquitoes and can cause outbreaks of severe brain infections with no approved drugs or vaccines available to combat them. Recently, we identified three proteins that are expressed on brain cells as specific host cell receptors for alphaviruses that cause encephalitis in both horses and humans. Our research aims to visualize how alphaviruses attach to these receptors and to test the importance of receptor interactions to the ability of the viruses to cause brain infections with implications for therapeutic targeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE While new brain stimulation therapies are now available for temporal lobe epilepsy patients who do not respond to drug therapy, the antiepileptic effects are very variable between patients. There is then a clear need to better understand the propagation and control network to develop more efficient individualized therapies. We are proposing to investigate the implication of the basal ganglia in the propagation and control of temporal lobe seizures and how the seizure onset pattern affects this propagation network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dry eye disease (DED) is a major health problem, however current treatments have variable and limited efficacy. Extracellular Ca2+-sensing receptor (CaSR) is a modulator of ocular surface fluid transport and promising drug target for DED treatment. This proposal aims to develop CaSR inhibitors as novel treatment candidates for DED, and to study the roles and mechanisms of CaSR in ocular surface health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is the most prevalent cause of dementia and the most common age-related neurodegenerative disorder. We showed in the mouse model of AD that transplantation of bone marrow hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) that give rise to blood cells, holds great promise to treat AD, by differentiation of the transplanted HSCs into microglia (type of immune cells in the brain). This approach fully rescued AD complications including neurocognition decline and neuroinflammation, but the mechanism of rescue is still unknown, and the objective of this application is to understand the mechanism of the beneficial impact of wildtype HSCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Drugs that inhibit mutant forms of the metabolic enzyme isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) enzymes were recently approved as therapies for some leukemias and solid tumors. However, inhibiting mutant IDH enzymes helps less than half of patients with IDH-mutant cancers, and drug resistance invariably develops. The proposed research investigates the surprising discovery that hyperactivation, rather than inhibition, of mutant IDH enzymes might offer a more effective strategy to treat IDH-mutant cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative In our previous NIDDK-funded CISTEM study, we integrated 3 different types of national databases to determine the impact of kidney transplant immunosuppressive regimens selection on the development of 10 separate efficacy or morbidity outcomes. We now seek to extend our results in CISTEM2 to dynamically optimize long term kidney transplant function through optimal immunosuppression management by integrating multiple transplant center electronic medical records datasets and deploying machine learning algorithms. With input from patient focus groups, we will refine our existing CISTEM web-based decision support tool input to assist transplant recipients and their care teams make more informed and personalized choices to minimize morbidity and extend kidney graft survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although numerous large studies have been done to demonstrate that structural variants (SVs) are important for brain tumor diagnosis and management, the full spectrum of SVs within pediatric brain tumors is not fully characterized and a clinical test that can rapidly and accurately identify all clinically relevant SVs is absent. In this study, we will work with Augusta University and Bionano Laboratories to validate and develop optical genome mapping, a method that uses ultra-high molecular weight DNA to identify SVs, as a clinical test for pediatric brain tumors and concurrently discover novel SVs in a large cohort of 1000 brain tumor samples. The outcomes of this study will provide a pathway for discovery of novel SVs, as well as allow for improved diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic management of brain tumors in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project seeks to improve both graft preservation and transplant outcomes, to expand the feasibility of transplantation as a treatment for intestinal failure patients. The team will advance donor organ preservation strategies that limit ischemia reperfusion injury and enhance our understanding of the complex interactions between graft immune factors and epithelial barrier integrity. This research will also apply novel technologic platforms to evaluate intestinal viability and barrier function in real-time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Histopathologic examination of annual bone marrow (BM) biopsies, the current standard for myelofibrosis (MF) treatment response assessment, requires three years to identify the post-treatment non-responders reliably. Our goal is to reduce this assessment timeframe to six months in order to improve health outcomes by allowing MF patients to pursue alternative therapies earlier than is currently possible. We propose an integrated histology approach that leverages quantitative molecular imaging to identify biomarkers correlated with the patient’s treatment responsiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Trauma, infection, and cancer treatments can cause taste buds to degenerate, leading to taste deficits that negatively affect nutrition and quality of life. Taste buds have the potential to regenerate, but we need a better understanding of mechanisms that direct this process in adults. The proposed studies will test injury-induced activation of interleukin (IL-1) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α signaling in specific cell types to promote taste bud regeneration and the recovery of taste function.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deep vein thrombosis and vaso-occlusive crisis (VOC) are taking a staggering toll on sickle cell disease (SCD) patients. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Serious ocular infections such as infectious keratitis, uveitis and endophthalmitis are leading causes of blindness globally. Early identification of the causative agent, and prompt initiation of effective therapy, are fundamental to improve outcomes and save vision. This proposal aims to develop a novel and innovative molecular diagnostic approach that can detect approximately 95% of the etiologies of these infections using only one test and with high accuracy, and reduces the time to generate actionable clinical results from days to only 12 hours.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Meibomian gland dysfunction is considered the leading cause of dry eye disease, a multifactorial debilitating disease of the ocular surface with a global prevalence ranging from 5 to 50%. This study will elucidate the role of components of the Hedgehog pathway in Meibomian gland development and renewal. It will also define the therapeutic advantage in targeting the Hedgehog signaling cascade using hydrogel-mediated drug delivery systems to counteracting Meibomian gland dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cardiac sarcomere structure is critical for cardiac function and it has been studied extensively with respect to its molecular composition and function during contraction. In contrast, the mechanisms underlying de novo sarcomere assembly early during development, at the stage when many congenital heart defects arise, remain poorly understood. Here we have used an unbiased mass spectrometry approach to determine the alpha-actinin interactome at different stages of cardiac development, from which we will interrogate the molecular mechanisms involved in the z-body to z-disc transition using genetic mouse models and pluripotent stem cell differentiations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE One of the major manifestations of the obesity epidemic sweeping the world is the increasing prevalence of non- alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). This is associated with a loss of the normal hormonal regulation of metabolism and accumulation of fat, and one underlying cause of this is disruption of intracellular signaling pathways that involve dynamic changes of cytosolic calcium. The purpose of this study is to elucidate the early changes in calcium signaling in response to high fat diet, which may precipitate the maladaptations in the hormonal regulation of hepatic metabolism that result in liver disease, diabetes and related comorbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Environmental carcinogens that damage DNA promote cancer and so our cells have multiple DNA repair pathways. Importantly, each repair pathway does not operate independently, and so we propose to study how interactions among different DNA repair activities shape the biological consequences of exposure to DNA damage in animal models. The results of this work will give rise to a deeper understanding of how cells react to DNA damage caused by an environmental carcinogen, and this will pave the way toward better ways to predict and prevent cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) is a debilitating disorder that includes chronic seizures and severe cognitive deficits that greatly impair quality of life. There is substantial evidence that the synchronization of brain activity is disrupted in epilepsy but it remains unclear how these changes directly impact seizures and cognitive deficits. This proposal uses a novel system to control the timing of interneurons in epileptic and control mice and will determine how the timing of interneuron firing mediates seizures and cognitive deficits in epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a genetic disease caused by the failure of cilia to beat, leading to recurrent infections and chronic lung disease, for which there is no treatment. Our proposed project will investigate the role of a novel cilia candidate protein that may provide protective function for motile cilia. We will determine the function of candidate proteins and how cells handle external and internal stress to identify shared pathways that could be therapeutically manipulated to treat PCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black/African Americans have a higher risk of developing and dying from lung cancer than non-Hispanic Whites. African Americans also have considerable exposure to major stressors resulting from structural racism, including air pollution and residential segregation. Determining how these stressors affect the development and progression of lung cancer will help identify the mechanisms underlying lung cancer disparities and develop approaches to reduce the high burden of disease in this population with the highest NSCLC risk and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), a form of severe lung injury, have a high risk of death (20%) and there are no known beneficial medications to lower this risk. We will test whether measuring dead space, a marker of abnormal lung function, may improve our ability to identify which children are at highest risk of dying from ARDS and the children that may benefit from a medication to improve lung function (inhaled Nitric Oxide). The results of this research could have a major impact on designing clinical trials to identify therapies that may decrease the risk of mortality in ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative Tinnitus, phantom sound perception, is a common problem that leads to neural changes within primary auditory cortex. Utilizing an innovative fNIRs probe that we adapted to the ear canal from a previous R21 grant, we are now capable of localizing brain changes (possible tinnitus corelates; hemodynamic responses and resting state functional connectivity) in human tinnitus that is both subjective and somatic (modulated by head and neck maneuvers). Our current proposal will fill a vital need in the field, as we will be able to closely measure both types of tinnitus in humans as well as corelate those changes with severity levels in those who can and cannot modulate perception with head and neck movements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For many with substance use disorder, motivation for drug is not appropriately blunted by frustration, meaning that recoupling frustration with decreased motivation is a novel therapeutic strategy. We have developed a method of quantifying frustration-related behavior in rats during operant responding which now allows us to study frustration effects on motivation in real time. This project will determine adolescent factors contributing to individual differences in frustration behavior and identify how frustration-related neurocircuitry couples to decreased cocaine motivation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative: Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) matching between a donor and recipient increases kidney graft survival, yet prioritizing antigen-level HLA matching in the kidney allocation system has resulted in racial disparities, with Black recipients getting fewer well-matched organs. Emerging molecular-level mismatch technologies will give us greater precision in identifying which transplants are truly well-matched. We will use computational tools to design an improved allocation system that prioritizes molecular-level instead of antigen-level matching to improve graft longevity, while adjusting allocation scores using a novel personalized metric of the likelihood of finding a well-matched donor, the personalized immunologic compatibility likelihood (PICL) to achieve equity.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Narrative We discovered and characterized an important role for glia in Rett syndrome (RTT), and the ability of glia, specifically astrocytes, to rescue RTT-like phenotypes in mouse models. Using human-based models for RTT, our recent studies suggest that mitochondrial abnormalities likely mediate the impaired energy metabolism in RTT astrocytes. The proposed studies aim to understand the cause of mitochondrial dysfunction in human astrocytes, the consequences of abnormal mitochondria on astrocytes’ structure and function, and ultimately on their support to neurons. We will rescue the mitochondrial aberrations in human RTT astrocytes and determine whether they, in turn, can rescue the structural and functional aberrations of human RTT astrocytes. The proposed studies have the potential (i) to advance our understanding of impaired mitochondria in human astrocytes and its contribution to RTT neuropathology, and (ii) to identify potential targets to rescuing mitochondrial aberrations and restoring the astrocytes’ support to neurons in human RTT models and, ultimately, in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative GSDMs and NINJ1 are associated with many human diseases, and deletion of GSDMD or NINJ1 significantly decreases pyroptosis, and remarkably protects mice from sepsis. Genetic mutations in GSDMA3, GSDME or DFNB59 cause alopecia and hyperkeratosis in mice and nonsyndromic hearing loss in humans, while polymorphism of GSDMB is linked to increased asthma and IBD risk. Elucidating the structural mechanism of pore formation by GSDMs will have significant impact on generating potential therapeutics against these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In a paper published in PNAS in 2023, we found that two different NOP receptor (NOPR) agonists potently induced sleep and profoundly increased EEG delta power in rats, mice, and non-human primates, suggesting that the N/OFQ-NOPR system may have a previously unrecognized role in sleep/wake regulation. At the highest doses tested, the magnitude of the NREM sleep and EEG delta power increase induced by either NOPR agonist exceeded that produced by the GABAA agonist zolpidem (AmbienTM, the leading insomnia medication). Since our studies to date have been based on use of exogenous compounds, in this proposal, we will test the hypothesis that the N/OFQ-NOPR system is a component of the endogenous sleep/wake regulatory system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative No treatment currently exists for Alzheimer’s-induced impairments of memory formation, a devastating symptom contributing to the massive toll of the disease. This project will investigate circuit mechanisms for associative memory impairment in the lateral entorhinal cortex. The project is expected to yield advances towards the development of therapeutics to rescue memory function processed in the lateral entorhinal cortex.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because a better understanding of risk in obsessive- compulsive disorder (OCD) across ancestral populations will lead to improved methods for prevention and treatment for all. This proposal focuses on rare genetic variation, which is understudied in OCD, and proposes to investigate risk for OCD in people of African/African American ancestry, which are under-represented in prior studies. It is relevant to the NIH mission of understanding risk architecture for mental illness including in diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative Many patients suffering from Post-Acute Sequelae (PASC) fulfill the clinical diagnostic criteria for Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (ME/CFS). Understanding whether PASC ME/CFS shares overlapping mechanisms with non-PASC ME/CFS is critical, as this could provide insights into the mechanisms and inform treatment strategies of ME/CFS in general. In this project, we aim to conduct non-invasive brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to compare the similarities and differences in cerebral oxygen and glucose metabolism between the two patient groups as well as healthy controls, correlating these MRI derived parameters with patient reported outcome measures and study the effects over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE This research project aims at determining how sensorimotor cortex in nonhuman primates contributes to the control of volitional adjustments to locomotion in an adaptive manner. The ability to modify gait with precise, voluntary adjustments is what allows animals to navigate complex terrains and to execute skilled actions during ongoing pursuits. Beyond the relevance to the basic neuroscience of sensorimotor control of locomotion, the aims of the project are essential for the development of new mobility therapies, including brain-machine interfaces, for restoring walking and volitional leg control in people with paralysis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug-resistant tuberculosis is a major global cause of morbidity and mortality with the need for rapid, accurate drug susceptibility tests that can be performed outside of centralized labs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to conduct a community-based longitudinal mixed-methods study characterizing sleep health inequities in a sample of Black sexual minority men across a 12-month period, focusing on upstream determinants (intersectional stigma and discrimination) and downstream consequences (mental health, physical health, and health behavior). Results will elucidate mechanisms through which intersectional stigma and discrimination at individual and structural levels affect sleep health and how compromised sleep health, in turn, contributes to mental and physical health problems in this group. Community input and mixed-methods data will inform future policies and intervention efforts, paving the path to health equity for this underserved group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is the most common type of sleep related breathing disorder characterized by frequent airway collapse during sleep. The goal of the project is to develop an innovative motion robust 3D high resolution dynamic MRI approach to quantitatively discern airway shaping in OSA. The successful completion will overcome major technical challenges in safely quantitating airway collapse during OSA in sleep.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Within a patient’s tumor, malignant cells are surrounded by a network of non-malignant cells including endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and infiltrating immune cells, which collectively contribute to the tumor microenvironment (TME). Recent work has revealed the presence of an intratumoral microbiota within most solid cancers; yet there is a fundamental lack of understanding on how microbes within the TME interact with human components of the tumor, or how they might contribute to disease progression. This proposal seeks to meticulously map the intricate cellular and metabolic landscape of tumor BCMs and their surrounding immune environment to advance mechanistic understanding of host-microbiota interactions within the TME, with the potential to reveal novel approaches for cancer prevent and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative This research will characterize language development and auditory function in young children who were exposed prenatally to the Zika virus. Altered auditory neural processing, even when hearing sensitivity is normal, can affect language development. This work will help to identify biological and postnatal environmental factors that contribute to increased risk for language and communication difficulties in children with prenatal exposure to viruses and provide novel information for detection and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adult survivors of CHD are the fastest growing group of CHD patients, approximating 40,000 per year, and with more adults now living with CHD than children; yet obstacles to transitioning from pediatric to adult care puts them at risk for significant morbidity and mortality. In this proposal, we aim to reduce care disparities in young adults with CHD by: 1) understanding geographic access and use of patient navigation to adult CHD services for high-risk populations (rural, minority and low socioeconomic status), 2) identifying barriers for transitioning successfully from pediatric to adult-oriented cardiac health services and partnering with adult CHD experts to actively re-engage high-risk patients in appropriate ACHD care, and 3) exploring novel medical shared care delivery models to increase the adult CHD workforce and improve long-term morbidity and mortality for this rapidly expanding population. We also propose to create the infrastructure for a novel REsearch And Career Health Equity System (REACHES) program to train a new generation of pediatric health disparities researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite their potential to prevent and treat gut infections, microcins remain severally understudied. We have developed computational and cell-based approaches that show microcins are widespread among Gram-negative bacteria and have identified potent examples effective against the gut pathogen Vibrio cholerae. Through this proposal we will uncover sequence-activity relationships controlling microcin activity and explore cell-based vectors to deliver them and treat V. cholerae intestinal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adoptive T cell therapy (ACT) has the potential to revolutionize cancer treatment by utilizing the immune system to target cancer cells. However, T cell exhaustion and the absence of stem cell memory T cells pose challenges to the effectiveness of ACT. We aim to enhance ACT by improving T cell phenotypes through epigenetic programming. By identifying key targets and gene regulatory regions associated with T cell exhaustion via high- throughput genetic and epigenetic screening, we will use epigenome editing to manipulate these factors and improve T cell function for better tumor control. This work will establish a framework for epigenetic engineering in human T cells and advance the development of an improved ACT platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our laboratory previously identified a variant of small cell lung cancer (SCLC) which lacks neuroendocrine identity, but instead resembles the tuft cell lineage, which has been clinically validated and is now referred to as SCLC-P. The goal of this proposal will be to reveal the unique biology and molecular vulnerabilities of SCLC-P, an aggressive tumor subtype defined POU2F3 expression and dependency. This project will integrate the latest innovations in molecular epigenetics together with novel genetic models of this disease to explore the emergent biological properties of this distinct tumor lineage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our overarching goal is to determine whether a newly discovered form of macromolecular organization – protein phase-separation – can explain the strong age dependency of human disease. Recently, it has been increasingly appreciated that many proteins involved in neurodegeneration and other diseases of aging have the capacity to self-associate, condensing to form ‘phase-separated’ compartments called biomolecular condensates. Our proposal leverages comprehensive libraries of human disease alleles along with biochemistry, cell biology, and physiological modeling to investigate and define the contribution of protein phase separation, and aggregation, to the age dependency of human disease processes.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite significant science, technology, and innovation system growth in Peru, the country’s approach to research ethics has not kept pace, resulting in few scholars in research ethics, scant options for graduate degrees or specialty track in research ethics, and scant original ethics research. Our goal is to increase the quality of research ethics and responsibly conducted health research in Peru. For this, we will provide a master’s degree program and options for advanced education in research ethics and integrity for multidisciplinary professions through practicum experiences, research opportunities, and professional mentoring.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have generated a novel approach to deliver a natural antiinflammatory protein (interleukin-10) using naturally occurring human cell-derived extracellular vesicles (exosomes) to reduce the risk of infection and inflammation-induced preterm birth. In mouse models, this drug can cross the placenta to treat the fetus and delay preterm birth with no side effects to the mother or the fetus. Before clinical trials in humans, we will conduct various toxicology studies using two animal models of pregnancy (mouse and nonhuman primates) and validate these results using a newly developed humanized intrauterine pregnancy tissue (organ on a chip; Non-Animal Model) before submitting the drug for FDA approval for clinical trials during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We remain ignorant about the tissue dynamics that govern cancer development during aging or chronic tissue injury. One primary example is liver cancer, which is the third most lethal cancer worldwide and largely develops within a chronically diseased liver. By unraveling the mechanisms by which the most frequent oncogenic mutation in liver cancer interacts with the tissue microenvironment in both healthy and diseased livers, we can potentially unlock novel therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autistic adults are more vulnerable to developing early-onset dementia than the general population as they age. This study aims to uniquely quantify dementia-sensitive neurocognitive, brain, and plasma biomarkers in middle- aged autistic adults to reveal pathophysiological mechanisms underlying prodromal dementia in autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The proposed studies will provide foundational insights into dementia pathophysiology in ASD to inform screening, diagnosis, therapeutic plans, and monitoring strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: RNA editing plays a crucial role in cellular processes to prevent autoimmunity, making aberrant RNA editing a significant factor in the development of autoinflammatory diseases. We aim to employ advanced experimental and computational techniques to identify critical RNA substrates in autoinflammatory diseases. By integrating these substrates into a cumulative score, we seek to enable the stratification and treatment of patients with diverse autoinflammatory conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The automobile towing industry is one of the most dangerous jobs in the US, with the highest fatality rate among all private industries. Despite this, it has received little attention and research, as highlighted at the National Occupational Injury Research Symposium. This proposal addresses this gap by identifying interventions that could reduce the risk of struck-by traumatic injuries among tow truck operators, in alignment with the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health 2019-2026 Strategic Plan (“Improve workplace safety to reduce traumatic injuries”).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: 11 Project Narrative Every year, tens of thousands of people in the United States await a life-saving kidney transplant; however, there exists a major shortage in transplants that is at least partially due to a high discard rate of transplant- quality deceased-donor kidneys. Our preliminary research suggests that widely varying thresholds for accepting a deceased-donor kidney among doctors may contribute to the high discard rate. To address this issue, our proposed study investigates how doctors make decisions about accepting kidneys for transplantation, aiming to reduce medically unjustifiable discards and save more lives by informing the future development of targeted interventions to improve the transplantation system.
