ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Falls are the second leading cause of unintentional death worldwide and lower limb prosthesis users constitute an exceptionally high-risk group. Currently, there are a lack of clinically accessible tools that can robustly predict fall risk across a representative sample of lower limb prosthesis users. Gait analysis performed with markerless motion capture has the potential to identify causal, modifiable, biomechanical risk factor for falls and could produce a cost-effective and easy-to-use fall risk screening framework.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mechanism of sensory innervation-induced regulation of limbal stem cells (LSCs) during corneal epithelial renewal, required for corneal maintenance and wound healing and ultimately critical for vision, is unknown. Based on preliminary findings, we hypothesize that Schwann cells (SCs) residing in the corneal limbus alongside LSCs are critical in mediating the innervation-dependent activity of LSCs. Therefore, we propose mechanistically defining the paracrine interactions between SCs and LSCs that regulate LSC activity, which, in turn, will enable development of novel topical therapeutics to treat NK in human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Triple-negative breast cancer is highly aggressive and uniformly lethal in the metastatic setting, highlighting the need for improved immunological control strategies for this disease. This project seeks to evaluate how the intracellular domain of the immune checkpoint receptor VISTA functions in triple-negative breast cancer. This should lead to the development of novel immunotherapeutic strategies to target VISTA for breast cancer and possibly other malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Native Hawaiian individuals represent one of the most underserved and understudied populations in medical research despite being one of the fastest growing populations in the US and facing alarming long-standing health disparities, many of which are metabolic in nature. In this study, we will generate large-scale metabolomic data in this population and Japanese Americans, who have complementary risk profiles compared to Native Hawaiians, to investigate genetic factors contributing to metabolic profiles in these populations and metabolic factors that contribute to the health and health disparities of these populations. This investigation will greatly bolster epidemiologic research in these understudied populations, and findings are expected to have important implications for mitigating health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Impaired mitochondrial biology in brain and immune cells is an emerging candidate mechanism for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) pathogenesis, but rigorously testing this hypothesis requires scalable approaches to profile mitochondrial phenotypes will cell-type specific resolution. In this proposal, we develop for public use and deploy a novel mitochondrial phenotyping approach – mitotyping – in brain cortical cells (ROSMAP cohort, n=381) and in circulating immune cells (RANN/CR cohort, n=175), and link the resulting cell type-specific mitotype alterations to age, cognitive reserve, and AD pathology among women and men. Mechanistically, we also deepen our understanding of mitotypes by complementing these studies with in vitro experiments that establish how primary energetic mitochondrial perturbations dynamically alter other domains of mitochondrial biology within single cells, between cells, and among immune cells of patients with rare mitochondrial DNA defects, thereby providing a novel approach, framework, and foundation to explore the role of mitochondrial alterations in human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. Shift workers, including frontline healthcare workers, bear a disproportionately heavy burden of obesity and cardiometabolic diseases due to late night and erratic eating patterns, logistical challenges associated with receiving care, and near-universal exclusion from relevant clinical trials. Time-restricted eating is a simple lifestyle intervention that structures eating patterns and can lead to weight loss and cardiometabolic improvements independent of diet quality. We propose an innovative randomized control trial that utilizes remote monitoring and guidance, wearable medical devices, and a smartphone app to deliver and promote a TRE intervention to healthcare night-shift workers to promote weight loss, improve cardiometabolic health, and sustain behavior change in this vulnerable yet extremely vital part of our community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism spectrum disorder (ASD), characterized by widespread impairments in physiological function that result in social deficits, has a prevalence rate of approximately 1 in 36 individuals. The current state of treatment uses non-targeted therapies that are often ineffective in a large percentage of patients and have a host of side effects. The objective of this proposal is to rigorously and mechanistically explore how robust enhancement of serotonin signaling via a short-term 2-dose MDMA intervention leads to long-lasting adaptations in a corticostriatal circuit and results in a sustained reversal of social deficits present in a genetic mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Despite multilevel evidence that an infant who experiences a respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection during the first 12 months of life will have a higher chance of developing asthma later in life, the susceptibility window during infancy remains undefined and an age-dependent causal relationship remains unproven. The overarching goals of this study are to determine if RSV causes asthma, to identify the age range during which RSV infection is most likely to cause asthma, and to determine to what extent RSV prevention products, maternal vaccines and/or RSV monoclonal antibodies, decrease the risk for asthma. If RSV causes asthma and the effect is age-dependent, RSV prevention or delay could have short- and long-term benefits by reducing the burden of the two most common respiratory conditions that result in significant morbidity and mortality in infancy and childhood.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genomic sequencing at birth has great potential to improve health not only by identifying infants with undiagnosed genetic conditions, but also by providing information that allows families to prevent disease altogether and to make better medical care decisions. In order for newborn genomic screening to achieve its potential, medical and public health systems will need to adapt existing newborn screening programs, families and clinicians will need to adapt to information and manage findings over long periods of time, and labs will need to reexamine genetic information to ensure findings are up-to-date with new knowledge. This study provides critically-needed evidence that will inform how newborn genetic screening programs should be developed and sustained to provide lifelong benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular dementia (VaD) is the second leading cause of dementia behind Alzheimer’s disease (AD) but its pathogenesis is still only poorly understood. Building on the importance of pericytes (PC) in maintaining the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and previous studies showing that the extracellular matrix (ECM) protein perlecan inhibits pericyte functions, we recently found that aging, hypoxia and endothelial nitric oxide synthetase deficiency in mice trigger increased expression of perlecan, and diminished perlecan proteolysis into bioactive fragments in the vascular basement membrane, and that this correlates with reduced pericyte coverage and disrupted BBB integrity. In this proposal we aim to gain a deeper understanding of how perlecan regulates PC function, and then test the concept that manipulation of perlecan’s influence could be therapeutically beneficial in multiple models of VaD by enhancing PC coverage of cerebral blood vessels, leading to improved BBB integrity and protection from cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: For Veterans and others with ALS, maintaining the ability to communicate is imperative. VA research is at the forefront of intracortical brain-computer interface technology (iBCI), an investigational neurotechnology that could improve independence for Veterans and others living with severe speech and motor impairments. iBCIs have enabled individuals with tetraplegia to use computers by thinking about the movement of their own hand, and to control point-and-click actions for on-screen typing, browsing the web and other familiar enabling activities. The main goal of this project is to provide Veterans and others living with paralysis or loss of speech with an intuitive iBCI-based communication interface that seamlessly enables both point-and-click computer interaction and high-performance multi-digit typing based on intended hand and finger movements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT  Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the most common genetic kidney disease in the world, often leading to kidney failure, and there is no cure. Tolvaptan is the only FDA approved treatment, but its use is restricted to persons identified to be at risk of progression based on kidney size alone. Using a comprehensive panel of blood and urine tests the current project will improve the ability to identify persons at risk of rapid kidney disease progression who could benefit from tolvaptan treatment or inclusion in other treatment studies of ADPKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Leptospirosis is a neglected disease caused by a bacterium transmitted through contact with contaminated environmental sources such as soil and water, and a major cause of morbidity and mortality among residents of resource-poor countries and affects US residents engaging in water recreational activities, military personnel, and travelers to tropical destinations. Despite its public heath impact, no effective prevention is available. In this proposal we will characterize and evaluate a multi-recombinant protein construct that elicit cross protection against mortality and renal colonization—revealing immune B cell epitopes that can be use in a multi-epitope approach for a widely-applicable vaccine against leptospirosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: Project Narrative More than half of the world’s population is under the threat of Plasmodium infection that causes malaria. During and following COVID-19 the number of malarial cases and deaths have increased alarmingly, possibly due to the recalibrated efforts of healthcare systems to control the pandemic. The goal of our research is to identify and develop new immune-combinatorial therapies that improve function of immune cells that are critical for resistance to this globally important infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research study utilizes advanced bioinformatics and high-resolution spatial transcriptomics to identify social genomic mechanisms linking structural racism (SRD), perceived discrimination (PD), and aggressive breast cancer (BCa) blood and tumor biology as one explanation for why women living in historically redlined neighborhoods have worse BCa recurrence-free survival (RFS) outcomes, even after controlling for individual- level, tumor, and receipt of treatment factors. We will also utilize multiscale geographically weighted regression to identify neighborhoods associated with higher and lower risk-factors for shorter RFS, such as SRD, PD, aggressive biology, which will help us understand what low-risk regions are doing well, and subsequently what interventions can help promote longer RFS in high-risk regions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is is rapidly becoming the leading cause of liver disease in the developed world, with no effective treatment. We propose that mitochondrial genome molecules (mtDNA) released from fat- laden liver cells in NASH act as a “danger signal” which drive liver disease by causing scarring, and that detection of mtDNA in the blood can serve as a non-invasive biomarker of disease progression. We will perform mechanistic studies to decipher/elucidate the molecular pathways responsible for the pathogenic effects of mtDNA in the liver, with the aim of discovering much needed innovative therapies and diagnostic assays for NASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tick-borne rickettsial diseases that cause human monocytic ehrlichiosis and human granulocytic anaplasmosis have become a growing public health concern for nearly four decades in the USA and many parts of the world. In this proposal, we propose to extend investigations that define genetics and host cell-free growth methods for two important pathogens: Anaplasma phagocytophilum and Ehrlichia chaffeensis. This will be valuable in advancing the understanding of pathogenesis, and the bacterial cellular and molecular interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: TDP-43 is a protein that plays a role in Alzheimer's disease (AD) and other neurodegenerative disorders, but its involvement is not yet fully understood. Tau, another protein associated with neurodegenerative diseases, has been found to be comorbid with TDP-43 pathology. The aim of this proposal is to investigate the interaction between TDP-43 and Tau and to determine the consequences of their functional relationship, with the goal of identifying targetable molecular features that will yield uniquely superior therapeutics that outperform the current inadequate treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative Primary tauopathies have no fluid or imaging biomarkers to track the disease during life. We will define when and which forms of tau proteins change during disease progression in familial and sporadic primary tauopathies. If we find primary tauopathy biomarkers that can stage the disease, it can help with early diagnoses and clinical trial designs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This technology development project will demonstrate feasibility of a significant – by one to two orders of magnitude – increase in sensitivity of pulse EPR methods to study biomacromolecules at low concentrations. The approach is centered on the development of a radically new line of high volume / high quality factors resonators that are based on photonic band crystals adapted for operation in the mm-wave frequency range. If successful, the proposed approach will greatly expand the applicability of pulse EPR methods to basic and applied research in the fields of biochemistry and structural biology.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The Vanderbilt-Nigeria Research Ethics Training Program (V-NET) will build on our strong, decade-plus-long Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC)-Aminu Kano Teaching Hospital/Bayero University Kano (AKTH/BUK) partnership and our highly successful, collaborative, and rapidly expanding portfolio of NIH- funded research and training in Nigeria. V-NET will develop a new Master of Science degree program in research ethics at BUK that involves didactic courses in addition to skills development, mentoring, and practicum experiences to build capacity for the ethical design, conduct, and oversight of genetic and genomic research in Nigeria. Through a series of collaborative educational efforts at AKTH/BUK and VUMC, V-NET will create a cadre of academics, researchers, health professionals and institutional review board members who will provide future leadership in the ethical design and review of research in the rapidly developing field of genetic and genomic research in Nigeria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: Project Narrative: This project aims to improve recovery from Phrenic Neuropathy, a neuromuscular condition that impairs the diaphragm muscle, causing breathing difficulties that lead to disability. Our team plans to use Therapeutic Electrical Stimulation, a method emerging as a clinical strategy to speed up nerve regrowth, delivered via a novel, wireless and bioresorbable implant. The main hypothesis is that this Therapeutic Electrical Stimulation protocol, via enhanced Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) signaling in motor neurons, will accelerate the nerve regrowth and reconnection to the diaphragm muscle and improve recovery from Phrenic Neuropathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: Several investigators from the Departments of Chemistry, Biology, Engineering, and Material Science with biomedical science applications in western and southern Puerto Rico are seeking funding to acquire a Cytation 5 Imaging Multi-Mode Reader. This instrument would provide combined image reading and absorbance/fluorescence/luminescence reading capabilities, enabling research that is currently unsupported by existing equipment. The acquisition of this instrument would allow for time-sensitive and more complex screening assays to analyze biochemical and cell-based activities in 96 or 384 well plates. Additionally, it would facilitate high- throughput image-based analysis of live cells in real-time, leading to faster progress toward our project goals. The Cytation 5 Imaging Multi-Mode Reader would greatly enhance our ability to perform advanced research, expanding the scope of our investigations and enabling us to gather critical data that was previously inaccessible. With its versatile capabilities, we anticipate significant advancements in our understanding of biomedical science and accelerated progress in achieving our research objectives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Surgery to treat femur fractures is difficult as surgeons must manually apply large forces to align the broken bone fragments with limited visual feedback. Complications are frequent, including high rates of malalignment, reoperations, and mortality in the elderly. This research will develop an image-guided surgical robotic system for femur fracture surgeries that will assist the surgeon by providing sufficiently large traction forces and precise intuitive control to automatically align the bone fragments with real-time tracking of the bone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research uses novel technology to detect leukemia at low levels after transplantation and inform potential next steps in therapy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study aims to investigate how top-down brain networks influence pain processing using direct intracranial brain recordings during chronic pain and pain relief. It will explore the interaction between ascending and descending circuits and examine the influence of emotion and expectation on pain perception. The findings will contribute to understanding the underlying mechanisms of chronic pain and may inform new approaches for pain diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal focuses on understanding why older people often suffer more severe liver damage from burns and finding new ways to treat and detect this damage early. Using state-of-the-art technology, we explore how burns may affect liver cell energy production, particularly in older individuals, leading to more damage and poor outcomes. Our project is primed to revolutionize the understanding and treatment of burn-related liver injuries, heralding the development of innovative medicines and diagnostic techniques that could notably augment survival rates and enhance overall health outcomes, especially in elderly individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pain is a universal human experience, and growing evidence indicates a close crosstalk between circadian rhythms and pain disorders including headaches; however, the underlying molecular mechanism is poorly understood. Based on our recent preliminary results from behavioral, omics and molecular studies, the current proposal aims to investigate the circadian clock function in rhythmic pain responses and delineate the mechanism of a novel circadian regulator of headache pain. This pioneering project will generate seminal functional and mechanistic insights toward understanding the temporal basis of pain, and promote development of new mouse models and chronotherapeutic strategies for headache and other pain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Trichomonas vaginalis is estimated to be the most common non-viral sexually transmitted infection worldwide (STI), causes considerable and costly perinatal/reproductive morbidity, and disproportionately affects persons of color; currently recommended treatment regimens have high breakthrough rates of infection. This proposal will examine the effectiveness and cost effectiveness of single-dose 2 g oral secnidzole compared to multi-dose oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily X 7 days for the treatment of T. vaginalis in women and men. Results of this study will impact future Centers for Disease Control and Prevention STI Treatment Guidelines for T. vaginalis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to develop a novel method of vaccine delivery through the oral cavity mucosa using a vaccine coated floss. By developing this approach, it may be possible to generate mucosal and systemic immunity. The use of a floss is painless and child friendly, therefore, this new method of vaccination could have a strong impact on public health and vaccination campaigns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE APOE4 is the greatest known genetic risk factor for sporadic Alzheimer's and there exists a high unmet medical need for therapeutics that could prevent disease associated with this variant. We have developed an innovative split luciferase assay that can detect the binding of compounds to ApoE4 in cells. We propose to leverage this breakthrough to both discover new and optimize known ApoE4 correctors into drugs that can generate in vivo proof of concept that they can functionally correct ApoE4 pathobiology in murine models and ultimately be developed into a therapeutic for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Artificial intelligence systems are emerging into clinical practice but due to the way in which these systems are trained on historical data their performance is highly sensitive to variations in the imaging data used as input. Quality assurance and monitoring frameworks that can monitor and verify the performance of these artificial intelligence systems are an unmet need in the medical community including radiation oncology. The goal of this project is to develop and evaluate quality assurance frameworks for several different artificial intelligence use cases in radiation oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitral valve disease is often under-recognized and not well characterized in echocardiography, the most common form of cardiac imaging. Artificial intelligence has the potential to identify subtle phenotypes, often not recognized by human clinicians, and distinguish between stable asymptomatic incidental findings and high-risk features that can lead to sudden cardiac death and other adverse outcomes. We will leverage deep learning applied to cardiovascular imaging to capture key features of mitral valve disease that could represent intervenable targets for mitigating cardiovascular risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Cardiovascular disease is the worldwide leading cause of death and is frequently initiated or exacerbated by stress. Further, both chronic stress exposure and heightened physiological reactivity to acute psychological stress predict cardiovascular mortality. Our prior work found that the rodent infralimbic prefrontal cortex divergently regulates male and female stress responses and the goal of this proposal is to determine how sex-specific function of infralimbic projections to the hypothalamus mediate stress-induced cardiovascular susceptibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Racial disparities in blood pressure (BP) control persist even after accounting for individual risk factors, and access to healthcare and insurance. Although currently available therapies can achieve high BP control rates, many patients experience uncontrolled BP, and racial disparity in BP control persist likely due to less aggressive treatment and poor patient follow-up. This study aims to explore the extent and determinants of racial/ethnic disparity in hypertension treatment according to recommended guidelines and its impact on patient BP control, with the goal of developing future targeted interventions to improve BP control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Central field loss due to age-related macular degeneration is highly prevalent, debilitating, and can lead to accidents and injury. The individuals’ decreased visual acuity and inability to correctly make compensatory eye movements and exploratory gaze shifts make performing daily tasks such as navigating a crowded street very difficult and even dangerous. This proposal investigates how loss of central vision affects individuals’ ability to look between objects in depth, stabilize objects on the retina during linear motion (e.g., walking), and coordinate eye and head movements to resolve oculomotor conflicts to appropriately meet gaze-shifting demands.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Endometriosis is a common condition, and there is a poor understanding of the genes and noncoding regulatory elements that drive disease development. This project will combine state-of-the-art single cell epigenomics and multiomics with new analytic methods that leverage germline risk information to identify cell types, regulatory elements and genes involved in disease development and outcomes. These insights are expected to pave the way to the development of personalized risk scores and precision medicine for endometriosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Monosomy 7 (-7) and deletions (del) of the long arm of chromosome 7 (-7/del(7q)) are the most frequent cytogenetic abnormalities and are associated with poor prognosis and chemoresistance. The proposed experiments aim to elucidate the mechanisms of NUP205 deletion in driving the bone marrow insufficiency phenotype, creating specific vulnerabilities, and influencing drug responses, as well as access the efficacy of elesclomol-based combination therapeutics for the treatment of -7/del(7q) malignancies in vivo and in vitro. Our long-term goal is to leverage a deep mechanistic understanding of haploinsufficient essential gene-mediated synthetic lethality to develop innovative therapeutic approaches to treat predisposition syndromes, preleukemia, and leukemia carrying chromosome and copy number deletions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We aim to generate novel bispecific antibody-drug conjugates (bisADCs) against pairs of emerging prostate cancer cell surface antigens expressed by adenocarcinoma and small cell neuroendocrine cancer. BisADCs have unique advantages compared with a mix of monoclonal ADCs, as they trigger synergistic effects through antigen tethering that improve drug delivery and anti-tumor efficacy. By benchmarking against ADCs currently in clinical trials, we will identify lead bisADCs with superior therapeutic index against the two subtypes of prostate cancer, which will be translated to clinical testing in the near future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We discovered that HMGB1 induces autophagy –a pro-survival mechanism in malignant mesothelioma (MM) that leads to chemo-resistant, and we found that antidepressant drugs (ADs) inhibit autophagy and sensitize MM cells to chemodrugs-induced apoptosis. Moreover, mitochondria protein, Mcl-1, blocks MM cell death when treated with chemotherapy. Here, we propose to study whether ADs may improve chemotherapy and whether that effect is further enhanced in combination with Mcl-1 inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lipids are abundant molecules in the brain and, as a result, are thought to be involved in both the aging process and common age-related neurodegenerative diseases. We recently discovered a new class of anti-inflammatory lipids, called SGDGs, that are greatly reduced in the brain during aging. In this proposal, we aim to understand why SGDG levels decrease with age and whether these lipids contribute to aging and a higher risk of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the tremendous advancement in organ-on-a-chip technologies, antibody-mediated rejection (ABMR) models on-a-chip have not been developed. Therefore, the overarching goal of this proposal is to engineer a synergistically integrated multi-organ-on-chip platform comprised of biomimetic vascularized human-tissue chips that will recapitulate the pathophysiology of ABMR, which will be coupled with a fully automated, compact, cost- effective, electrochemical biosensor monitoring allograft function and injury. Our goal is to offer a novel platform that can significantly impact transplant immunology research while accelerating the understanding of ABMR, increasing the translation of novel ABMR treatment protocols and regimens to the clinic, and improving organ allocation schemes for highly sensitized patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Skeletal muscle is central to everything we do and must repair to meet the vital demands of human life. Human pluripotent stem cells are the only in vitro system that can create unlimited numbers of muscle cells in a dish. How hPSCs commit to all stages of skeletal muscle growth and how to support these muscle cells once they are created is pivotal to improve our understanding of skeletal muscle repair, development, and to design better cell therapies. Skeletal muscle stem cells are supported by their niche, but the molecular cues regulating the niche of hPSC muscle cells has only begun to be explored. This proposal seeks to regulate the hPSC muscle niche to better support the number and function of muscle cells created by hPSCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR (LAST, FIRST, MIDDLE): Legrand, Matthieu Project Narrative Hypotension during surgery and anesthesia is a major contributor to postoperative acute kidney injury (PO-AKI), which is associated with higher risk of cardiovascular events, chronic kidney disease, higher costs, and mortality. Vasopressors are the key pharmacologic intervention to correct general anesthesia-induced vasodilation but the best vasopressor to use is unknown. We propose to perform a multicenter cluster randomized, multiple-crossover trial of phenylephrine versus norepinephrine in adult patients undergoing major non-cardiac surgery to answer the question of the best vasopressor to prevent PO-AKI. VEGA-2 M.Legrand June 2023 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Disorders such as major depression, schizophrenia, and autism spectrum disorders are marked by debilitating deficits in social interactions, but our lack of understanding of the basis of social interactions presents a major roadblock to developing neural circuit-based therapies to treat them. Here, we propose to study the single-neuron and circuit basis of cooperation and inter- brain synchronization using rhesus macaques playing cooperative social games. We will investigate how recent social interactions shape neural representations and the causal basis of cooperation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Impairments in new learning and memory are common in Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and negatively impact several important aspects of everyday life (e.g., social and occupational functioning), but treatment options are limited due to the lack of cognitive rehabilitation (CR) protocols supported by Class I research evidence. To address this critical need, the presently proposed randomized clinical trial (RCT) examines the efficacy of an 8-session CR protocol encompassing training in the application of three strategies (self-generation, spaced learning, and retrieval practice) with the greatest empirical evidence to treat impaired learning and memory in persons with MS: Strategy-Based Training to Enhance Memory (STEM). Results are expected to substantially improve our ability to treat learning and memory deficits in persons with MS, which would lead to improved everyday functioning and overall quality of life for persons with MS, as well as reduced caregiver burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The incidence of dementia is dramatically increasing, and there is an urgent need to identify risk factors and prevention strategies for cognitive impairment and dementia, including Alzheimer’s disease. There is growing recognition that cardiovascular integrity is associated with abnormal brain changes and cognitive impairment. The proposed project will generate evidence to support the development of novel strategies for delaying dementia onset and progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interindividual variation in the effectiveness of cancer chemotherapy cannot be fully explained or predicted, resulting in health risks to patients and inefficient utilization of limited healthcare resources. While variations in the gut microbiome of patients have been shown to influence treatment outcomes, the mechanisms by which these microbes change chemotherapeutic drug disposition remain poorly understood. Based on our strong in vivo and in vitro data showing that a prevalent gut microbe inhibits a key drug efflux transporter, this proposal will expand our mechanistic understanding of host-microbiome interactions in drug disposition and provide the first step towards using microbial genes and/or metabolites as predictive markers for cancer chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative New therapeutic strategies are badly needed in Early T-cell precursor Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ETP- ALL), yet current biological understanding of this subtype of pediatric leukemia is limited. The completion of COG’s AALL00344 clinical trial, which enrolled 325 ETP-ALL patients, represents an exciting opportunity to improve our understanding of the biological reasons for treatment failure. Using single cell multi-omics coupled with patient-specific and large-scale computational validation studies, we will define molecular features of ETP- ALL that explain treatment resistance, improve understanding of carcinogenesis and its relation to normal T-cell development, and define novel targetable genes and pathways for patients with ETP-ALL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Program Narrative Approximately 25% of persons in the United States have an audiometric signs of hearing loss consistent with noise damage, and this hearing loss impacts their ability to understand speech and discern different sounds. Although the primary cause of hearing loss is damage to the hair cells in the cochlea, the central nervous system also undergoes changes in how the remaining auditory signal is processed and perceived. In this proposal, we examine changes to the brain mechanisms in the first part of the brain that processes sound, the cochlear nucleus, in order to help develop optimal strategies to correct for hearing loss, and to understand how sound (including speech) discrimination and perception are affected by hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance: Atherosclerosis is a progressive chronic inflammatory disease that remains the leading cause of death in the USA and worldwide in spite of widespread use of statins, other lipid lowering strategies, and life-style modifications. Remarkably, despite decades of research, little is known about late stage lesion development and mechanisms that result in the rupture or erosion of the protective fibrous cap overlying advanced atherosclerotic lesions leading to catastrophic thrombotic events including a heart attack (i.e. myocardial infarction) or stroke. The goal of studies in this proposal is to develop novel approaches for reducing the late stage clinical complications of atherosclerosis through dietary and/or pharmacological approaches that induce metabolic reprogramming of the key cell types that we have recently shown form the protective fibrous cap, enabling them to form a thicker and mechanically more robust fibrous cap (i.e. analogous to a stronger patch on a tire), and thereby reducing the probability of lesion rupture or erosion leading to a possible heart attack or stroke.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (NARRATIVE) Increasing clinical evidence suggests an association between osteoporosis and Alzheimer's disease (AD), two age-related disorders, but the underlying mechanisms remains poorly understood. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed MARC-WSU program will equip high achieving juniors and seniors from underrepresented groups with the skills needed to complete their undergraduate degrees, matriculate into a graduate program, and pursue a career as a leader in biomedical research. Through the MARC-WSU program, a diverse and well-trained pool of scientists and engineers will contribute to creative and innovative health solutions allowing the United States to remain a world leader in biomedical sciences. Moreover, by increasing diversity in the biomedical sciences workforce MARC-WSU will enable the United States to eliminate health disparities across the nation by providing an empathetic workforce that reflects all socioeconomic backgrounds.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance) Episodic memory plays a key role in children's social and cognitive development, and likely influences life outcomes in adulthood, but young children have poor memories for past events. In this grant, we propose a theory-based and innovative series of studies in which we measure component processes of episodic memory longitudinally, while also collecting measures of structural brain changes and measures of real-world autobiographical memory. Findings from the proposed studies will lead to a better theoretical framework to facilitate healthy development and to ground intervention methods with at-risk populations such as children with temporal lobe epilepsy, Down Syndrome or Type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Drug resistance in targeted cancer therapy usually occurs in solid tumors. This project aims to identify the biological and structural bases of resistance to aid in the selection and development of a pipeline of drugs to delay the progression of tumors. This project is relevant to the mission of the National Cancer Institute because it will lead to longer survival of patients with cancer and an eventual cure for the disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The long-term goal is to develop effective physical rehabilitation approaches to improve balance and gait to prevent falls in people with Parkinson’s disease and other elderly people at high fall risk. To reach this goal, we will identify objective measures of turning, gait and mobility activity during daily life that best reflect fall risk and to explore the use of home monitoring of mobility as outcome measures for rehabilitation to improve turning quality. We will also test the effectiveness of a Turning Boot Camp rehabilitation intervention to improve quality of turning and mobility in people with Parkinson’s disease. 05-08-17

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Dynamic rearrangements of the actin cytoskeleton are essential to all eukaryotic cells. Defects in actin regula- tion are associated with various diseases, ranging from immunodeficiency and neurodevelopmental disorders to cancer metastasis and pathogen infection. The proposed research will determine the fundamental mecha- nisms of central actin regulators known as the Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome Protein (WASP) family proteins, which will lay the foundation for understanding how actin remodeling is dysregulated in diseases and can be treated therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A three-week intensive lecture- and laboratory-based course will be held at an institution renowned for advanced research courses, with the overall goal of attracting new investigators to research on normal and disordered hearing and balance. Course participants at various stages of training (all post-undergraduate) will work shoulder-to-shoulder with many expert course faculty to learn cutting-edge experimental approaches specific to auditory and vestibular biology as well as the potential for conducting research that improves the lives of patients. The course experience will initiate scientific networks for the course participants and, as a corollary benefit, increase interactions among established investigators from different sub-fields of hearing, balance, and related research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the clinical high risk for psychosis (CHR) criteria offer an important public health target and opportunity to prevent psychotic disorders, substantial heterogeneity exists in CHR both at ascertainment and in outcome that limits treatment development. Our 26 international sites will recruit 1040 CHR and follow them with clinical and biomarker assessments over two years, along with 260 healthy controls assessed at baseline. In partnership with the Data Processing, Analysis, and Coordinating Center, we will contribute to analyses to dissect the heterogeneity of CHR and develop tools for outcome definition and patient stratification.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For use in low- and middle-income countries, we propose to develop an affordable, automated colorectal cancer detection (GeneXpert® CRC-MD) assay that analyzes our published, hypermethylated DNA panel in plasma to rapidly detect malignancy. In collaboration with our industry partner, Cepheid, and our clinical team in Nigeria and Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, we will analytically and technically validate the assay for future product development. Innovative approaches to increase early detection and decrease treatment delays of CRC can save thousands of lives in the many resource-poor areas of the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Genetic copy number variations (CNVs) play a causative role in neurodevelopmental disorders, increasing their risk by up to 30-fold. Although the biological effects of CNVs are not fully understood, we show that they produce abnormal excitability in neurons and circuits. We will use mouse and human cells to study the biological effects of a specific CNV on chromosome 16 and repurpose current anticancer and antiepilepsy drugs in an attempt to reverse the excitatory/inhibitory imbalance in human neurons with this CNV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Improving opioid use disorder outcomes depends not only on developing evidence-based treatments and prevention strategies, but also on optimizing the healthcare delivery and payment systems in which these interventions are deployed. Though value-based care is one of the most widespread healthcare delivery system innovations in the US today, large knowledge gaps remain in our understanding of whether – and how – these models promote better care quality for people with opioid use disorder. This career development award application proposes to use Massachusetts Medicaid accountable care organization implementation as a natural experiment to understand the effect of value-based care reform on quality of care and adequacy of reimbursement for opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial and human hypermutations are essential for fitness in response to environmental challenges, but must be tightly regulated to avoid genetic chaos. The proposed research studies the regulation of error-prone DNA polymerase V, required to copy past DNA template lesions in Escherichia coli, which avoids cell death, and the regulation of activation-induced deoxycytidine deaminase (AID), which initiates somatic hypermutation required to generate antibody diversity in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The DNA damage response pathway is important for repair damage DNA in cells. Many cancer therapies involve DNA damage-inducing agent, and a detailed understanding of the DNA damage response pathway and in cancer cells will help us to design targeted therapy for specific cancers. Ovarian cancer (OC) is one of the most common gynecological cancers among women worldwide. We recently identified SYK tyrosine kinase as a key player in the DNA damage response and contributes to chemoresistance in ovarian cancer. We will study how SYK regulates DNA repair and whether we can use SYK inhibitor to sensitize ovarian cancer cells to chemotherapy and PARP inhibitor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most genetic variants associated with common diseases are difficult to interpret, because they lie within non- coding regions of the genome with unknown function. This project will leverage high-throughput genomic perturbations and computational analyses to establish a new strategy to discover novel regulatory sequences, interpret non-coding variants, and connect disease-associated variants to the genes they regulate. The results from this project will accelerate understanding of gene regulation and molecular mechanisms underlying human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fatal opioid overdose is one of the most pressing issues affecting the U.S., yet the current standardized screening measures for opioid misuse in clinical practice are under-performed, laborious, and susceptible to demand characteristics and concerns about stigmatizing the patient. To combat these issues, BEAM Diagnostics, Inc. developed Beacon-OUD, a digital opioid misuse assessment that efficiently produces an objective measure and prevents potential judgements related to patient status, circumstance, or bias. This proposal, an extension of a successful Phase I STTR, seeks to develop Beacon-OUD into a fully-realized product for use both as a stand-alone tool and as an EMR-integrated solution for large healthcare systems to maximize standardized opioid screening in a variety of healthcare settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to detect low levels of cancer is crucial for cancer diagnosis and treatment; however, even state-of- the-art techniques such as imaging and ‘liquid biopsy’ through deep sequencing fail to detect cancer when the tumor burden is extremely low, as can occur after treatment or surgery when small numbers of cancer cells remain. To address the challenges of detecting such low levels of cancer we propose to make non-incremental advances in our promising recently developed technology – MRDetect – which uses a sample of the patient's blood to find low levels of tumor by employing powerful computational tools of artificial intelligence to dramatically boost cancer detection. We expect that these advances will also foster broad adoption of this new technology across cancer, empowering precision cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Human physiology is markedly influenced by environment through interaction with a family of sensors known as PAS proteins. Proteins such as the Ah receptor influence our response to the microbiome, proteins like Clock influence our response to light and circadian time and the HIFs influence our response to atmospheric oxygen levels. By understanding how these proteins effect human physiology we can better understand and design prevention strategies and therapeutics for a variety of environmentally modified diseases such as cancer, diabetes, inflammatory bowel disease, and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Congenital heart disease (CHD) is the leading cause of death due to birth defects, but the etiologies remain mostly unknown. We have identified a gene named SHROOM3 as a candidate for causing CHD, and this project investigates SHROOM3’s mechanism in Wnt/PCP signaling in the heart. Identifying a novel CHD candidate, and its mechanism of action, has potential to improve CHD diagnosis, identify comorbidity risks, tailor treatment strategies, and develop therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Program narrative The Training Program in Pharmacological Sciences provides PhD students with a comprehensive background in the discipline of Pharmacology by bringing together training faculty from different research fields involved in the discovery, development and use of therapeutic compounds, exposing students to relevant clinical problems, emphasizing translational research, and providing opportunities for students to present their research in national and international meetings. The program offers courses in Pharmacology, provides training in quantitative research skills, scientific communication and writing, and supports career development activities to ensure the success of students in subsequent research-intensive and research-related careers. The training grant supports students early during their training (1st and 2nd year), emphasizes recruitment and retention of diverse students, upholds a culture of responsible conduct in research as well as rigor and reproducibility in scientific research and has outstanding outcomes, with alumni represented in the entire spectrum of the research enterprise, leading research groups in academia and industry, defining patent law, and shaping future research policy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over half of all low-income, U.S. children live in unaffordable, unstable, and/or substandard-quality housing, which has been linked to a range of adverse child outcomes; however, little is known about the impact of these housing conditions on infants’ and toddlers’ health and development, how housing and neighborhood environments interact to influence young children’s healthy development, and whether other anti-poverty programs can improve housing circumstances for low-income families with young children. Using data from the NICHD-funded (R01HD087384) Baby’s First Years (BFY) study – a large-scale randomized control trial evaluating the impact of a monthly, unconditional cash transfer (UCT) to low-income mothers – I will study how a UCT impacts housing affordability, composition (i.e., who lives in the household), stability, and quality among low-income families with infants and toddlers, the configurations of housing and neighborhood ecosystems experienced by low-income families, and how housing and neighborhood characteristics impact young children’s healthy development. Results from this proposal will offer new insights into how early childhood housing and neighborhood conditions interact with family economic resources to shape children’s health and development trajectories, as well as inform the design of anti-poverty programs aimed at improving early childhood environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The issue of chromosome interactions is clearly relevant to public health, as these can lead to dramatic changes in transcription and may, therefore, directly contribute to disease. Indeed, aberrant interactions may also increase mitotic recombination, aneuploidy, and the formation of translocations, all of which have long been known to be underlying causes for many diseases, including cancer. As the mechanisms of chromosome interactions have not yet been systematically explored, this study has the potential to reveal new therapeutic targets for the treatment and prevention of chromatin-based diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative Utilizing complementary gain-of-function and loss-of-function approaches, the proposed studies will test the efficacy and safety of targeting miR-30c as novel stroke therapeutics in aged mice. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it represents a novel exploration of gait quality impairments in a chronic low back pain population with heightened fear-avoidance/pain catastrophizing, which puts them at increased risk for poor clinical outcomes. Identification of gait quality impairments in this high-risk population may lead to improved physical therapy interventions. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission to enhance health and reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: A next-generation extendable simulation environment for affordable, accurate, and  efficient free energy simulations PI: Tai-Sung Lee, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ 08854-8087 USA. In the filed of molecular simulations, a new generation of integrated methods, workflows, and phys-ical models are emerging, which leads to a critical barrier to progress in the field is the lack of a software package with seamless incorporation of existing software modules with emerging scien-tific advances. To surmount this barrier and in responding to NIH Focused Technology Funding Opportunity which calls for innovative, focused technology development of a working prototype of critical research tools, we propose to develop a next-generation executing environment for sim-ulations. The proposed work will offer fast prototyping, accessibility to new algorithms, further improvements in single-GPU performance, strong scaling in synchronous and asynchronous en-semble methods, and interoperability with different types of force fields and physical models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The experiments I propose aim to understand the effects of critical period odor experience on both the development of the olfactory bulb circuit and changes in innate odor behaviors in adolescent and adult mice. The goals of my proposed research are to quantify the changes in input and output from the olfactory bulb glomeruli that detect an odorant following olfactory critical period exposure to this odorant; furthermore, I propose to see if behavioral and morphological changes in this circuit persist following olfactory bulb reinnervation. These experiments will advance our understanding of how experience during a developmental critical period impacts neural circuit development and lasting behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Great attention has been paid to the potential role of the external globus pallidus (GPe) in motor control and the aberrant GPe neuronal activity is closely associated with movement deficits in both PD patients and Parkinsonian animal models. Our preliminary results show that the activity of newly identified glutamatergic neurons in the GPe may contribute to PD-related behavioral dysfunction in dopamine-depleted mice. Thus, we will elucidate the anatomical and functional organization of GPe glutamatergic neurons to improve our understanding of GPe circuitry and its contribution to PD-related behavioral dysfunction in animal models for the progressive PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The two major challenges to the care of patients with acute interstitial nephritis result from the lack a non- invasive biomarker. These include the need to perform a kidney biopsy to establish the diagnosis and lack of information on patients most likely to benefit from therapy. Here we will enroll a cohort of participants with biopsy-proven, adjudicated acute interstitial nephritis and suitable controls to validate IL-9*TNF-α as a biomarker for both establishing the diagnosis of acute interstitial nephritis and to identify patients most likely to benefit from therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Biliary tract cancer (BTC), the second most common primary hepatobiliary cancer worldwide, is highly fatal; approximately 90% of BTC patients die within five years after diagnosis. Therefore, primary and secondary prevention measures are vital to reduce its mortality rate. Herein, we propose a well-powered study to systematically search and validate novel biomarkers for BTC risk in order to design cost-effective strategies for BTC prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Transcriptional regulatory networks that control context-specific gene expression levels play a major role in defining the cell type identity. This project will develop and apply novel computational tools for single cell omic datasets to identify regulatory networks for individual cell types and examine how they change across related cell types. Our tools and resources will provide a broadly applicable framework to study network dynamics and how they affect normal and disease processes in mammalian species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Kaposi's sarcoma (KS) is one of the most common cancers in sub-Saharan Africa, and, like other tumors, early detection can lead to improved survival. We propose to develop, manufacture, and perform a multi-site sub-Saharan African clinical validation of KS-COMPLETE – the first true sample-to-answer diagnostic system for Kaposi's Sarcoma (KS). This system will enable physicians to diagnose KS at the point-of-care in less than 60 minutes – compared with the 2 weeks traditional pathology often requires – significantly improving patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: This study will examine the association between prenatal, early childhood, and adult metal exposures and late life cognitive function, as well as whether early life exposures modify effects of adult exposures. In a subset of a population that donated their baby teeth as children and is now in their 60's and 70's, we will analyze metals in those previously collected baby teeth to assess early life exposures and in repeated toenail samples for adult exposures and relate those to performance on cognitive tests. We will also assess micro RNA (miRNA) profiles from extracellular vesicles in blood of the adults to examine possible epigenetic mechanisms underlying associations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Even though smoking in pregnancy harms the baby, pregnant women struggle to quit smoking. We are coupling a texting program that helps pregnant women quit with a program to teach obstetric clinicians how to counsel women to quit. PHR: The goal of the training program is to train pediatricians for careers as investigators who will address the present and future challenges of childhood infections. Academic physicians with research interests in Pediatric Infectious Diseases are urgently needed to meet the ongoing and emerging threats to child health of the Covid- 19 pandemic, congenital HIV infection, childhood malaria and tuberculosis, diarrheal diseases, and respiratory infections—critical problems that are further complicated by increasing antimicrobial resistance, emerging infectious diseases, and societal opposition to childhood vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. Programmed death ligand-1 (PD-L1) is an immune checkpoint protein involved in tumor immune suppression and expressed in a variety of cancers. PD-L1 detection by immunohistochemistry is used to guide immune checkpoint therapies, however few tools exist to quantify total PD-L1 levels in the whole body and fewer to do so non-invasively. We will develop and translate a PD-L1 imaging agent to guide cancer immunotherapy, and create an easy to use kit formulation for improved dissemination and broad access.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ST. JOSEPH'S HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Manganese (Mn) is an established neurotoxicant that affects the same motor and cognitive brain pathways affected in Parkinson disease (PD), notably the nigrostriatal system. In this renewal, we will use positron emission tomography (PET) brain imaging to investigate the role of Mn in degeneration of the dopaminergic system and the potential neuroinflammatory mechanism. Successful completion of these aims will provide a unique opportunity to understand the mechanism of an important environmental neurotoxicant that targets the nigrostriatal brain pathway, which is the same pathway affected in PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because there is currently no clear understanding of the mechanistic underpinnings and roles of different inhibitory somatostatin receptor subtypes in the alpha and beta cells of the pancreatic islet. The mechanisms proposed complement existing understandings of paracrine signaling within the islet and integrate these with novel observations of filamentous actin reorganization following somatostatin receptor activation. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIDDK’s mission because it directly addresses the mechanism by which somatostatin inhibits insulin and glucagon secretion, which can be leveraged to improve the quality of life for millions of Americans with diabetes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black and Latina women experience a higher burden of pregnancy complications, maternal mortality, and preterm birth compared to white women due to the significant impact of racism and racialized inequity. Yet, no studies have examined whether experiences of racism prenatally affect fetal health and development through a process of “biological embedding” of racism measured daily during pregnancy. The proposed multi-site and rigorously-designed longitudinal research aims to advance understanding of racism-related health disparities as well as modifiable stress-buffering factors in pregnant Black and Latina women and infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application aims to investigate the impact of HIV brain infection and prescription opioids on ischemic stroke, a major co-morbidity in the infected population and opioid abusers. The central hypothesis is that HIV and prescription opioids activate inflammasome in the CNS that can worsen stroke outcome, including post-stroke HIV reactivation in the CNS and egress into the periphery. The obtained results will have a potential to be a major breakthrough by its focus on novel mechanisms underlying vascular comorbidity, such as ischemic stroke, in HIV infection and opioid abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Long-term survival after heart transplantation continues to be limited both by immune-mediated damage to the transplant and by adverse effects caused by calcineurin inhibitors (CNIs), which are part of nearly all immunosuppressive regimens in heart transplantation. In this application we propose to use belatacept, initially with a CNI that will be slowly reduced and then stopped, to achieve CNI-free immunosuppression (with mycophenolate mofetil and prednisone), which we hypothesize will prevent rejection, suppress the development of antibodies that cause damage to the transplant, and eliminate the adverse effects of CNIs together improving survival after heart transplantation. The accompanying studies will inform as to why the approach did or did not work and determine whether non-invasive biomarkers can be used to predict clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electroencephalography (EEG) is an essential clinical diagnostic and research tool in neurology and cognitive neuroscience, but the technology has essentially remained unchanged for the past 100 years. In this proposal, we aim to develop “next-generation” dry EEG using MXene, a material with high compatibility with biology and magnetic fields (e.g., like those in magnetic resonance imaging, MRI), high stability, is convenient to set up and clean up, and is low-cost relative to other devices. This project will offer researchers and clinicians a high-resolution dry EEG technology that overcomes many of the limitations of current devices used in hospitals and laboratories around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among the 12,000 individuals who serve as deceased organ donors yearly in the US, there are racial disparities that have persisted despite intervention, with the Black population most recently donating at 69% of the White population. Structural racism, the normalization and legalization of routinely disadvantaging minority populations, is an upstream social determinant of racial disparities in health and health outcomes, yet its contributions to racial and geographic variation in deceased organ donation have not been explored. The goal of this proposed research project is to examine whether structural racism and its downstream effects on healthcare resource availability and access explain racial and geographic differences in deceased organ donation; our results will be immediately applicable to contemporary policy addressing organ donor pool expansion and governing the allocation of scarce deceased donor organs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of vaccination strategies that protect against both known and future COVID-19 variants would greatly impact the COVID-19 pandemic trajectory and long-term global public health. This project will help determine which combination of diverse sarbecovirus exposures leads to the development of pan- sarbecovirus neutralizing antibodies, by conducting longitudinal surveillance of human cohorts naturally exposed to a high diversity of sarbecoviruses in Myanmar. Our findings will have broad implications for vaccine development and understanding of high-risk behaviors that are contributing to sarbecovirus spillover in a critically important ecological region for coronavirus emergence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because neutrophilic asthma is associated with poor response to existing therapies and increased disease severity. Understanding the biologic mechanisms responsible for severe asthma exacerbations, specifically the role of microRNAs in neutrophilic airway inflammation, will lead to the identification of new treatment modalities. This project will ultimately improve outcomes in severe neutrophilic asthma through tailored therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A third major spillover of a novel coronavirus from its animal reservoir into a human population occurred in late 2019 setting off a pandemic of severe acute respiratory distress, viral pneumonia and death that continues to be a major public health threat to this day. In addition to safe and effective vaccines, direct-acting antivirals with complementary mechanisms of action and patterns of resistance are desperately needed to treat symptomatic individuals during the acute phase of SARS-CoV-2 infection. Here, we propose a medicinal chemistry plan and screening strategy to improve the potency and pharmacokinetic properties of a novel series of coronavirus inhibitors. Our goal is to identify a broadly active Development Candidate for the treatment of COVID-19 and other coronaviruses with pandemic potential.

PHR: NARRATIVE The molecular mechanisms that govern the development of the human nervous system are incompletely understood. We recently discovered that expression of a transcription factor critical for neural development, SOX2, is regulated via dynamic reorganization of the three-dimensional architecture of the genome. Our research will elucidate the mechanisms underlying this previously unrecognized process and will allow us to harness the dynamics of 3D genome organization toward understanding and treating neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project will use an innovative mouse model of human ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) to understand how the potentially fatal disease in humans is caused and what newer and safer treatment options can be developed. AAV is an autoimmune disease characterized by patient’s own immune system attacking their vital organs such as the kidney and lung. If untreated, patients can die from kidney failure and lung bleeding. The current treatments are consisted with immunosuppressive drugs that carry high toxicity from long-term use and are not always efficacious to prevent relapses. In this project, we will test the hypothesis that complement, a series of proteins in the blood which are normally involved in protecting us from infection, may misdirect its attack on the kidney and lung to cause the pathological symptoms seen in AAV. We will also test several inhibitors of complement in our model to see if they can prevent or reduce kidney and lung injury. These studies may lead to the development of novel therapeutics that are more effective and safer than nonspecific immunosuppressive drugs (e.g. steroids) currently used in human AAV patients with significant side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE STATEMENT Medications for opioid use disorder such as buprenorphine provide an effective treatment option that significantly improves outcomes; however impact is limited by adherence challenges. We propose to develop a novel wearable sensor system, MINDER, which will continuously monitor physiologic changes to detect buprenorphine use and will use machine learning algorithms to accurately identify adherence to buprenorphine use in laboratory and field settings. The results of this study will form the foundation for a wearable, sensor- based, real-time monitoring system for individuals being treated with MOUD, and to develop precision medicine interventions for OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE STATEMENT Innovations in medicine, particularly for diseases that disparately affect minority and underserved populations, are at risk because those entering the biomedical research career path continue to underrepresent certain historically excluded populations. The Duke Paired Undergraduate Mentoring Program (PUMP) in Uronephrology is a sustainable program that will develop a diverse pipeline and enhance success in academic careers by providing mentorship and skills-building, thereby preparing the next generation of scientists to advance urology and nephrology-related disease prevention, treatment, and cure. This program will serve as a model for expanding across disciplines to develop the biomedical workforce and meet the nation’s needs for innovation in medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE These studies will determine the role of TP53 and CDKN2A mutations in promoting malignant progression of oral premalignant lesions and in the response to oral cancer prevention with antibodies that reinvigorate the immune system. We will also investigate novel strategies, based on reactivation of TP53 functions, to sensitize oral premalignant lesions to immunoprevention. Molecular and cellular analyses of the oral lesions that evade immunoprevention will identify mechanisms that promote resistance and will help refine future prevention interventions. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Our lab demonstrated that KRM accelerate cyst growth in multiple animal models of cystic kidney disease and are also present in patients with accelerated rates of renal function decline making KRM- targeted therapeutics highly desirable; however, it is not feasible to give patients resident macrophage targeted inhibitors for long periods as these inhibitors deplete resident macrophages in other tissues where they are needed for basic biological functions. In this application, we seek to identify a tissue specific approach for long- term KRM depletion by studying the mechanism of KRM niche filling after depletion in wild type and cystic mice. If successful, these data would provide a novel approach to target KRM in patients with cystic kidney disease or any other disease that involves KRM including acute kidney injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to investigate how different members of the microbiota, as well as different microbiota compositions affect the virulence of enteric pathogens. This work has fundamental implications for how differential compositions of microbiota may affect disease outcome and susceptibility to pathogens. Defining the mechanisms by which the microbiota affects the regulation and activity of virulence factors expressed by intestinal pathogens would represent a significant step forward in the field of microbiota-pathogen interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The burden placed on family caregivers and the toll on their mental and physical health have never been greater and will continue to rise; by 2026 the number of individuals with cancer is expected to swell to over 20 million and in 2019, the number in the their last year of life was over 600,000. Healthcare clinicians should be concerned with the health of family caregivers for their own sake (e.g. preventing future family caregiver morbidity), but also because these caregivers deliver 80% of the home care to community-dwelling patients with advanced illness. Replacing these services with paid professional help would be economically unfeasible as caregiving services have been valued at $450 billion; thus it is imperative that interventions be developed that keep caregivers healthy and functioning, not only for their own sake, but also so they can provide the best care possible to patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our skin functions as a finely tuned sensory organ that allows us to detect an array of sensory stimuli. The axon endings of somatosensory neurons densely innervate skin where they detect touch, pressure and pain. Specialized skin cells develop during skin organogenesis and influence axon growth, function and repair. To better understand how the skin sensory system develops, this proposal uses zebrafish as an accessible model for studying how specialized sensory cells arise during skin organogenesis, interact with axons and differentiate from stem cell progenitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposed studies will investigate how ezrin, an actin-binding protein, regulates the macrophage immunomodulatory and bactericidal functions during lung infections. The relevance of this study is based on our recent finding that ezrin levels are low in macrophages from individuals with cystic fibrosis, a disease characterized by lung infection and hyper-inflammation. These studies will deepen understanding of MΦ biology and identify potential targets for therapies against lung diseases.

PHR: NARRATIVE Serum biomarker measurements have been widely used as diagnostic indicators, but many markers are not sufficiently sensitive or specific assessments of disease state. We will initially focus this effort on the outstanding need for improved detection of high-grade serous ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The most common cause of death in infants and children admitted to a pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) is neurological system failure and the survivors suffer life-long neuro-morbidities. Our unique program trains MDs, PhDs, and MD/PhDs in basic, translational, or clinical research, from seven departments that treat infants and children who require neurocritical care across the continuum of care, from the field to the emergency department, the PICU, and to rehabilitation and recovery. The goal of our program is that our graduates ultimately develop into independent investigators who are fully equipped to bring their expertise to rigorously and ethically study and successfully develop novel neuroprotective, resuscitative, and regenerative therapies, and improve neuro-outcomes across all of pediatric neurocritical care.
