PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to public health, as the identification of fundamental pathways and novel molecular drivers for treatment-emergent lineage plasticity of prostate cancer and the development of new strategies to combat antiandrogen therapy resistance are expected to unlock the secrets in cancer drug resistance mechanisms, and will therefore yield important opportunities to advance therapeutic options and improve outcomes for the cancer victims. PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed studies is to study the molecular and cellular mechanisms whereby extracellular ERp57 and PDI in concert with their oxidase ERO1α regulate neutrophil adhesive function cooperatively and distinctly, contributing to neutrophil recruitment and tissue damage under inflammatory conditions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The use of personal medical devices (e.g. continuous glucose monitors) by youth with type 1 diabetes as well as their potential to aid children and their caregivers to manage the daily demands of type 1 diabetes and optimize blood sugar control have rapidly expanded over the past twenty years. However, demographic (e.g. race/ethnicity) and socioeconomic (e.g. household income, parental education, and insurance) factors impact access to and continued use of such technology. The goals of this project are to better describe and analyze the interplay of such factors in sustained utilization of CGM in different clinical settings and to characterize their impact on a national level to enable the development and implementation of a pilot study designed to achieve improved equity in continuous glucose monitoring use for pediatric patients with type 1 diabetes.

PHR: Project Narrative The human heart shows little regenerative capacity following an injury such as a heart attack, resulting in decreased cardiac function and increased incidence of heart failure. The proposed work is expected to reveal key regulatory mechanisms by which epicardial cells guide successful heart regeneration in zebrafish. This study will provide novel insights into the natural regenerative capacity of the zebrafish heart and will inform new approaches to promote cardiac repair in heart attack victims.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Viral proteins interact with human proteins to hijack human cells and replicate transmissible viral particles. To learn more about how this process works, this project will screen for protein-protein interactions between viral proteins and human proteins and between viral proteins and other viral proteins. To potentially identify new antiviral drugs, this project will also screen for small molecules that modulate the new protein-protein interactions that are identified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The overall goal of the Inter-collaborative Radiation Countermeasures (INTERACT) Consortium, a newly formed University of Maryland School of Medicine (UMSOM)-based Center for Medical Countermeasures against Radiation (CMCR), is to develop safe, effective, and practical medical countermeasures (MCM) to mitigate and/or treat acute radiation syndrome (ARS) and the delayed effects of acute radiation exposure (DEARE). INTERACT is a partnership of internationally-recognized investigators from four U.S.-based universities who possess a broad depth of expertise in MCM development, a unique set of animal model platforms, and a common goal of sharing ideas and quality practices to advance the cutting-edge scientific discovery and translational development of MCMs. This will be accomplished through partnering with the nation- wide consortium to bring multidisciplinary expertise, advanced capabilities, and wide-ranging resources necessary to strengthen the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)/National Institute of Health (NIH)’s mission to provide safe and effective medical management to victims of a radiological or nuclear incident. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE A deadly lung disease caused by nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM), cousins of the bacterium that causes tuberculosis, is becoming more prevalent worldwide, particularly in aging and immunocompromised individuals, and cystic fibrosis patients. Currently available therapies often fail to achieve cure due to the natural resistance of NTMs to most antibiotics, including rifamycins which show excellent activity against many other bacterial infections. Here we propose to generate new rifamycins that are specifically active against important NTM species to improve the treatment NTM disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: A major signaling molecule for the innate immune system and target of the last-resort antibiotic colistin, lipopolysaccharide is an essential, ubiquitous component of the gram-negative bacterial cell envelope. Despite being implicated in processes ranging from cell envelope permeability to division, the precise contribution of lipopolysaccharide to gram-negative physiology is poorly understood. Applying genetic and cytological approaches, I propose to fill this gap in our understanding of this essential molecule.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) has become a widespread global pandemic. While the primary clinical manifestation of severe COVID-19 is lung failure, complications following acute illness can involve long-term manifestations that are not fully understood. Our work will help expand our understanding of the long-term cardiac effects from severe COVID-19 and their underlying mechanisms, which could help enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability in survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A common type of childhood cancer, acute myelogenous leukemia (AML), affects approximately 500 U.S. children annually, and only about half survive. This project will examine how to target the metabolic dependencies of pediatric AML. Additionally, we will test a well-tolerated drug for incorporation into treatment for pediatric AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the most common genetic kidney disease and the fourth most common cause of end stage renal failure. Tolvaptan, the only FDA-approved drug that is proven to delay the progression of ADPKD, is expensive and is associated with some side effects that may limit its use in some patients. Our overall goal is to understand the metabolic derangement and the underlying molecular mechanism in ADPKD, in order to develop novel therapeutics targeting metabolic pathways to ameliorate ADPKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals who survive a heart attack are at risk for developing heart failure, which affects 6 Million Americans and has a 5 year mortality rate over 40%. Fibroblasts, a type of cell found in the heart, become activated after a heart attack and long-term activation of these cells contributes to heart failure progression. Preventing prolonged fibroblast activation may enable us to develop new therapies to treat heart failure.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is the most common cause of multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS), and sepsis-induced MODS is a leading cause of prolonged hospitalization and death for children. We previously found that children with prolonged MODS also have persistent immune cell mitochondrial dysfunction. Through the proposed study, we will now determine if mechanisms that normally restore and maintain mitochondrial health are abnormal in children with prolonged sepsis-induced MODS, leading to persistent mitochondrial dysfunction that then sustains inflammation and increases severity and duration of organ dysfunction.

PHR: Project Narrative Plant natural products and plant natural product-derived drugs have been indispensible towards the treatment of different diseases and the prophylactic maintenance of healthy lifestyle. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure remains the foremost barrier to human health and wellness, contributing to more deaths and morbidity than almost any other disease. This debilitating and progressive disease is worsened by chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the heart but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood, preventing development of new therapies. Our proposal seeks to elucidate a new mechanism of how cardiac macrophages expressing the receptor CX3CR1 can resolve chronic inflammation and limit fibrosis, thus preventing heart failure and potentially improving outcomes for patients with many types of cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This prospective cohort study aims to characterize Veterans’ experiences with, and outcomes following, discontinuation of long-term opioid therapy. Results from this study will provide VA operations administrators, hospital executives, and clinicians with information that characterizes opioid discontinuation from patients’ perspectives. These perspectives can inform best practices for discontinuing opioid therapy, when clinically indicated, while simultaneously mitigating negative consequences of discontinuation and engaging and empowering patients to manage chronic pain with evidence-based non-opioid treatment modalities available within VA and in the community. Such approaches are highly consistent with patient-centered care paradigms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Genomic diagnostics relies on the accurate interpretation of genetic variation to disease causation, which can be hampered by the large predominance of Variants of Uncertain Significance (VOUS) identified in many disease genes as well as variable expressivity, a hallmark feature of many genetic diseases. We will work to resolve both types of uncertainty for the autosomal dominant disorder, Alagille syndrome, which is caused by mutations in JAG1 and NOTCH2. We have developed an innovative, high-throughput assay to resolve missense variant classification, and we will utilize transcriptomics to better understand genotype- phenotype relationships that will ultimately provide guidance to clinicians and geneticists and develop tools and techniques that we can apply to other disease genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and human metapneumovirus (hMPV) are two closely related viruses that cause thousands of deaths and hundreds of thousands of hospitalizations worldwide each year. There are no approved vaccines for either virus, although pre-fusion-stabilized RSV fusion (F) proteins have shown great promise in clinical trials. This proposal will determine if a chimeric F protein bearing immunodominant epitopes of both RSV and hMPV F proteins is protective in several animal infection models of RSV and hMPV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: BK virus is a common infection of immune-suppressed kidney transplant patients, leading in some cases to loss of the transplanted kidney. There is no effective anti-viral against BK virus and the standard practice is to reduce immunosuppression, which can itself lead to kidney rejection; hence the management of immunosuppression of these patients is very challenging. We propose to use existing data sets from NIH- funded transplantation clinical trials to develop mathematical models and optimal control algorithms of the dynamic interactions between the virus, the immune systems, and the transplanted kidney and to build a software tool for personalized immunosuppression in these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer is a lethal malignancy that often begins in the fallopian tubes with serous tubal intraepithelial carcinoma (STIC) and recent work has demonstrated that the presence of STICs is associated with a high risk for primary peritoneal cancer, an ovarian cancer related malignancy. Currently there are few biomarkers for STIC or early ovarian cancer, nor are there consensus guidelines for how to best care for patients with STIC, and we therefore propose to characterize cellular and molecular features of healthy fallopian tubes, STIC and invasive cancer. Our goal is to identify markers in STICs that are indicative of high risk for invasion and possible primary peritoneal cancer so these patients can be selected to undergo more aggressive surveillance or treatment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have discovered a process in the myofibroblasts that may cause the cells to grow quickly after a heart attack. By shutting off this process, we can not only block the cells from growing too quickly but also make them help repair the heart to help it pump stronger.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly half of all hospitalized patients with Alzheimer's Disease and Alzheimer's Disease Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) develop delirium superimposed on dementia (DSD), which is associated with not only significant morbidity and mortality for patients but also considerable suffering for family caregivers. Integration of family members into delirium identification and prevention efforts is feasible and can improve outcomes, but these efforts (including their impact on caregiver outcomes) have not been adequately examined in DSD identification and prevention. The proposed study will examine DSD communication practices/gaps and develop a patient, family caregiver, and clinician-informed communication and engagement care model for collaborative DSD identification and prevention using intervention mapping, a framework to develop theory and evidence-based health interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is among the most lethal of human cancers (currently the 3rd leading cause of cancer death in the US), and existing therapies confer unsatisfactory clinical responses. The tumor microenvironment (TME) of PDAC is among the most inhospitable of any cancer type, and the ability of pancreatic tumor cells to survive and grow under these conditions likely contributes to their recalcitrant behavior. The main goals of our proposal are to define the molecular mechanisms by which PDAC cells adapt to these nutrient- and oxygen-deprived (“arid”) environments, determine how such environments affect interactions between tumor cells and other cells making up the TME, and to identify drug vulnerabilities that can be exploited for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The epithelial cells that line the intestinal tract each build hundreds of finger-like protrusions referred to as ‘microvilli’, which extend into the gut lumen. Although microvilli are essential for nutrient absorption and other aspects of intestinal physiology, there is little information on mechanisms that control their growth. The proposed studies will elucidate molecular pathways that lead to the assembly of these protrusions during intestinal epithelial cell differentiation and thus may provide insight on the basis of human diseases characterized by loss of microvilli.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: O-GlcNAcylation is dysregulated in many neurological diseases and metabolic disorders and rapidly modulates GABAAR currents in the hippocampus. Understanding whether O-GlcNAc mediated depression of GABAergic transmission changes in the presence of phosphorylation or a drug of abuse will provide insight on potential therapeutic strategies that can target synaptic dysfunction. Because of this, we propose that an acute increase in O-GlcNAcylation will dictate the polarity of phosphorylation and allosteric modulators on GABAAR function, while a decrease in O-GlcNAcylation can restore inhibition in a disease model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Our sense of hearing relies on the survival of a limited number of inner ear sensory cells throughout our entire lifetime. This project will provide clues about the molecular machinery regulating the stability and shape of the inner ear sensory organelles known as stereocilia. The identification of these molecular players might uncover novel therapeutic targets to maintain the integrity of stereocilia in some types of congenital or noise-induced hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This project seeks to: 1) define the role of primary sensory cortical neurons in the initiation of movement, 2) determine the anatomical and functional integrity of the SI locomotor pathway, and 3) examine the therapeutic efficacy of modulating this newly characterized pathway for restoring walking after spinal cord injury (SCI). State- of-the-art cellular-specific optical imaging, optogenetics, and electrophysiology in freely behaving mice combined with viral tracing methods and chemogenetic neuromodulation will accomplish this proposal's objectives. Overall, a greater understanding of the anatomical organization and the functional significance of this novel sensory cortical-locomotor pathway will facilitate the development of new strategies to restore movement after SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Statement Allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) is an increasingly prevalent lifesaving treatment option for hematologic cancer patients. After HCT, patients and their family caregivers must work together as a team to adhere to the complex post-HCT medical regimen, which is critical for good patient health outcomes. The proposed work is a refinement and test of a novel, brief Problem-Solving Intervention to improve patient-family caregiver team management of the medical regimen and thus improve patient and family caregiver emotional well-being and health-related quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal pursues to understand how membrane proteins are selectively distributed to different compartments in heart muscle cells, so that they can perform specific functions in control and diseased hearts in both sexes. The potential positive impact of these studies is to gain new knowledge of how heart muscle cells normally produce and ship proteins, communicate with each other, how such processes go wrong in heart diseases in both sexes, and how to design new drugs targeting the selective shipment of these proteins to relieve adverse symptoms of heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Significance of the proposed research During early embryonic brain morphogenesis, development of a single neuron begins with the establishment of axon and dendrite identities, an architecture that is critical for the directed information flow in the brain. Aberrations affecting dendrite development lead to developmental neuropathologies, including intellectual and motor disabilities, epilepsy, autism spectrum disorders, and neuropsychiatric disorders. Using state of the art approaches, cutting edge genetic manipulations, optogenetic activation of second messenger signaling, and lifetime decay FLIM-FRET in vivo measurements, this proposal examines the molecular mechanisms of apical dendrite development in pyramidal neurons in the developing mouse embryonic brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Intact cognitive skills are necessary for independent living, going to work, and managing finances, and any loss of cognitive skills places a burden on society akin to what is seen with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias. The TelePORT Study (Telehealth-Enhanced Patient-Oriented Recovery Trajectories after Intensive Care) is the first post-intensive care syndrome longitudinal long-term cognitive impairment intervention study. The societal effect from long-term cognitive impairment after critical illness is great as many of these patients are employable adults or functional retirees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project addresses barriers to the development of effective therapies for debilitating and costly falls in parkinsonism, and directly aligns with the NIH Brain Initiative goal to image and modulate human brain circuitry. This study investigates the role of non-invasive repetitive cerebellar transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) for postural instability in PSP, a parkinsonian disorder featuring early and severe balance deficits and falls. Cerebellar neuromodulation will inform our understanding of neural pathways involved in postural instability, a debilitating parkinsonian symptom that is refractory to current therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Lower urinary tract dysfunction (LUTD) is nearly ubiquitous in men of advancing age and involves a dynamic interplay among prostate, bladder and urethra. The cellular and molecular mechanisms that regulate prostate enlargement and detrusor dysfunction are largely unknown and appropriate mouse models to study the function of individual cell types in the lower urinary tract are lacking. The foundational human tissue and data resource generated here will lead to new testable hypotheses and the development of more effective medications.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  With the rising incidence of stroke and rapidly growing medical costs, more effective and efficient rehabili- tation is crucial to handle the increasing burden on our healthcare system. Robotic assistive devices, such as the Barrett Upper-Extremity Robotic Trainer (Burt®), can provide effective, repeatable treatment while reducing the burden on therapists. To improve patient engagement and provide more effective therapy while lightening the load on the therapist, we aim to develop new Burt® SmartAssist™ functionality, a combination of a new adaptive assistance method for the Burt® robot, an intuitive path specification interface, and advanced data visualization features to help therapists take full advantage of the system’s capabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL PROGRAM PROJECT NARRATIVE The release of IL-1β and the fiery cell death called “pyroptosis” that accompanies this release underlies much of the pathophysiology of inflammatory disease. This Program Project aims to better understand the cellular and biochemical mechanisms governing both canonical and non-canonical pathways for IL-1β secretion, their integration with different modes of regulated cell death, and their links to the pathogenesis of Inflammatory Bowel Diseases (IBD) and Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Lay Summary Throughout human history, infectious diseases and inflammatory such as the flu or cold viruses or stomach bugs, have been drivers of human evolution. These threats are so dangerous that humans have evolved redundant mechanisms to neutralize them. The Gasdermin family of proteins helps drive inflammation in the face of these threats. Despite this, little is known about Gasdermin family redundancy, the mechanisms by which Gasdermin family members are regulated and Gasdermin family members role in normal blood cell development. This grant application aims to study these important problems in the context of inflammatory disease.

PHR: Project Narrative: Maintaining energy and fluid homeostasis is critical. Disruptions in energy homeostasis cause malnutrition or obesity, and failure to defend fluid homeostasis causes dehydration or hypertension. A better understanding of the relevant circuits can help lead to treatments for disorders of energy balance, such as obesity and diabetes, and can provide targets for understanding and preventing disorders of fluid balance such as dehydration or hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE / Public Health Relevance Despite their granulocytic similarities which distinguish them from other myeloid leukocytes, neutrophils, mast cells and eosinophils play non-redundant roles in innate immunity and immune homeostasis. This project will define how these non-redundant functions involve alternative mechanisms of IL-1β production, GSDM family expression and subcellular trafficking, and regulated cell death. The results of these studies will define novel mechanisms for how GSDMD and GSDME mediate granulocyte-specific immune signaling responses which play critical physiological roles during acute infection/tissue damage but contribute to tissue dysfunction in humans with common autoimmune, allergic, or chronic inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Carbon monoxide (CO) gas has been identified as an essential signaling molecule in the human neuronal system and has been shown to have many therapeutic applications. Molecules that create CO gas upon activation with an external stimulus are commonly dubbed CO releasing molecules, or CORMs, and have shown to be vital tool in studying the effect of CO in biological systems. This research proposes to create a new class of CORMs based on organic molecules that efficiently produce CO gas, are directly polymerizable, and have predictable and well-defined products following the release of CO, attributes not currently accessible with state-of-the-art CORMs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance Inflammasomes play important roles in immune defense against infections and autoimmune/autoinflammatory disorders such as inflammatory bowel disease, multiple sclerosis, and Alzheimer’s disease. Activation of the inflammasomes lead to maturation and secretion of proinflammatory cytokines and pyroptosis, a highly inflammatory form of cell death that triggers cytolysis accompanied by cytokine release. Intriguingly, pyroptosis- and membrane pore-independent function of GSDMD in secretion of cytokines has been demonstrated in neutrophils, epithelial cells, and T cells. The goal of this proposal is to probe mechanisms for pyroptosis- dependent and novel pyroptosis-independent release of proinflammatory cytokines mediated by GSDMD. The outcome will not only provide novel insights into lytic and non-lytic cytokine release, but may also stimulate the development of therapeutics that target inflammatory disorders.!

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Narrative We have discovered that triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells overexpress the enzyme RNase H2, enabling them to overcome excessive replication stress and survive. Based on this unique feature, we have further demonstrated that RNase H2 inhibition can effectively kill TNBC cells both in vitro and in vivo. The goal of this study is to build on this knowledge to develop novel and effective RNase H2 inhibition-based monotherapy and combination therapy to cure TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance  About 1.3 million people suffer from inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) in the United States. With cause of the  disease still elusive, there is currently no cure or preventive measure for the condition. Interluekin-1β (IL-1β) is  a potent pro-inflammatory soluble protein that is highly upregulated in the inflamed intestinal tissues in patients  with Ulcerative Colitis and Crohn’ Disease. It is currently unclear how IL-1β is released by various cell types in  the intestine. In this application, we propose to delineate the biochemical events-mediated by Gasdermin D, a  novel protein participating in driving IL-1 β production and intestinal inflammation. Completion of this project will  provide novel therapeutic strategies to break the pathogenic cross-talk between immune and structural cells and  terminate the non-resolving inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease is a debilitating disorder that exerts a substantial and growing impact on public health in the context of an aging population. A sizeable body of research has demonstrated that sleep problems, particularly daytime sleepiness and obstructive sleep apnea, increase the risk of developing Alzheimer's disease pathology and dementia in later life. This project will identify specific and objective measures of diminished daytime alertness that are associated with increased risk of Alzheimer's disease pathology and cognitive decline, which will be a critical advance, allowing those at greatest risk for Alzheimer's disease to be more readily identified so targeted therapies and prevention strategies can be employed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is a genetic kidney disease that results in formation of multiple fluid filled kidney cyst that leads to loss of kidney function. We found that a high animal based protein diet fed PKD mice resulted in rapid cystic kidney disease progression through impairing a cellular component called mitochondria and increased a group of blood cells that protects us from fighting infection, called macrophages. Rapid cyst growth was mitigated when mice were fed a plant-based (wheat-gluten) protein diet. The most abundant amino acid in the casein compared to wheat-gluten diet is lysine. This proposal will determine whether specific content within the animal based protein, lysine, impairs the mitochondrial function, activate macrophages and accelerates kidney cyst growth in PKD mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because we aim to improve prognostication for patients with advanced cancer by developing frameworks to integrate clinician intuition with machine learning algorithm- based mortality risk predictions (“human-machine collaborations”), a critical step to better identify patients who may benefit from earlier advance care planning and palliative care. This research proposal will optimize an existing machine learning mortality risk prediction algorithm and methodologically assess strategies to present machine learning estimates to clinicians in order to increase prognostic accuracy, advance care planning, and palliative care among patients with advanced cancer. The project is relevant to the NCI's mission by generating fundamental knowledge to inform clinicians, researchers, and policymakers about effective methods to improve and integrate predictive algorithms into clinical practice, thereby allowing better targeting of evidence-based interventions to improve quality of life for patients with advanced cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE STATEMENT Smoke exposure in early life is a significant public health concern because it may predispose smoke-exposed children to substance use and other behavior problems. This study examines youths’ abilities to control their emotions and behavior as pathways that may lead to unhealthy outcomes for smoke-exposed children. The work conducted here may reduce the public health impact of early smoke exposure by identifying targets for prevention and intervention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic human fungal pathogen that is ubiquitous in the environment and is an important cause of disease for patients with HIV/AIDS, other autoimmune diseases, and solid organ transplants. The standard model for the study and treatment of cryptococcal disease assumes that infections are caused by a sin- gle strain or genotype but our preliminary studies demonstrate that mixed-strain Crypto- coccus infections are common among a patient population drawn from the southeastern United States. This research will advance public health by estimating the frequency and genetic structure of mixed Cryptococcus infections, identifying environmental lineages of Cryptococcus that contribute to mixed infections, and characterizing epidemiological correlates and health outcomes associated with mixed infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Relevance: We have found that antiviral lymphocytes reliably fuse with CNS resident astrocytes following viral brain infection and this proposal will determine the kinetics and longevity of fusion formation upon CNS infection. We will determine whether T cell/astrocyte fusion is a general feature of the CNS immune response using a variety of viruses with different cellular tropisms and test the requirement astrocyte antigen presentation in the fusion process. Finally, we will profile the transcriptomic changes these hybrid astrocytes undergo upon T cell fusion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke and traumatic brain injury are leading causes of disability associated to neurovascular impairments and increased cognitive decline. Glial cells are in close contact with the vasculature and after neurovascular injury, release pro-inflammatory cytokines that can be detrimental to neuronal survival. Understanding the signaling mechanisms of vascular-glial communication will advance the discovery of novel targets to prevent neurodegeneration followed by brain vascular injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative Use of some antibiotics, antihistamines, and anti-arrhythmia drugs (among others) are approved at limited doses because of a side effect called acquired long Q-T syndrome (aLQTS), which predisposes to a ventricular arrhythmia that causes sudden death. The present research aims at developing drug candidates, which can lead to effective and safe therapies to prevent aLQTS. Success in this endeavor would expand the therapeutic dose range of existing drugs, and permit promising new drugs to reach the marketplace.

PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research evaluates a park-level intervention to increase moderate/vigorous physical activity and decrease sedentary time among low-income diverse children ages 6-12 yrs. A two-arm group randomized trial will randomize 24 parks for a 24 month period to compare an intervention that combines youth sports park program fee waiver plus intensive outreach versus usual outreach and usual program fee structure on changes in child physical activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Short sleep duration confers high cardiovascular and metabolic risk, but lifestyle factors and molecular mechanisms that contribute to increased blood pressure and poor glucose control during short sleep are not completely understood. Habitual short sleepers are constantly eating, the proposed studies will evaluate if this behavior contributes to heightened cardiovascular and metabolic risk, and will examine if this may be related to eating during night. Our study will identify restricted eating duration (8 hours/day) as a potential way to improve cardiovascular and metabolic health in habitual short sleepers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Gadolinium based contrast agents (GBCAs) are used with MRI to detect and stage cancers and other diseases and to guide treatment. However there are safety concerns about the potentially toxic gadolinium metal ion. We have invented a gadolinium-free contrast agent to replace GBCAs. The goal of this proposal is to test the safety and imaging efficacy of this new agent RVP-001 in patients with brain cancer or other brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a leading cause death and long-term disability however, differing recovery outcomes have been observed between male and female children. Although these differences in recovery have been associated with basic patient factors (e.g., age, sex), current prognostic models fail to fully account for these variances in TBI recovery. As such, this proposal will utilize a representative piglet TBI model to further understand the effects of sexually dimorphic neuroanatomical structures on changes in cellular processes, functional neural networks reorganization, and cognitive, behavioral, and motor function post-TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Non-typhoidal Salmonella serotypes are the single most common cause of death from diarrheal disease associated with viruses, parasites or bacteria and the leading cause of foodborne disease outbreaks in the United States, producing between $0.5 billion to $2.3 billion in annual costs for medical care and lost productivity. The most common human clinical isolate is Salmonella enterica serotypes Typhimurium (S. Typhimurium). Research proposed in this application will support pioneering studies on molecular mechanisms that control the balance between the pathogen, the host and its microbiota. The proposed studies will drive knowledge about Salmonella gastroenteritis to a higher level by providing critical new insights into pathogenesis and mechanisms that enable the pathogen to overcome colonization resistance mediated by the gut microbiota.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm infants who are mechanically ventilated face increased risk of developing brain injury and neurodevelopmental problems, but we do not understand the link between mechanical ventilation and increased risk of brain injury in preterm newborns. The goal of this proposal is to test the hypothesis that mechanical ventilation causes pulmonary cells to release vesicles that penetrate the brain and induce brain cell death. If we can understand what is causing brain cell death in mechanically ventilated preterm newborns, we may be able to develop therapeutic strategies to improve the neurodevelopmental outcomes of these vulnerable infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Studies in mice and humans highlight the importance of antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC) in the prevention of herpes simplex virus infections. The goal of this application is to isolate and characterize monoclonal antibodies elicited by DgD-2, a novel candidate vaccine, with this protective activity and to define the role HVEM signaling pathways play in generating these IgG subclass switched ADCC antibodies. The results obtained will have broad implications and accelerate the development of strategies to bolster vaccine and monoclonal antibody efficacy against a range of pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our laboratory uses high throughput chemical screening combined with modern target identification techniques to identify novel small molecules with physiological activity. This approach results in pharmacologically privileged mechanistic information and often the chemical starting points for drug development campaigns. This work will principally focus on three key areas: identifying compounds to promote regenerative organ repair, developing small molecule activators of transcriptional stress responses, and advancing methodology to identify small molecules with novel reactivity and/or biological activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Latently infected CD4+ T cells are considered to be the most important HIV reservoir preventing the implementation of an HIV cure, however, myeloid cells have been shown to be infected by HIV/SIV and to establish latency in animal models. Therefore, elimination of the T cell reservoir alone is not likely to result in complete virus eradication. Our long-term goal is to aid the development of effective HIV cure strategies by gaining a better understanding of the type and location of the cells in the brain that harbor replication-competent HIV under ART suppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-typhoidal Salmonella enterica is a leading cause of bacterial foodborne gastroenteritis and causes the most deaths of any foodborne pathogen in the United States. Here, we will explore how Salmonella regulates its response to sulfite stress produced by the innate immune system. Since sulfites are antibacterial reactive sulfur species with widespread availability in the host, our work will lead to new therapeutic strategies to combat Salmonella infections.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Placental dysfunction, in particular changes in placental nutrient delivery, contributes to many important pregnancy complications and has been linked to disease in childhood and in adult life. Very little information is available on placental phospholipid synthesis or the role of these lipids in regulating placental function and delivering essential lipids to the fetus. We expect that the results from the proposed work will ultimately lead to new understanding of the causes for placental dysfunction in pregnancies complicated by growth restriction, and maternal diabetes and could help to improve life long health of children whose development was affected by these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Justification (Project Narrative) Deciphering the interactions of microbes with each other and their host habitats is essential for understanding the oral microbiome's role in health and disease and for developing preventive and therapeutic strategies. Currently, we lack sufficient understanding of why bacteria live where they do in the mouth—such as on teeth, tongue or gums--to accomplish these goals. This proposal will close that knowledge gap using bioinformatic tools and in-depth analysis to establish a genomic, ecologic framework that will eventually enable clinicians to treat oral diseases through knowledge-based manipulation of bacterial composition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative We use the interface of aging and breast cancer in older women to inform geroscience and Alzheimer’s disease- related dementias (ADRD). We propose to use data from our older breast cancer survivors and non-cancer controls to elucidate the role of biological aging in cognitive and physical declines, and examine the role of sleep in these relationships. This clinical translational project addresses key NIA priority areas and will provide important data to inform future ADRD studies and interventions to improve health and resilience of our aging population.

PHR: Title: Targeting NQO1+ tumor to trigger innate and adaptive immunity  Project Narrative Defective innate sensing in tumor microenvironment (TME) might contribute to checkpoint blockade resistance.  In  a  new  study,  we  will  demonstrate  that  a  tumor- targeting  prodrug  triggers  tumor- selective  innate  sensing  to  overcome  checkpoint  blockade  resistance  and  bridge  innate  and  adaptive  immunity.  This  prodrug  will  be  bioactivated  by  tumor- enriched  enzyme  and  overcome  immunotherapy  resistance  and  eradicate  well-   established and checkpoint blockade refractory tumors. This study implicates that proper innate sensing inside  TME might synergize with T- cell- dependent immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) survivors experience tremendous psychological symptoms (e.g., anxiety and depression symptoms), low levels of positive psychological well-being (e.g., flourishing, gratitude), and diminished quality of life (QOL) in the setting of high rates of treatment-related toxicities, a prolonged recovery with a substantial risk of life-threatening complications, and long-term morbidity and mortality. However, scalable psychosocial interventions tailored to the unique needs of HSCT survivors which focus on psychological well-being holistically (i.e., incorporate positive psychological skills and can buffer against distress) are lacking. To address these gaps, the proposed trial assesses the efficacy of a positive psychology intervention (PATH) in HSCT survivors for improving anxiety and depression symptoms and QOL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE 30-50% of cancer survivors who have completed treatment with curative intent have untreated insomnia, and cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is a first line, evidence-based treatment. In response to PAR-21- 341, this resubmission aims to optimize synchronous, virtual CBT-I for cancer survivors (Survivorship Sleep Program; SSP) in a 2x2 factorial trial (N=80 cancer survivors with insomnia) by evaluating 2 intervention design components [delivery (individual vs. group) and booster sessions (0 vs. 3)] on the primary outcome (change in insomnia severity from baseline to 1-month surveillance/booster), explore study participation and sleep outcomes by race and by ethnicity using feasibility benchmarks established in our previous pilot trial, and characterize the acceptability of the SSP design components via exit interviews to characterize preferences, challenges, and future intervention delivery considerations. Bolstered by support from our community partnerships, this project will yield multiple deliverables to innovate cancer survivorship care, chiefly an optimized, scalable, virtually-delivered intervention that addresses chronic insomnia, one of the most deleterious concerns among the growing, and racially and ethnically diverse, demographic of cancer survivors in the U.S, and will inform a future R01 efficacy trial and future considerations for delivering CBT-I to cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tens of thousands of Veterans survive critical illness annually, only to experience profound and often persistent impairments in physical function for months to years later that lead to disability and poor quality of life. Little is known, however, about the mechanisms and biological basis of physical recovery, inhibiting efforts to improve outcomes. This study will enroll 62 Veterans who survive an admission to the intensive care unit (ICU) and characterize mitochondrial function in these patients using novel metabolic imaging methods (31- phosphorus magnetic resonance spectroscopy) and blood-based biomarkers to determine the association with physical recovery up to 6 months after critical illness. This knowledge gained from this proposal will pave the way for new rehabilitation and intervention strategies to restore function and quality of life after the ICU.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  There is a national shortage of qualified clinician-scientists with the skills to conduct the rigorous clinical research needed to address the most vexing population-based questions in neurology. Leveraging the efforts of a distinguished, experienced, and committed training program faculty, a rigorous curriculum of both didactic training and mentored research, and a world-class biomedical research environment, this training program provides trainees with the skills needed to design, conduct, and complete high-quality epidemiologic research in clinical neurology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In South Africa, women with HIV (WWH) are at a dramatically elevated risk for cervical cancer, which is preventable through timely screening and treatment of precancerous lesions; however, screening via Pap smears is only effective if women are retained in care, and unacceptably high rates of WWH with abnormal Pap smears are lost to follow-up. This study will (1) explore the barriers and facilitators to follow-up appointment attendance and subsequent treatment among WWH with a recent high-risk abnormal Pap smear and their providers; (2) develop a multi-level intervention to increase follow-up appointment attendance and subsequent treatment; and (3) evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention in a pilot randomized trial. If feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy are demonstrated, then the intervention will be ready for large- scale efficacy/effectiveness testing, with the ultimate goal of decreasing the incidence of cervical cancer among WWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Three sentences. Damage to the spinal cord doesn’t heal because regrowth of injured axons is limited by the lack of growth capacity of adult neurons and by the inhibitory environment in the injury site. We use rodent models to test controlled delivery of treatments to promote axonal regeneration after injury avoiding off-target effects and study the role of the inhibitory environment when injured axons are prompted to grow. These studies are relevant as they could open the field to explore combinatorial strategies to promote optimal axonal regrowth after spinal cord injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance Nearly half of all childhood cancers occur in children under 5 years of age who are at greatest cognitive risk due to a rapidly developing brain and treatment-related disruption to the early learning environment; yet, there are no studies of cognitive interventions targeting young children undergoing cancer treatment. Studies have shown caregiver education regarding the importance of the early learning environment on child brain development combined with interactive neurodevelopmental games designed to strengthen brain pathways for specific skills, at times when the pathways are particularly sensitive to life experiences, are associated with improvement in parent-child interactions and child problem solving skills. If caregiver education combined with interactive neurodevelopmental games are shown to promote cognitive and social-emotional development in infants undergoing medulloblastoma treatment, there is great potential for reducing cognitive morbidity and improving quality of life for the entire population of young children undergoing cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will systematically characterize the properties and mechanisms underlying the influx pathway of cochlear aqueduct and how age may alter its function in mice. The studies will address key gaps in our understanding of the cochlear aqueduct and will use the most sensitive pre-clinical MRI and laser capture microscopy coupled to single cell sequencing technologies to investigate an unexplored area in auditory research. The results from this project will establish a fundamental basis for understanding the CA as a passage route to and from the cochlea and its use for pre- clinical delivery strategies to treat cochlear disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: There are currently no treatments that reverse disability or repair cortical demyelinating lesions in progressive multiple sclerosis (MS). Cortical microglia respond to demyelination, but it is not well-understood how microglia later contribute to myelin and oligodendrocyte replacement. This proposal will provide a fundamental understanding of the relationship between cortical microglia and oligodendrocytes, that will drive future therapeutic remyelination strategies.

STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Cellular and Molecular Biology of Glia Study Section[CMBG]

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Approximately 42,000 Veterans are living with chronic spinal cord injury (SCI) in the United States. SCI often leads to an extremely sedentary lifestyle and marked bone loss that is associated with an increased life-long risk of fractures, morbidity, and financial burden. To date, there is no practical approach to safely and efficaciously treat osteoporosis and bone fractures in Veterans with chronic SCI. This study will test if a novel agent, an antibody against a bone cell receptor (Siglec-15) with unique bone-preserving and bone-building activity, can safely improve skeletal integrity, strength, and fracture healing in a preclinical model of chronic SCI and severe bone loss below the level of lesion. The proposed study will clarify basic mechanisms of novel processes that control bone cell function, thereby improving efforts to reverse SCI-related deterioration of bone. If successful, the proposed treatment can be swiftly deployed in a clinical trial and, ultimately, to clinical care with greater promise to improve skeletal health in Veterans with chronic SCI than that of currently available treatment options.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: All manual lifting and repositioning techniques have a high-risk for injury to caregivers. Work-related back pain and injuries are a widespread epidemic, and due in large part to repeated patient handling activities, including lifting, transferring, and repositioning tasks. Research has shown that mechanical lift technologies reduce the risk of injuries, but people with mobility impairments and caregivers both desire new, powered devices for safer, more comfortable, and independent transfers. The goals of this project are to iteratively design, prototype and test a modified AgileLife Powered Personal Transfer System and a compatible group 3 power wheelchair to allow the ‘no lift’ system to be used independently by wheelchair users.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Compromised hand function due to stroke and spinal cord injury is a leading cause of disability among U.S. Veterans and the broader population. There is growing evidence that pairing stimulation of the vagus nerve with task repetition during rehabilitation can enhance relearning of motor functions compromised by neurological injury. Implantable vagus nerve stimulators require medical procedures that are invasive and costly, but there is evidence to support that the vagus nerve can be accessed with electrical currents applied to different locations on the external ear. Which location to target is not well understood, and the intensity and timing of stimulation needed to achieve therapeutic effects remain unresolved. This project examines whether a noninvasive approach to vagus nerve stimulation enhances motor learning and addresses practical considerations, such as where and how to stimulate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: We propose a highly coordinated and synergistic Center that will develop end-to-end approaches and generalizable methods for designing potently protective vaccines against paramyxoviruses and bunyaviruses. Our Center brings together groups with world-leading expertise in computational protein design, structure-based vaccine design, mRNA vaccines, structural biology, viral entry, viral diversity and evolution, animal model development, high biosafety-level containment virology, vaccinology, and vaccine process development and technology transfer. Our Center will generate new knowledge, tools, and generalizable vaccine design approaches that will significantly advance vaccine development for pandemic preparedness generally, and will have a direct impact on public health through the development of antibody and vaccine candidates for several paramyxoviruses and bunyaviruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Injury to axons in the central and peripheral nervous systems can have devastating consequences, often resulting in paralysis due to limited axon regeneration. Glia are critical for promoting axon regeneration – creating a permissive environment by clearing axonal and glial debris or inhibiting regeneration by releasing debris into the environment – but the mechanisms of glial adaptation to the stress of axon injury are unclear. In this proposal, I will identify the molecular and cellular basis of a novel glial recovery response to axon injury and its necessity in promotion of subsequent axon regeneration.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed United States Zimbabwe Research Ethics Training Program (US-Zim RETP) is to develop the capacity for research ethics education, training, and ethics research in Zimbabwe. The US-Zim RETP is proposed as an innovative and sustainable Research Ethics Education training program. The program aims to enhance the pedagogical and curricular strengths of key University of Zimbabwe Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences (UZFMHS) to deliver research ethics courses and mentoring in Zimbabwe; develop and implement a 2 year Master’s level degree in research ethics at the UZFMHS; and to promote key priorities around research ethics in Zimbabwe.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans are most likely to disclose suicidal thoughts to their close supports such as family and friends. These loved ones are, in turn, very interested in learning how to help a Veteran in need. Close supports are uniquely poised to provide a meaningful contribution to suicide prevention, if they can learn how to effectively promote Veterans' connection to care. VA S.A.V.E. (Signs; Ask; Validate; Encourage and Expedite) is a suicide prevention gatekeeper training specifically tailored to the Veteran community that teaches close supports how to identify signs of suicide risk and how to connect the at-risk person to professional treatment. The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of VA S.A.V.E. and to explore factors impacting its potential widespread implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our objective is to determine if angiotensin-receptor blockers (ARBs) can enhance T cell infiltration into breast tumors and if this enhancement, when combined with cancer immunotherapy, can effectively reduce breast cancer progression. To accomplish this, we will measure T cell infiltration and function directly in mouse breast cancer models and we will also evaluate human breast cancer tissue samples to explore the potential synergy between ARBs and cancer immunotherapy. This research is of critical importance, considering the alarming annual toll of over 40,000 American lives claimed by breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will characterize the phenotypic nature of cognitive dysfunction in fibromyalgia (FM) using a combination of self-report and objective measures of cognition, complemented by neurophysiological (EEG) and functional magnetic resonance (fMRI) outcomes. Cognitive symptoms are one of the most debilitating aspects of FM, are poorly understood and thus poorly managed, and are present in a wide range of chronic pain conditions beyond FM. Therefore, this project addresses a critical practical challenge that has applications for the improved healthcare management of a broad range of patients suffering from chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our team proposes to collect data from a large sample of people who experience hallucinations using smartphone behavioral measurement tools. With the aid of innovative computational modelling strategies, these data will be used to develop “clinical signatures” that indicate which individuals are at heightened risk for severe outcomes such as hospitalization and suicide. If successful, these measures and models can be used to guide scalable clinical decision making, resource allocation, treatment, and impactful prevention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this project is to investigate the ethical questions that arise during the return of individual research results to participants involved in housing exposure studies. It will result in Household Exposure Results Report-Back (HERRB) guidelines, informed by participants in prior research studies and by diverse stakeholders. These guidelines will build the ethical competency of housing exposure researchers as they work to responsibly return results to participants in ways that build trust and support action by individuals and communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Neuropathic pain is a debilitating chronic pain condition that affects 6-8% of adults, the majority of whom do not adequately respond to currently available treatment options. We aim to establish a multidisciplinary team of scientists with expertise in pain biology, medicinal and computational chemistry, structural biology, pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, and translational pain research, and create the appropriate infrastructure for the development of novel non-opioid, 5-HT3 receptor antagonists for the treatment of neuropathic pain.

PHR: Project Narrative The Mary H. Weiser Food Allergy Center and the closely associated Allergy and Clinical Immunology Division in Internal Medicine are submitting this application for a CoFAR clinical research center. The application is in three parts: Part A describes the extensive clinical/clinical research capabilities of the Center. Part B outlines a consortium-wide study project that investigates a new and potentially safer way to diagnose food allergy. Part C describes a local study that seeks to evaluate the unique genetic basis for the closely related disorders of food allergy and atopic dermatitis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Smoking cessation among Veterans with chronic medical illnesses substantially decreases morbidity and mortality; however, many patients (>50%) with chronic pain continue to smoke and experience more barriers to smoking cessation. In a recently completed comparative effectiveness trial (IIR15-092), we compared a standard smoking cessation protocol (including pharmacotherapy) to a cognitive behavioral intervention (CBI) integrating an evidence-based smoking cessation intervention with a pain self-management intervention among Veterans with chronic pain. Though this intervention was significant (and promising), high rates of depressive symptoms were observed that may have interfered with optimal effectiveness. This proposal combines the established effectiveness of a CBI with the use of an Interactive Voice Response (IVR) system to enhance the effectiveness of the intervention in those without depression by allowing patients to interact with a computer-operated phone system and receive feedback to reinforce CBI skills, motivation, and self-monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Genome architecture deteriorates during aging contributing to age-related pathologies. In this proposal we outline research related to one gene, SIRT6, which has been implicated as a regulator of mammalian life and health-spans; here we will investigate the molecular mechanisms by which SIRT6 maintains genome architecture. We are optimistic that our research will generate novel insights into the aging process and lead to therapeutic strategies designed to attenuate age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative-Clinical Research Center The increasing number of Americans afflicted by food allergies has become a major public health problem and there remains inadequate preventative or therapeutic strategies. Mount Sinai’s Consortium for Food Allergy Research Clinical Research Center will perform site-specific projects, propose a Network-wide clinical trial to the Leadership Center, and participate in Network-wide studies selected by the Leadership Center and NIAID program officers to address this unmet health need. We will conduct novel and impactful clinical trials and studies and incorporate mechanistic studies to advance prevention and management strategies and to improve knowledge on the origins and immune basis of food allergy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asian Alcohol Flushing Syndrome impacts over 500 million people and is caused by a genetic variant in the ALDH2 gene that also causes a range of serious health conditions. This study will engage the East Asian American community to investigate how to implement genetic testing in clinical care and the effect of genetic testing for ALDH2 variants on modifiable health behaviors using a pragmatic comparative effectiveness trial. Results obtained in this study can aid implementation of genetic and genomic testing for marginalized groups in an equitable and ethical manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DMGs are a universally lethal group of malignant brain tumors which affect both children and adults. A pathological hallmark of this disease is dysregulated transcriptional silencing, though the mechanisms are poorly understood. This proposal will define these molecular mechanisms and determine their relevance across DMG subtypes, thereby laying the framework for a novel therapeutic approach which can improve upon the standard of care radiation therapy in DMGs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Epidemiologic data published by our group estimate that 1 in 13 children and 1 in 10 adults have food allergies, which in turn impose substantial psychosocial and economic burden on affected patients and families. The NUCoFAR Clinical Research Center proposes to advance the prevention, management, treatment of food allergy by leveraging the complementary expertise of its MPIs and their experienced, multi-institutional research team. The proposed site-specific project aims to understand the basic mechanisms of food allergy and oral tolerance, while the proposed network-wide project will develop a CoFAR-wide data commons, which will harmonize and aggregate a wide variety of clinical and epidemiologic data for analysis and future network- wide collaboration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The SWI/SNF complex is a critical regulator of gene expression and is frequently mutated in a wide range of human diseases. This complex is combinatorially assembled from approximately 30 genes, yet we don’t understand how these assemblies are regulated or what the consequences are of having different compositions. The goal of this project is to define new mechanisms that regulate chromatin remodeler composition and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Viral encephalitis is a major cause of epilepsy that can induce short term seizures and long term, recurrent seizures in infected patients. Despite this public health burden, the etiology between seizures occurring during acute infection and chronically, post-viral clearance is unknown. Elucidating hippocampal and network mechanisms in the TMEV mouse model of viral-induced epilepsy across different timepoints may provide critical clues for manipulating seizure-active circuits and eventually lead to novel patient therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Cancer and cognitive problems including Alzheimer’s disease are common diseases of aging that often occur together and impose heavy burdens on patients and caregivers. Cancer patients with cognitive problems have worse health outcomes and need personalized cancer care that often cannot be met by current oncology clinic workflows. Growing telehealth use within the VA has helped relieve some of the burdens on patients and caregivers, and telehealth is expected to be an integral part of future VA cancer care. However, there is limited guidance on its use for complex patients. There is a critical need for oncology clinics to proactively design care processes that can meet the unique needs of older cancer patients with cognitive problems. The goal of this project is to deeply understand the telehealth oncology experiences of patients, caregivers, and clinicians in order to design and test a patient-centered intervention to improve telehealth cancer care delivery, so telehealth cancer care can be equitable for all Veterans regardless of age and memory and thinking abilities.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Dr. Myers’ research projects address areas related to functional restoration in persons with chronic disease. His studies largely focus on applications of exercise therapy and other lifestyle factors to improve physical function, reduce disability, and lower health care costs in Veterans. These areas include studying the physiologic effects of rehabilitation in chronic diseases including chronic heart failure, coronary artery disease, spinal cord injury (SCI), and chronic kidney disease. These are important areas of research among Veterans because heart disease is the leading cause of death and disability in Veterans, and SCI and chronic kidney disease are the two most costly health conditions in the VA system. Dr. Myers’ studies are designed to reduce the overall burden of heart disease and other chronic conditions by improving physical function, reducing disability, and thus reducing health care costs associated with them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: The proposed Kentucky Occupational Safety and Health Surveillance (KOSHS) program will 1) identify industries, occupations, and worker populations at high risk for work-related injuries and illnesses; 2) identify risk factors, trends, and emerging issues; 3) identify gaps in, and improve, occupational injury and illness surveillance systems; and 4) develop interventions for the prevention of occupational injuries. When injury prevention knowledge is attained by the worker, injuries on the job and the economic costs of injuries will decrease because there will be fewer workers’ compensation claims. Fewer occupational fatalities will occur and the severity of occupational injuries will be reduced.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Kentucky Occupational Safety and Health Surveillance Program

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Cigarette smoking has severe negative health consequences for women who smoke and their children. During pregnancy many women are able to quit smoking but relapse shortly after delivery. Second-hand smoke exposure to newborns and infants increases their risk of both acute and chronic illness. Safe and effective smoking relapse prevention strategies that target the postpartum period are lacking. Sex hormones (progesterone and estradiol) have been shown to influence tobacco use behaviors in women during the postpartum period. This study proposes an innovative intervention to examine the effect of modifying progesterone and estradiol to prevent postpartum smoking relapse which will improve health outcomes for mothers and their children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Oral and oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas occur with high incidence rates and prevalence in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), with poor survival rates due to late diagnosis and treatment. We propose a mobile-based intra-oral imaging system, powered with deep learning image classification and patient triage to address the urgent need for a low-cost, portable, easy to use, and reliable method for oral cancer screening in LMICs. We expect that the mobile-based image classification and triage approach will eventually improve detection rates, treatment outcomes and quality of life of patients in LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance: In this proposal, we plan to conduct a novel adaptive phase 1b/2 clinical trial (ADAPT-BLADDER) to study the clinical safety and efficacy, genomic biomarker signatures predictive of patient benefit, and mechanisms underlying tumor antigen-specific adaptive immune responses of innovative combination immunotherapy regimens to treat BCG-relapsing non-muscle invasive bladder cancer patients. This research will improve the overall public health of bladder cancer patients by providing data crucial to optimizing patient selection in future phase 3 studies with the ultimate goal of establishing new durable bladder-sparing options for BCG-relapsing patients. Furthermore, this proposal has important relevance to all cancers since the need to optimize combination immunotherapy approaches is not restricted to bladder cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Changes in cell fate are frequently triggered by ubiquitin-mediated degradation of regulatory proteins. Dysregulation of degradation or transcription is frequently associated with human diseases like cancer. Structural and biochemical insights into the mechanism of dynamic, coordinated transcriptional control, especially in a readily-screenable synthetic context, might allow new breakthroughs in molecular medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health in that it will lead to greater understanding of, and creation of more effective, behavioral interventions for those with central auditory dysfunction. Of particular relevance are older adults for which midlife hearing loss has been shown to be one of the greatest predictors of late life development of Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). This work strongly aligns with the mis- sions of the NIA, and NICHD, which funded an R03 upon which the current proposal builds, the proposed re- search cuts across the bounds of numerous other NIH agencies, including the NCI, NIMH, NIAAA, NIHCD, NI- DA, NINDS, in that all of these agencies work with populations who could gain direct benefits from successful approaches to utilizing behavioral methods to enhance human well-being and performance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The ovarian TME is characterized by large numbers of immunosuppressive myeloid cells that reduce the effectiveness of current immunotherapies. Our data suggest that EGFL6, a protein secreted by OvCa cells, drives an accumulation of immunosuppressive myeloids cells cells in the tumors and inhibits the activity immune checkpoint inhibitor therapies. In this study, we will determine the mechanisms of EGFL6 immunoregulatory activity and evaluate the efficacy of EGFL6 neutralization as an adjuvant to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Mucosal surfaces line the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and urogenital tracts and serve as the first barrier to foreign invasions due to specialized immune cells that reside at this boundary. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this project, we are developing instrumentation and methods to study virus capsids, bacteria, and extracellular vesicles at the single-particle level with higher spatial and temporal resolution. Analysis of single particles provides unprecedented insight into biological processes that is often missed when a population is studied as an ensemble. A more thorough understanding of the physical and chemical properties of these systems is of fundamental interest and will lead to improved therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project narrative Hearing loss affects the quality of life and productivity of millions of citizens. The sensory hair cell bundle transduction machinery is a major site of dysfunction for genetically induced, age-related, and noise induced hearing loss. The success of this proposal will provide an unprecedented understanding of how the sensory hair bundle functions and, in doing so, will be foundational in developing preventative and therapeutic interventions for hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) are a heterogeneous stromal cell population that influence disease course and treatment responses in aggressive cancers. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma has a substantial stromal component, yet the composition of the stroma and its role in promoting malignancy remain unclear. In this proposal, I will elucidate the subtypes of CAFs in thyroid carcinoma and investigate the tumor-promoting effects of CAF-driven Wnt signaling, providing a novel therapeutic target for a disease with an urgent need for new treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Gene regulation is controlled in part through the binding of different proteins to DNA, proteins which control how DNA is organized and how it can be transcribed to RNA and from there to protein. Specifically, sequencing of protein-DNA interactions is logistically difficult and limited with current 2nd generation technologies: only short-range interactions are studied, extensive chemical or enzymatic treatments are needed, and heterogeneity is hard to probe. In this funding period, we are seeking to add to our toolbox to explore the epigenetic state of the human genome via measurement of modifications and insertions to the DNA sequence, with a focus on protein-DNA interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Narrative In the past five years we have grown our biomedical informatics training program to be one of the best in the nation (see Progress Report) while serving a deeply economically and socially needy area of the US, and while recruiting an extraordinarily diverse cohort of students to a program that reflects the highest aims of the NLM training program’s intent and focus. We are even more excited by, and committed to, training our current and forthcoming students to be the researchers needed in biomedical informatics and data science: an essential (if not the essential) key to improving healthcare’s efficacy, efficiency, safety and responsiveness. Review of our program described in this document demonstrates how we have succeeded and continue to serve our trainees, the discipline’s next generation of world class researchers, and, indeed, to serve US healthcare with a carefully crafted and innovative NLM T-15 program.
