PHR: Project Narrative  Understanding systems-level neural mechanisms underlying anesthetic-induced unconsciousness can have tremendous translational benefit because it can significantly impact the development and delivery of anesthetic agents. Achieving this goal requires a whole-brain perspective as AIU is believed to be a brain network phenomenon. In this grant, we will fill this gap by elucidating how whole-brain networks are dynamically reorganized to support different patterns of information exchange from the awake state to unconscious states induced by distinct anesthetic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Developmental ethanol exposure leads to Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders (FASD), which are characterized by physical, behavioral, and cognitive impairments. Microglia, the innate immune cells of the central nervous system, may play a role in alcohol's effects on the brain. This proposal will examine the role of cerebellar microglial dynamics and microglial interactions with cerebellar neurons in FASD pathology, and investigate whether microglia can be a potential target for FASD therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: The primary objective of this study is to develop statistical models and methods for evaluating existing or new cancer treatments for precision cancer medicine when synthesizing data from multiple resources, including evidence from randomized controlled trials (RCT) and real world data (RWD). We will rigorously evaluate the agreement of findings from RCTs and RWD, as well as develop algorithms to select optimal therapies determined by patients’ tumor subtype and other clinical features. The clinical findings will improve cancer practice guidelines leading to enhanced patient outcomes; and the novel statistical tools will be applicable to a broad range of cancer research and to building evidence-based clinical practice.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: ST. JUDE CHILDREN'S RESEARCH HOSPITAL GRADUATE SCHOOL OF BIOMEDICAL SCIENCES, LLC
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During embryonic development, cells producing Sonic Hedgehog (SHH) extend long, thin filopodia called cytonemes to transport the morphogen directly to receiving tissue. Our lab has developed fixation protocols to preserve these delicate structures in cultured cells and mouse embryos for confocal imaging. My project utilizes these protocols in combination with biochemical techniques to determine the cell surface interactions that are promoting SHH-induced cytoneme formation and the intracellular signaling pathways leading to cytoskeletal rearrangement and cytoneme outgrowth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In this proposal we will evaluate the mechanisms through which the transcription factor Blimp1 regulates the stability of eTregs and TFR cells during EAE and MS, and how loss of Blimp1 in eTregs re-shapes the CNS and overall neuroinflammation. The information obtained from this proposal will be used to develop strategies for novel therapeutic approaches to MS and other autoimmune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease will affect an estimated 14 million Americans by the year 2050, contributing to economic burden and reduced quality of life for patients and caregivers. As the U.S. population ages, it is critically important to identify who is at greatest risk for Alzheimer’s disease-associated cognitive decline. Studying novel markers of risk for and resilience to cognitive decline in cognitively normal older adults may identify those who would benefit most from early detection and treatment strategies for Alzheimer’s disease.

PHR: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is a common and serious public health problem that currently lacks effective therapies. Secreted hormones are an important class of metabolic regulators in the body that are uniquely amenable for therapeutic development. We propose to use state-of-the-art genomic tools and genetic and disease models to investigate the mechanisms of action and therapeutic potential of a fat-derived hormone in treating metabolic liver disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interstitial Cystitis/Bladder Pain Syndrome (IC/BPS) is a common, chronic, and often debilitating condition. PHR: Project Narrative This T32 training program is designed to train new clinical, epidemiological, and translational infectious disease investigators, who are needed to discover better ways to diagnose, treat, and prevent serious emerging and re-emerging infections and other Global Health threats such as HIV/AIDS, influenza, meningitis, and antimicrobial-resistant infections. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The threat to patient health from kidney cancer goes beyond the cancer itself, as following removal the remaining kidneys can lose function with a likelihood that is difficult to predict. Tests that can provide insight on the risk of declining kidney function may thus have a tremendous impact in improving patient health and reducing costs. By evaluating kidney cancer patients with diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging, we propose to both better understand the cancer itself and potentially predict the risk of function loss before surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Mechanism of Action of a Novel Golgi-Targeted Anti-Cancer Agent PROJECT NARRATIVE The Golgi GOLPH3 pathway contains multiple cancer drivers, including GOLPH3, MYO18A, PITPNC1, and PI4KIII? that act together through the secretory pathway to promote many common human cancers. Through a phenotypic screen we have identified a small molecule inhibitor of the GOLPH3 pathway that preferentially kills cancerous cells compared to untransformed cells, but the direct target remains uncertain. We propose to determine the mechanism of action of this compound to provide new insight into mechanisms of oncogenic transformation and enable hit-to-lead optimization for new cancer therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Obstructive sleep apnea is an important disease since it is very common and can affect brain function. Older individuals with sleep apnea may have a special type of sleep apnea which can respond to certain medications which can stabilize breathing pattern. In theory, medications which improve sleep apnea could be used to improve breathing pattern, quality of life and possibly brain dysfunction (including risk of Alzheimer’s dementia) in older people at risk of this disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The “Systems Science and Comparative and Cost-Effectiveness Research Training for Nurse Scientists” (S2CER2) research training program will provide nurse scientists with knowledge and skills to conduct interdisciplinary research to advance health equity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The hypothesis that the negative affective states driven by alcohol withdrawal drive continued alcohol use through negative reinforcement has served as a foundational hypothesis guiding research in the alcohol field. D2 receptor containing medium spiny neurons (MSNs) in the nucleus accumbens are a negative reinforcement circuit that have been involved in alcohol drinking and undergo mechanistic changes in response to long-term alcohol exposure. Results from this project will examine the control of D2 MSNs in operant alcohol behavior before and after chronic intermittent ethanol exposure and provide a better understanding of the key motivational drive to take alcohol after long-term use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Alcohol use disorder and sleep disorders are commonly comorbid, and dysfunctional sleep significantly increases the risk of relapse in individuals abstaining from alcohol. My project will investigate synaptic mechanisms of ethanol and noradrenergic modulation in a population of wake-promoting dopamine neurons in the midbrain. In doing so, we hope to elucidate potential novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of dysfunctional sleep in the context of alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Social disadvantage and marginalization due to intersectionality of multiple social determinants of health are frequently associated with women’s adverse health outcomes. The use of data science and health information technology will improve research effectiveness in reducing health disparities among disadvantaged groups of women by providing various strategies that were not possible without these methodologies (e.g., increasing access to hidden populations, improving the precision of measurements). The proposed T32 program trains pre- doctoral and post-doctoral nursing scientists within interdisciplinary teams to have knowledge and skills to employ data science and/or health information technology in order to improve women’s health while considering the intersectionality of multiple social determinants of health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Narrative This project tests three new strategies for improving the efficacy of anti-cancer antibodies and antibody-drug conjugates. Our optimization approaches may be used to enhance the efficacy of many anti-cancer therapies that are in current use, with application to all cancers that develop as solid tumors (including lung, breast, colorectal, and prostate cancers). Given the high rate of incidence of cancer, with approximately 1.7 million new cases and 600,000 deaths each year in the United States, this project, if successful, may have a substantial impact on human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cocaine use disorder is a chronic, relapsing condition with severe public health impacts and limited effective treatment options. The current proposal aims to assess the acute effects of transcranial magnetic stimulation on electroencephalogram markers that contribute to poor treatment outcomes and has the potential to advance NIDA's objective of developing novel treatments that specifically target underlying neurobiological mechanisms of cocaine use disorder. This study can potentially improve transcranial magnetic stimulation treatment and ultimately lower the health burden of cocaine use disorder on the individual and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed study will examine if there are differential effects of angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI) subtypes on 1) motoric, 2) cognitive, and 3) neurodegenerative and vascular outcomes among participants in 2 nationally available cohorts. It will be the first to examine these outcomes in older adults on ACEI without dementia. Early identification of older adults at risk for the development of cognitive impairment and functional decline, coupled with a better understanding of how this commonly prescribed medication affects cortical regions associated with dementia, is of paramount importance as a prelude to identification of targeted therapies to slow the progression of dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Better grasp of the mechanism underlying chromosomal rearrangements and mutagenesis is highly relevant to public health because genome-altering events are central to understanding both the changes in cells at the onset of tumorigenesis and during the treatment of cancers with chemotherapeutics that function by damaging DNA and elevating genome instability. The results from the proposed research is expected to contribute to understanding how genome instability-inducing factors such as non-canonical nucleosides and secondary DNA structures are regulated and connected to the transcription process and are therefore applicable to the part of NIH’s mission to develop fundamental knowledge regarding development and treatment of cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative The mission of the Chemical Biology Training Program is to provide multidisciplinary training for graduate students, which integrates all aspects of chemistry and biology. The program fosters interactions among the faculty and students from departments in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences and the School of Pharmacy. The overarching goal of the proposed training program is to produce a diverse population of scientists who are well-trained in rigorous and transparent scientific methodology, experimental design, and data interpretation, and who have developed the professional skills required to find success in a broad range of research-intensive or research-related careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Research of the brain receptor functions holds a promise for better diagnostic tools and drugs that could be tailored to the individual needs, thereby eliminating or reducing side effects and even providing a way for prevention of disease. Real time imaging of receptor modulation using simultaneous phMRI and PET will challenge the present theories of signaling and synaptic plasticity during degenerative processes. The results of receptor modulation can be readily utilized in the drug development for dopamine-glutamate regulation related disorder, like Parkinson’s disease, schizophrenia or drug abuse.

PHR: Project Narrative Argonaute proteins in animals, plants, fungi, and bacteria use small pieces of RNA or DNA to find and control genes. The proposed research will reveal how organisms make small RNAs and use Argonautes to control development and reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Despite years of effective suppressive antiretroviral therapy (ART), latent HIV-infected cells can persist in people with HIV (PWH) and reintroduce disseminated HIV infection after cessation of ART, preventing the functional cure of HIV-infected individuals. The anti-HIV-1 immune response in most patients is inadequate to effectively eliminate reactivated cells, necessitating the development of strategies to boost the anti-HIV immune response to enable it to clear the reservoir after reactivation. We postulate that by redirecting CD8 T cells that are highly effective in controlling chronic latent CMV infection to target and kill HIV-infected cells, we can boost the HIV- specific immune response in PWH to prevent recurrent viremia after the cessation of ART and contribute to providing a functional cure of HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will utilize human intracranial recording and stimulation to quantify the unique contributions of the posterior cingulate cortex (PCC) to episodic memory. Specifically, we will use single unit and population measures of neural activity to test a new account of PCC function which focuses on the executive processes needed to support memory retrieval and memory based decisions. By studying PCC, a convergence zone of memory and executive systems, progress can be made in elucidating how the failure to successfully leverage past experiences in daily behavior can occur as a common symptom of both neurodegenerative disease (e.g. Alzheimer’s disease) and multiple psychiatric conditions (e.g. schizophrenia) implicating PCC dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public health response to infectious disease epidemics requires multidisciplinary, quantitative, and critical skills to address all aspects of control from preparedness to elimination. The proposed training program will provide foundational training in epidemiological study design and inference, ethics, and advanced methodological training in one of three methodological areas: (1) Transmission Modeling and Infectious Disease Dynamics, (2) Molecular Epidemiology and Phylogenetics, and (3) Disease Mapping and Burden Estimation. As part of this program, trainees will apply these methods to practical issues in policy and disease control through practicums and projects in translational research and implementation.
PROJECT_TERMS: Infectious Disease Epidemiology;research in practice;Translating
PROJECT_TITLE: Research in practice: translating infectious disease epidemiology RIP-TIDE
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Microbiology and Infectious Diseases Advisory Committee[MID]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Conserved membrane fusion mechanisms, essential for cell growth, neurotransmission, and hormone secretion, are "hijacked" by invading bacteria and viruses which must enter the lysosome/vacuole to infect and cause human disease. We discovered, cloned, purified, and study a central catalyst of this process, termed HOPS, which is conserved from yeast to humans and is known to be essential for pathogens to gain access to the lysosome, an essential step in infection. Our advanced studies of HOPS, including development of facile assays, are a prerequisite for the development of drugs which thereby target pathogen invasion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Allergies are major causes of pregnancy complications and neonatal morbidity. This project explores the function of maternal IgD transferred to the fetus during pregnancy in the protection from neonatal allergy. The novel scientific concept and clinical implications of this project fit well both the scientific and public health goals of NIH, and will have a significantly positive impact on how to innovatively and more efficiently tackle early infant morbidity due to increasing incidences of allergies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Synaptic dysfunction is common to neurodevelopmental disorders and is considered a major contributor to behavioral deficits. This study will uncover novel axonal mechanisms that initiate abnormal synaptic development in Fragile X syndrome, by combining cell group specific genetic approaches with in vivo time-lapse structural and functional imaging. The results are applicable in understanding the generation of synaptic pathophysiology in neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cryptococcus neoformans (C. neo), is one of the most significant fungal pathogens worldwide, with few treatment options. The ones that do exist are often lengthy and highly toxic. Veterans are at high risk of fungal infections due to underling immune deficiencies (especially from cancer therapy) and unique deployment- related exposures. This project studies how the fungi producing a specific sugar (trehalose) leads to protecting it from the immune system during infection. The project investigates multiple levels of the immune defenses that are rendered ineffective when C. neo is capable of making trehalose. Interfering in this sugar production may lead to new treatment options which could allow the immune system to get the upper hand on C. neo infections and clear the infection. Our results could have implications in other fungal infections, as trehalose synthesis is typical throughout, and is even found in some bacteria species. As such our results can have a far- reaching impact on antimicrobial treatments for Veterans.

PHR: Project Narrative This project will create tools that use viral genome data to make actionable public health inferences. Through analysis of evolutionary patterns of seasonal inﬂuenza virus, we will guide the process of vaccine strain selection and thereby improve vaccine efﬁcacy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Chronic pelvic pain is the hallmark of patients with chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CPPS), a category of prostatitis that is a significant source of morbidity in American men. Currently, there is lack of effective mechanistic therapies for CPPS and there is an urgent unmet medical need. This project will evaluate mechanisms behind a potential therapeutic for chronic pelvic pain that was obtained from prostate commensal bacteria and can modulate immune and neuronal functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will collect samples from 10,000 South Korean women with recurrent major depressive disorder and 10,000 matched controls. All subjects will be genotyped and the location of genetic risk factors identified in a genome-wide association analysis. The cohort will also provide detailed information about the likely environmental causes of depression, and when combined with a similarly deeply phenotyped cohort from China, will form a uniquely powerful resource for the discovery of genes involved in recurrent major depressive disorder.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The relatively high proportion of active (REM) sleep in fetuses and newborns is the foundation for the decades-old hypothesis that active sleep is important for early brain development. One of the critical components of active sleep, myoclonic twitching, is now known to provide abundant and precise sensory input to the developing brain, suggesting that twitches are a key driver of activity-dependent development in the sensorimotor system. Here, using a longitudinal design to investigate sleep in premature human infants—who are at greater risk for cerebral palsy, autism, and other neurodevelopmental disorders—before and after discharge from the neonatal intensive care unit, we will determine whether twitching is a useful diagnostic tool for detecting atypical developmental trajectories and informing future interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE COURSE ON ADVANCED SEQUENCING TECHNOLOGIES & BIOINFORMATICS ANALYSIS  This advanced course offers the latest training in DNA and RNA sequencing and analysis. The explosion in genomics over the past several decades has spawned a range of sequencing technologies and approaches that each have advantages and disadvantages over competing approaches, even as the underlying cost drops precipitously. Biomedical scientists now use DNA sequencing technologies not just to catalog the genomes of thousands of species, but to probe genetic variation within species, including multicellular organisms such as plants and animals, fungi, bacteria and viruses. Techniques such as single cell sequencing allow for sampling of normal tissue across time and space, providing an ever more in-depth understanding of normal development and disease progression, while RNA sequencing in its many iterations provides detailed molecular analysis of the genome expression and regulation, informing both our understanding of normal biological processes and the progression of diseases such as cancer and viral infections. The plethora of sequencing technologies together produce an avalanche data, and practitioners must also be trained in the latest bioinformatics tools and approaches to make sense of and interpret the unprecedented volumes of information generated experimentally. The course will enroll a diverse cadre of students ranging from graduate students to group leaders, promoting collaboration and exchange of ideas between faculty and trainees, and thus represents a significant and valuable investment towards accelerating genome research and its application to biomedical and biological questions. Effort will be made to broaden access to this educational resource using a combination of hands-on in-person and online training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because a majority of women and men will experience lower urinary tract symptoms in their lifetime, but existing treatments have limited efficacy and important risks. Understanding new age-related mechanisms of lower urinary tract symptoms will lead to more accurate diagnosis and novel individualized treatments that improve or maintain health-related quality of life and physical function in older adults. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIA's strategic goal to understand the dynamics of the aging process and to improve the health, well-being, and independence of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mycophenolic acid, the current anti-proliferative immunosuppression agent of choice for lung transplant recipients, demonstrates extensive variability in both therapeutic effect and adverse drug effects. This project will investigate how genetic and clinical factors regulate mycophenolic acid exposure and effects and how mycophenolic acid exposure correlates with clinical outcomes. We aim to establish recommendations for therapeutic drug monitoring and precision dosing utilizing a patient’s genetic and clinical profile to optimize therapeutic effects and minimize adverse drug effects of mycophenolic acid.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Over 2/3 of adults in the USA are overweight or obese and there is currently a shortage of effective treatments to reduce the excessive food intake that leads to obesity. Novel and effective obesity prevention and treatment strategies are aided by basic science research identifying specific brain chemical systems that reduce food intake. A novel approach is taken here; we believe that more progress can be made towards obesity treatment and reducing associated health care costs if basic research were to focus on understanding neural and biological mechanisms through which learning and memory, reward, and environmental food cues interact to cause excessive feeding and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A projected doubling of the elderly population by 2050 will dramatically increase the incidence of cognitive impairments associated with Alzheimer’s disease (AD), resulting in tremendous social and economic burdens. Advances in therapeutic or preventive strategies leading to even modest delays in onset and progression could significantly reduce this burden, especially as no real effective treatment at either the clinical or preclinical stage of AD currently exists. The proposed research utilizes a unique 60-year longitudinal cohort to provide new insights into factors from early childhood to later adulthood that impact neurocognitive mechanisms of reserve which, in turn, may serve to both delay the onset of AD pathology and moderate the impact of AD pathology and other age-related brain changes on cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The Cancer Research Training Program (CRTP) described herein is designed to prepare the next generation of young investigators for successful careers in cancer research. By providing trainees with the practical skills to perform high-quality research, the foundational knowledge to cultivate a process of life-long learning, and the skills to be part of a dynamic and interactive research team, the CRTP will help to create a new generation of cancer researchers who are uniquely prepared to make inroads into understanding and treating cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The OHSU SOD is uniquely positioned to offer this comprehensive research mentoring and training PORT for the next generation of oral health scientists since we are the only dental school in the state of Oregon, supported by robust OHSU and state-wide research and research training resources. We are committed to address current and future shortages in the oral health research workforce by preparing a diverse and inclusive cadre of individuals for careers as independent scientists. Our objective is consistent with NIDCR’s mission to advance national research needs in the dental, oral and craniofacial health and science.

PHR: The Adolescent Health Promotion Research Training Program provides training in sexual and reproductive health research to post-doctoral physicians training in Adolescent Medicine. This program is designed to address national health and workforce disparities in adolescent health and responds to the Healthy People 2030 objectives. Physician graduates will ultimately contribute to the scientific development of innovative and effective prevention strategies for pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections, including the human immunodeficiency virus, among youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a common and life-threatening condition that is most frequently caused by sepsis, has a 30-50% death rate, and has no disease-specific therapies. The goal of my research program is to develop a discovery and mechanistic pipeline to identify clinically relevant mediators of ARDS, and rapidly translate the most promising findings into pre-clinical models. Using our novel discovery methods, model systems and translational research approach, we will transform our understanding of ARDS pathogenesis and lay the groundwork for future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic chronic inflammation is a common comorbidity of type 2 diabetes and inflammatory bowel disease, affecting a patient’s immune, nervous, endocrine, and reproductive systems. The contribution of postprandial inflammation to the systemic chronic inflammation in those contexts remains unclear. This study seeks to identify this missing link and understand how intestinal track displaced hyaluronan promotes liver Kupffer cell Marco expression to promote hepatic and systemic inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Many cancers, including colon cancer, are more aggressive in obese patients, but the explanation is unknown. We recently discovered that colon cancer grows faster in diet-induced obese mice and our preliminary findings suggest that such rapid growth is caused by overexpression of a molecule called GPR65 on the macrophages in the tumors of these mice, resulting in impaired anti-tumor immunity. In this project, we will identify the mechanism by which GPR65 becomes activated and promotes the growth of colon and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE FDA’s recent efforts towards banning menthol cigarettes must be paired with evidence-based tobacco regulatory policies that maximize the likelihood that menthol smokers respond by quitting tobacco use altogether or switching to modified risk tobacco products (MRTP) instead of non-menthol cigarettes. This project examines the influence of flavor availability on switching to an MRTP known as IQOS, part of the Heated Tobacco Product (HTP) class, among menthol smokers using clinical lab and naturalistic evaluations of abuse liability. Results will help federal regulators predict the public health impact on menthol cigarette smokers of policies restricting access to menthol-flavored HTPs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Innovative implementation strategies for HIV prevention are needed in the Southern US to decrease HIV transmission. Engaging high risk contacts of sexual and gender minority people with newly acquired HIV through social network methods may have higher yield in reaching those who would benefit from immediate linkage to HIV treatment or prevention services than standard partner services. The proposed research aims to evaluate HIV transmission networks in North and South Carolina, and to develop and implement a partner services intervention to use social network strategy to increase testing and linkage to HIV care or prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death in diabetic patients. In previous grant cycles, we identified a novel pathway linking diabetes to atherosclerosis; in our preliminary data, we identified a compound that can inhibit this pathway. We expect that our work will yield a safe, effective drug to prevent cardiovascular disease in diabetic patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Safety-net hospitals are ideal sites to stage evidence-based OUD services such as transitional opioid programs (TOPs) that link hospitalized patients to community-based outpatient settings in underserved communities. However, these institutions are less likely to offer OUD services, due in part to barriers that are not well understood. In this study, we will assess the current opioid programs offered by safety net hospitals, explore barriers and facilitators to adopting and implementing TOPs by interviewing hospital decision makers and community partners at five safety net hospitals, and convene an expert panel to identify and tailor high-yield implementation strategies to increase the availability of transitional opioid programs and other evidence-based opioid services in underserved communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Human samples contain immense riches of data, but are extremely precious as experiments consume them. To solve this problem, we propose developing a new method that indefinitely preserves such material across experiments. This means ideally limitless experiments can be performed to improve accuracy, or different ones can be performed to look at different types of information afforded by the sample.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Renal cysts are fluid-filled sacs that interfere with normal kidney function. Dysfunction of primary cilia or of cilia-associated proteins can lead to cystic kidneys so it is critical to understand the role of such proteins in renal cyst formation. Here we use a novel mouse model as an entry point to genetically isolate ciliary signaling in the context of known molecular players of cyst formation, and determine whether and when it can reverse renal cysts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis remains a major cause of morbidity and mortality; however development of effective therapies for sepsis treatment represents a major challenge. Using preclinical models of lung inflammation caused by live methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (USA300 clinical strain 923) and inactivated Staphylococcus aureus particles to recapitulate sterile septic conditions after antibiotic treatment, this study will investigate local regulation of lung microvascular barrier function via cell junction-associated molecular mechanisms promoting reduction of inflammatory signaling and recovery of endothelial barrier. This study may lead to discovery of a new group of pharmacological molecules for the treatment of sepsis and other diseases associated with increased vascular leakage and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Almost half of the human genome sequence has been created by self-replicating, genome-bound transposable elements like L1, and the replication of these elements can cause numerous diseases including cancer, autoimmunity, and infertility. Despite their persistence and prevalence, the functional consequences of the evolution of L1s is incompletely understood. We propose to study how L1s evade the factors used by the human genome to block their replication and how evasive L1s might impact human health. (3 sentences)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Tolvaptan, which has limited efficacy and significant toxicity, is the only approved treatment that slows the decline of renal function in patients with ADPKD in the US. Among the most promising drug candidates are protein and lipid kinases. We applied a new strategy to identify novel kinases up-regulated in PKD kidneys and will determine whether inhibiting or activating any of these kinases slows cyst growth and progression of kidney disease with the goal to identify new kinases that are potential targets to slow cyst growth in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposal is focused on determining therapeutic mechanisms of a novel therapeutic strategy, post- ischemic acute injection of the DHA metabolite, NPD1. This strategy is based on our novel findings that out of several DHA metabolites, Resolvin D1, NPD1 and Resolvin D2, only NPD1 afforded robust protection against neonatal hypoxic-ischemic brain injury and this was coupled with beneficial effect on mitochondrial function. Potential implication of this research is very broad, because post-ischemic mitochondrial dysfunction is one of the major mechanisms of tissue damage driven by reperfusion injury.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: In order to improve diagnostic quality, we need a systematic approach to measure it in large-scale data across clinical providers. In this project, we will develop such an approach and apply it to the specific setting of emergency department radiology, using data covering millions of visits and thousands of radiologists. Measures of diagnostic quality across a large number of clinicians in a wide range of locations will enable us to understand not only the determinants of diagnostic quality at the provider- and system-level but also its relationship with patient health outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Measuring and Understanding Diagnostic Quality from Large-Scale Data

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how adult blood stem cells maintain themselves is essential for developing future cellular therapies and treating blood diseases including anemias, myelodysplastic disorders and hematopoietic malignancies. Previously, we found that the MUSASHI2 gene is essential for blood stem control and elevated abundance in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes results in a poor outcome. This proposal studies the mechanisms of the MUSASHI2 regulatory network for the development of novel future therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Lung cancer accounts for more than 1.5 million deaths worldwide each year. This proposed Emory University P01 program intends to generate new therapeutic strategies for treating lung cancer patients by improving understanding of the dysregulated growth regulatory and immunotherapy resistance mechanisms in lung cancer patients with lost LKB1. Overseen by an Executive Committee, Internal and External Advisory Boards, the program will encompass three interconnected research projects supported by three core resources and an interdisciplinary team that will integrate novel insights from LKB1 biology and its role in resistance to immunotherapy in order to discover innovative clinical strategies for lung cancer patients based on LKB1 status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative While pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is resistant to immune checkpoint blockade (ICB), preventing the formation of the T cell sequestering CXCL12 “coat” renders mouse models of this disease susceptible. This proposal will identify the amino acids of KRT19 required to form the covalent isopeptide bond between it and CXCL12, quantify the rate of CXCL12 coat formation and disassembly, and determine how these processes polarize the immune system. The knowledge gained will guide future pre-clinical and clinical studies attempting to block the formation of the CXCL12 coat in the treatment of PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Elevated glutaminolysis has been considered as a hallmark of cancer, but the mechanism through which glutaminolysis is upregulated and how it contributes to immunotherapy resistance is largely unclear. We found that glutamate dehydrogenase 1 (GDH1), an essential enzyme in the glutaminolysis pathway, is selectively activated by FAK in LKB1-deficient lung cancer and suppresses anti-tumor immunity via alpha KG-mediated metabolic, transcriptional, and protein stability regulation. In this proposal, we will explore the mechanism by which FAK-mediated GDH1 activation inhibits antitumor immunity specifically in LKB1-deficient lung cancer and validate the therapeutic efficacy of targeting GDH1 in combination with immune checkpoint inhibitors as a novel anti-cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Balance disorders are common in people with Parkinson's disease and respond poorly to dopaminergic medications. We propose to investigate a novel hypothesis about the effects of cholinergic neurotransmitter changes in specific areas of the brain that are associated with processing of vestibular information and how this relates to balance disorders. Positive findings in the study may result in new treatment strategies to prevent falls in older parkinsonian and non-parkinsonian adults with age-related vestibular changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Neuropeptide S is a neurotransmitter released in the brain to promote wakefulness, but the mechanisms by which it exerts its effects are unknown. Here we will use state of the art methods to map the connections between brain cells that produce Neuropeptide S and the cells known to promote wakefulness. The data generated in this proposal may lead to the development of new treatments for sleep and anxiety disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The work proposed here, a multidisciplinary effort to improve the therapeutic index of a well-established class of drugs-the aminoglycosides. We propose to reduce their ototoxicity, while simultaneously improving the anti- infective effects. In vitro and in vivo ototoxicity studies will be used to optimize the development of a new class of small molecules developed by NUBAD as non-toxic therapeutics. The success of the proposed work would be a significant addition to currently available classes of aminoglycosides in broad spectrum drug development. Using our preliminary data, we propose using our promising leads to develop and optimize a small library of small molecules that can be employed to inhibit microbial growth but with significantly lower ototoxicities, opening possibilities for development of therapeutics with improved therapeutic profiles over existing clinical standard of care drugs. The proposed research describes such a strategy for improving the therapeutic index of aminoglycosides by designing novel structures that lower their ototoxicities.

PHR: NARRATIVE The Molecular Pathology and Immunology Core 2 will collect and store tissues from patients with lung cancer, and will characterize these tissues using pathologic, genomic and immunologic tests. The Core will provide the tissues and the associated clinical, pathological, immunologic and genomic information to the investigators of all three of the proposed translational projects and to the biostatistics core for integration into a specialized lung cancer P01 database. These studies will help us understand lung cancer better and potentially allow us to develop new treatments for about one quarter of all lung adenocarcinoma patients whose tumors carry LKB1 mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias have a devastating impact on public health and patient function, and interventions to slow cognitive decline or reduce risk of developing dementia are desperately needed. There is a strong link between visual impairment and cognitive impairment or risk of dementia; we hypothesize that cataract surgery—a widely available intervention to improve vision—may be able to “bend the curve” for risk of dementia onset and worsening. This study will use existing large-scale electronic health record data to investigate the impact of cataract surgery and visual impairment on incidence and progression of dementia in a real-world setting, which will enable a subsequent clinical trial and other dementia research for a more precise approach to treating individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid therapy is controversial due to risks for misuse and dependence; yet, many patients continue to advocate for and use opioids at the cost of high rates of continued exposure and soaring national rates of opioid addiction and overdose deaths. This project will evaluate the neurobiological consequences of opioids, in particular how central nervous system (CNS) activity is altered in patients on long-term opioid therapy, a research focus which to date, has been remarkably neglected. The knowledge gained through this work will inform novel CNS-based strategies for effective alternatives to opioid therapy, avenues to reverse deleterious neurobiological consequences of opioid therapy, and treatments to aid in opioid cessation and to combat drug addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to one million Americans undergo invasive mechanical ventilation each year and are subject to high rates of morbidity and mortality. These patients are cared for by a team of clinicians, including physicians, nurses, and respiratory therapists; however, the role that each clinician group plays in determining patient outcomes is unknown. This project will explore how different types of clinicians contribute to patient outcomes individually and as teams, thereby creating new knowledge that can inform strategies and policies to improve care of this high-risk patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This study takes advantage of unique camera technology developed in my laboratory for live imaging of cells in the human retina. We will use this camera to investigate how the retina's light‐capturing cells contribute to our vision and how they are affected by retinitis pigmentosa, the most common form of inherited irreversible vision loss. Results of this study may help improve our ability to detect and treat some of the most blinding diseases in the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Copy number variants are a class of genetic mutations, which are associated with greatly elevated rates of major psychiatric disorders such as autism and schizophrenia. We propose to assemble the largest neuroimaging and genomic dataset to date (total of 140,000 individuals) to identify mechanisms that mediate the effects of deletions and duplications on brain structure and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Having a co-occurring substance use disorder is common in and a significant predictor of treatment dropout for individuals with first episode psychosis (FEP). Reducing substance use in this vulnerable co-occurring disorders population is an unmet need that requires novel interventions to improve engagement in substance use elements of integrated psychiatric care. The present research project will iteratively develop and pilot test a highly accessible version of a well-established substance use disorder treatment engagement strategy, Community Reinforcement Approach and Family Training, targeting family members of people with co-occurring substance use disorders and FEP and delivered via telemedicine (CRAFT-FT) to assess changes in substance use disorder treatment engagement, substance use, and family distress compared to treatment as usual and in-person CRAFT-F.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE  This training grant contributes to the replenishment of specialists, both MD and PhD, in a number of topical areas of national health priorities. These include, but are not restricted to, diabetes, obesity, cardiovascular disease, women’s health, and behavioral medicine. It is a high quality and highly structured program, supported by an outstanding training faculty and exceptional institutional resources at one of the premier medical research campuses in the US. Over its long history (>46 years) it has been very successful in training outstanding fellows for research and research-related positions in academia and other research settings, as defined by the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Public Health narrative Gene therapy allows for production of therapeutic proteins by patients' own cells. However, once the gene therapy is administered to the body of a large animal or a human, we have no methods of measuring how well the gene therapeutic is expressed, or whether it has reached the correct cells. Here, we are developing new technologies that will enable such measurements with a simple and convenient blood test.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Alcohol exposure is associated with aberrations in alternative splicing, but the functional consequences of this are unknown. Genome engineering approaches using Drosophila melanogaster provide an opportunity to understand this at a highly mechanistic level. Here we interrogate how alcohol-induced aberrant splicing of Drosophila D2-like Receptor influences behavior and neural dynamics, which will establish a connection between dynamic alternative splicing and changes in nervous system function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In spite of the major success of immune checkpoint inhibitory (ICI) antibodies capable of triggering immune responses to solid cancers, pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) responds poorly to this intervention due to an immune depleted or “cold” tumor microenvironment. In this application, we will develop a series of nanocarriers to deliver chemotherapeutic drugs to induce “immunogenic cell death” (ICD), which is capable of creating a “hot” tumor environment that can be further exploited to obtain a sustained immune response. The cornerstone of the PDAC immunotherapy platform is a silicasome nanocarrier, which has the ability to deliver ICD stimuli in combination with synergistic small molecule inhibitors that interfere in local immune suppressive pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to 1) identify articulation-based dysarthria subgroups derived from articulatory performance profiles of talkers with a variety of underlying neurological conditions using a taxonomic (data-driven) classification approach, 2) determine the articulatory performance characteristics that uniquely differentiate these subgroups, 3) determine if the disease type varies systematically across the identified articulation-based subgroups, and 4) determine the extent to which auditory- and visual-perceptual judgements of articulatory performance map onto the findings of speech kinematic measures. The proposed project is highly relevant to public health and the mission of NIH and NIDCD because it aims to advance our understanding of articulatory impairment patterns and how they may vary across talkers with dysarthria. New discoveries from this project will set the stage for future research efforts that aim to elucidate the subgroup-specific articulatory mechanisms that underlie speech intelligibility loss and recovery in these talkers and facilitate personalized dysarthria management and the development of new, impairment-specific intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hearing loss is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and other forms of cognitive impairment in humans. In mice, hearing loss causes cognitive impairment reflecting hippocampal dysfunction. We will use a mouse model of AD to disambiguate whether hearing loss specifically accelerates key AD pathologies such as accumulated amyloid β plaques and hyperphosphorylated tau, and to determine whether neuronal activity patterns in the hippocampal network are disrupted by hearing loss, to provide insight into the mechanisms through which hearing loss causes cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Acquired mutations in cancers, including liquid cancers such as leukemia, can lead to drug resistance in cancer cells. The proposed studies in this proposal will seek to investigate how chromosome rearrangement between Daple and tyrosine kinase receptors lead to leukemias, and the tools that will be generated may offer a new modality to target such mutations. Insights gained through the proposed studies will provide a mechanistic insight into the Daple-Kinase gene fusion and to establish zebrafish as a rapid and personalized disease model for therapeutic testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and its related metabolic disorders are at historic prevalence throughout the world. There is no reliable way to predict what diet is ideal for metabolic health on an individual basis. This project will explore the role of genetic variation in the response to two popular diets (high-fat/low-carb, vs. low-fat/high-carb) in a genetically diverse mouse population and discover the genes and pathways that mediate diet responsiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related macular degeneration is the leading cause of blindness in the elderly in the US and is a significant public health issue that is projected to worsen due to the rapidly aging population. Here we aim to understand how retinal cells change in normal aging and how these normal age-related changes differ from the changes that lead to age-related macular degeneration. This project will allow us to detect age-related macular degeneration earlier and will produce new tools to monitor retinal cells that will facilitate the development and testing of preventative therapies to slow or prevent vision loss in age-related macular degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic injuries from burns, blasts, or major surgery disrupts normal immune system functions, which can lead to the development of life-threatening infections and prolonged critical illnesses. Targeted immunotherapies for traumatic injuries to restore immune system function have not yet been developed and are urgently needed. This project studies the scientific processes involved in using specific natural immunostimulatory DNA as a novel treatment approach to enhance immune system health in immune compromised trauma patients that are at risk of dying from complications of their injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will promote the public health of more than 15 million Americans who serve as family caregivers for relatives with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. It will assess whether stress reduction therapy incorporating guided imagery practices that promote perspective taking and empathy can improve the effects of family caregiver skills training delivered remotely by smartphone. It will also test the feasibility of using smartphone estimated markers to track caregiver insomnia and stress, which could eventually help reduce caregiver suffering and healthcare costs by identifying early warning signs of treatment failure and symptomatic worsening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Mechanisms of Endogenous DNA Damage Promotion This project leverages Escherichia coli as a tractable, proven cancer model for discovery of functions and consequences of a large, diverse, conserved network of proteins that promote DNA damage and genome instability, with the goal of modeling functions of large numbers of cancer proteins currently poorly understood. The DNA damage-up proteins (DDPs) were discovered in E. coli, their human homologs shown to be cancer predictive, and also to promote DNA damage and mutation. This project uses the E. coli model to uncover both mechanisms that generate spontaneous endogenous DNA damage, and the functions and mechanisms of DNA-damage promotion by bacterial and human DDPs, to understand how many cancer-promoting proteins drive cancers, which may potentially enable universal, economical cancer/disease screening, and novel anti-cancer drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorders (SUDs) are highly prevalent among formerly incarcerated individuals, and drug overdose rates are elevated post-incarceration. The proposed research represents an opportunity to identify individual and environmental-level predictors of opioid and/or cocaine use over a one-year period among formerly incarcerated individuals, and to determine whether they are receiving adequate levels of addiction treatment. The proposed research will identify substance use treatment gaps and influential factors that are amenable to intervention in the interest of informing effective responses to problematic substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Iron balance in the body must be closely controlled to provide this essential nutrient for red blood cell production, but to prevent the damaging effects of too much iron on a number of organs including the liver, heart, and pancreas. This proposal will investigate how the liver senses iron levels in the body to control production of a hormone called hepcidin that is critical to keep body iron in balance. Our work will help to understand how iron balance is disrupted in diseases of too little or too much iron including anemia, hemochromatosis, and b- thalassemia, with the ultimate goal to identify new ways to treat these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research relates to type 2 diabetes (T2D), which is a major public health challenge due to its increased prevalence worldwide. Specifically, the studies address deficits in both pancreatic β-cell function and mass in T2D by interrogating the therapeutic potential of a novel metabolite of the renin-angiotensin system, namely angiotensin(1-2). By using cell-based and whole-body models, it is expected that the proposed studies will reveal previously unrecognized intracellular mechanisms of action for angiotensin(1-2) that impact glycemic control, and could be exploited in the pursuit of new drugs that target several abnormalities in T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The interaction between prefrontal and visual cortical areas is critical for many cognitive functions including attention and working memory. This proposal investigates the role of phase coding in visual cortex, along with its modulation by prefrontal activity during working memory, and the ability of a similar coding mechanism to expand the information capacity of the visual system during eye movements. Understanding the role of phase coding during working memory and eye movements will provide a necessary comparison point for neurological disorders involving impaired prefrontal-sensory interactions, including schizophrenia, Alzheimer’s disease, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and autism spectrum disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative With knowledge of the genes that contribute to resistance against infectious diseases, researchers, medical professionals, and epidemiologists can better estimate the risk that individuals and populations face from a particular infection, predict the spread of an infectious disease, and develop gene-based therapies. The proposed work will tackle a central challenge in identifying these genes: their effects seem to depend strongly on context, with many genes contributing to parasite resistance in only one of many environments or against only one of many parasite strains. I take advantage of new resources for studying natural populations of a biomedical model organism, Caenorhabditis elegans, and its natural parasites to advance our general understanding of how, and why, genetic and environmental contexts change the loci that promote resistance against infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy alcohol drinking during adolescence is known to disturb brain development and functioning and increase risk of drinking problems in adulthood, but the extent of the lingering effects of youthful drinking on adult functioning remains unclear. The goal of NCANDA-A (Adulthood) is to follow youth who have and have not engaged in hazardous drinking to determine alcohol's influence on the brain, cognition, emotion, and life activities in emerging adulthood when young men and women are establishing themselves in careers, relationships, and independent living. Recognition of signs of risk to adjustment in adulthood following youthful drinking may enhance opportunity for personal success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE Under chronic blood pressure as in hypertension, the heart muscle compensates by a variety of ways that result in thickening and enlargement of heart muscle wall or hypertrophy. Left ventricular hypertrophy in hypertensive patients is a strong predictor of heart failure and mortality. Our studies may provide a new understanding that can help drug screening and drug discovery to prevent adverse cardiac remodeling and heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Although over 40,000 obese individuals with end-stage kidney disease initiate dialysis each year in the United States, there are no guidelines on optimal obesity management in the setting of dialysis care. Obese dialysis patients may lose weight due to chronic illness or due to intentional weight loss attempts, though it is difficult to differentiate between healthy and unhealthy weight loss in these patients. This proposal seeks to advance the science of obesity management in dialysis settings by providing new tools to differentiate between healthy and unhealthy weight loss trajectories among obese dialysis patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent advances in cancer immunotherapy have irrefutably demonstrated the powerful ability of the immune system to destroy cancer through the activity of T cells, however the benefits of these treatments have been restricted to a small percentage of patients. We found that cancer cell death leads to an altered abundance of potassium within tumors, which acts as a previously unidentified ionic check upon T cell antitumor function. The proposed research will assess the functional consequences for cell death and local potassium release for in vivo T cell antitumor function in human cancers, leverage our preliminary data to define a non-canonical role for intracellular potassium (K+), and test novel cancer treatments based on the directed manipulation of T cell potassium transport.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is strong commitment in sub-Saharan Africa, and globally, to improve hypertension treatment as a key part of the global strategy to reduce cardiovascular disease mortality by 25% by the year 2025. As hypertension diagnosis and medication availability improve, there is a critical need for interventions to improve patient- centeredness and patient engagement in chronic hypertension care in order to achieve and maintain the long- term benefits of hypertension treatment. In this K23 proposal, I will develop and pilot test a theory-informed implementation strategy to improve hypertension treatment adherence among people with and without HIV in the context of an integrated chronic HIV-hypertension care model in rural western Kenya.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Little progress has been made in the treatment of patients with EWS fusion driven cancer, including Ewing sarcoma, a pediatric solid tumor driven by the EWS/FLI1 fusion oncoprotein. In this proposal, we will evaluate the novel hypothesis that Ewing sarcoma tumors are susceptible to oncogene overdose through decreasing TRIM8, the E3 ligase for EWS/FLI1. We will determine the mechanisms governing the EWS/FLI1 and TRIM8 interactions, including condensate formation; the impact of TRIM8 repression on epigenetic states; and test the hypothesis that the glutamate receptor GRM2 mediates toxicity downstream of EWS/FLI1 overdose mediated by TRIM8 repression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer is a disease that often originates in genomic abnormalities; however, these genome-level defects exert its functional significance at the level of proteins. Coordinating within the Clinical Proteomic Tumor Analysis Consortium, the Proteome Characterization Center at the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory will comprehensively characterize the protein- (including multiple protein modifications such as phosphorylation) and metabolomic-level changes in cancer and healthy states by combing proteome-, metabolome-, and genome-level information. This will contribute to a more unified understanding of cancer biology with translational potential, e.g., development of new cancer diagnostic, prevention, and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic and epigenomic abnormalities collaborate in disease initiation and progression, as exempliﬁed by frequent mutations in protein-coding genes which can vary spatially in separated sub-regions of tissues. This project will develop computational methods to infer tissue-spatial epigenomic landscape which can not be measured using current techniques, leveraging the emerging technologies of spatial transcriptomics, and develop novel statistical methods to identify differential epigenomic signals across patients or cell populations. The outcome of this project can lead to the development of new epigenetic targeted therapy and new epigenetic therapeutic drugs for various diseases that helps the broad community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: With the ongoing scale up of Dolutegravir (DTG), an integrase strand transfer inhibitor antiretroviral treatment, in Sub-Saharan Africa, weight gain has been noted in postpartum women living with HIV. How maternal DTG impacts the physiology of maternal and infant body weight regulation has not been studied. In a cohort of maternal-infant dyads from Uganda, we propose to study how DTG-based regimens affects energy intake and expenditure along with biological measures of appetite and metabolic pathways relevant in weight regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE G-protein–coupled receptors (GPCRs), the largest class of membrane signaling proteins, represent one of the broadest class of drug targets. The GPCRs that respond to glutamate, the main excitatory neurotransmitter of the brain, the mGluRs, have been implicated in various neurological disorders and identified as potential drug targets. We propose to study the molecular mechanisms that set and regulate their function at synapses and that can be used in drug assays in the nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative People with heart failure who do not take their medications as prescribed are at high risk of complications leading to hospitalization, death and poor quality of life. In the proposed intervention, nurses will use easy-to- understand language to coach patients and their care partners to help them work together and build skills to overcome their individual barriers to adherence in order to improve and sustain patient medication adherence. If effective, this intervention will support long-term medication adherence, thus reducing hospitalizations and deaths related to heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases are occurring with increasing frequency and are a threat to human health in the United States and worldwide. To improve knowledge of these diseases and develop the infrastructure to conduct infectious disease research, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) has formed the Emerging Infectious Diseases Research Centers Network (EIDRC-Net). RTI International and Duke University propose to jointly establish the EIDRC-Net Coordination Center to provide overall Network coordination and communication and to build a research infrastructure to help NIAID respond rapidly to infectious disease outbreaks when they occur.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying the genetic variants responsible for patient phenotypes is challenging, especially for rare diseases. We will develop algorithms for interpreting variants of unknown clinical significance by modeling the effects of all variants in a patient on protein 3D structures, integrating structural features with machine learning, and using systems biology to identify functional interactions between variants. In collaboration with the Undiagnosed Dis- eases Network, we will develop and validate mechanistic hypotheses about the genetic basis for disease and establish a foundation for personalized treatments that reflect patients’ unique genetic backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research study investigates the neurobiological profile of young adults with persistent Developmental Language Disorder. DLD can lead to significant limitations in communication, and interpersonal, academic, and occupational success. The link between the behavioral phenotype of the disorder and brain structure and function will be examined in a group of adults with and without DLD (18;0 - 21:0) to facilitate successful targeted treatments of neurodevelopmental language disorders in young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Treatment dropout is a primary challenge for individuals suffering with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and alcohol use disorder (AUD) following trauma exposure. A clearer understanding of the factors that contribute to dropout will enable us to identify individuals at risk of drop out and guide treatment retention efforts. There is a crucial need for strategies that decrease the likelihood of treatment dropout so that individuals with PTSD and alcohol misuse may receive the full benefit of treatment, increasing the likelihood of positive long-term outcomes for this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Food allergy affects nearly 10% of the United States population, and misdiagnosis leads to difficult, anxiety- provoking, and growth-limiting food avoidance. Current diagnostic tools are fraught with inaccuracy or require ingesting possible food allergens under medical monitoring, which is cumbersome, risky, and costly. The goal of this project is to understand the role of leaky skin and gut barriers in food allergy to develop more accurate and less onerous tests to diagnose food allergy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with high-risk solid tumors including sarcoma, renal tumors and other rare solid tumor types have experienced a disproportionately high rate of death from disease highlighting the unmet need for effective therapies. With increased access to potential curative therapies resulting from passage of the Research to Accelerate Cures and Equity (RACE) for Children Act, development of the NCI Pediatric In Vivo Testing Program will facilitate the evaluation and prioritization of drugs for pediatric clinical development. We propose to apply the unique expertise and comprehensive patient-derived xenograft (PDX) tumor model portfolio assembled by our Research Team to test drugs relevant to pediatric sarcoma, renal tumors and other rare solid tumors.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Human genetic studies have produced hundreds of thousands of loci and candidate genes for a wide range of diseases, but often have not resulted in sufficient mechanistic insight to lead to actionable changes in prevention, diagnosis, or treatment. One of the rate-limiting steps has been animal modeling which is typically not feasible at a large enough scale in animals closely related to humans, though in recent years the zebrafish has begun to fill this gap. We have created, maintained and continued to develop a Zebrafish Community Resource to bring state of the art technologies and disease modeling to investigators studying human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Narrative  Cholinergic transmission in the amygdala is critical for emotional memory as demonstrated by the observation that deficits in this signaling underlie emotional disturbances associated with a variety of disorders, including Alzheimer’s disease, drug addiction, anxiety and trauma-related disorders, and schizophrenia. The goal of this project is to determine at a cellular and circuit level how cholinergic signaling modulates amygdalar circuits to regulate emotional memory. These studies will further our understanding of the cellular and circuit mechanisms by which acetylcholine acts to regulate emotion and inform novel avenues for the development of therapeutics to treat a variety of debilitating emotional disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  There is a critical need to understand the mechanisms of action of anti-neoplastic agents that target nutrient dependency in cancer cells. The objectives of this application are to determine the roles and mechanisms of cystine transporter SLC7A11 in regulating nutrient dependency and to therapeutically target nutrient dependency in cancers with aberrant expression of SLC7A11. Our proposed studies will have significant impact on both our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of nutrient dependency and our ability to therapeutically target nutrient dependency in cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biliary atresia is one of the most devastating liver diseases in the pediatric population worldwide, developing in newborn infants after a prenatal insult to the extrahepatic bile ducts. The proposed work seeks to understand the potential ways – healing vs. injury progression – that the bile duct responds to this insult in the prenatal, perinatal, and early postnatal periods. Understanding these wound healing behaviors, particularly those occurring shortly after birth when diagnosis of biliary atresia is possible, offers the potential to develop therapies that shift the balance from progression to healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The olfactory system allows humans to evaluate the quality of food sources and to avoid harmful chemicals, thereby promoting overall health and quality of life. Relatively little is known about how higher order brain structures process olfactory information in mammals. We are using a combination of different techniques to understand the importance of an understudied brain region, the dorsal tenia tecta, for olfactory perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Because traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a major public health problem for civilian and military populations, effective rehabilitation approaches for TBI are essential. An in-home, family-inclusive program (the Veterans' In- home Program [VIP]) showed efficacy with veterans with TBI and their families and was highly acceptable to both. Building on the VIP, the HOME intervention will be tested with veterans and civilians with chronic TBI- related symptoms and family members in a 2-group randomized controlled trial.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of physician-scientists in the United States has been steadily declining, and there is a major need for more basic and translational researchers focused on digestive, pancreatic, and liver related research. The Training Program in Gastrointestinal Sciences at the University of Pennsylvania Perelman School of Medicine has had historic success and remains at the leading edge in nurturing young researchers and ensuring their maturation into independent investigators in digestive, pancreatic, and liver diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative People with brainstem stroke, advanced amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease), or other disorders can become unable to move or speak despite being awake and alert. In this project, we seek to further translate knowledge about interpreting brain signals related to movement, and to further develop an intracortical brain-computer interface (iBCI) that could restore rapid and intuitive use of communication apps on tablet computers by people with paralysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As cannabis legalization has expanded, the incidence of driving under the influence of cannabis has increased and concurrent use of cannabis and alcohol has become more common. In this project, participants will administer one of two novel forms of cannabis (oral and vaporized) in combination with alcohol, and we will evaluate the individual and interactive effects of these substances on cognitive performance, driving ability, and subjective intoxication. Results will further the development of a promising novel tool for detecting cannabis impairment (the DRUID app) and inform regulatory and policy decisions concerning cannabis and alcohol.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity affects more than 1.4 billion adults worldwide and is a significant risk factor for chronic diseases such as hypertension, diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases. However, present non-operative treatment options of obesity are woefully inadequate – intragastric balloons have been demonstrated to be effective in enabling temporary weight loss (~25-30% of excess body weight) but are fundamentally limited to very selected patients as a temporary treatment or as a bridging intervention to bariatric surgery. The proposed research will overcome the limitations of IGB by creating an ingestible gastric-resident electronic-enhanced metamaterial architecture (iGEM) that can transform obesity treatment with a digital-based personalized and dynamic obesity treatment strategy that can be optimized based on safety consideration, patient’s treatment goals, and the quality of life.
