IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our goal is to develop a novel non-invasive, safe, sensitive, and specific methodology to monitor genetically altered human immune cells, called chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells, after they have been transferred into patients to treat cancer. We have developed a DOTA antibody reporter, which binds to a clinically employed radiometal complex (DOTA), and we propose to use this tool for tracking transfused CAR T cells to determine their location and study their functionality, and in case of imminent treatment failure, to exploit these engineered T cells to deliver a deadly payload to the tumor with the goal of improving the anti-tumor efficacy of CAR T-cell therapy. By combining next-generation armored CAR T cells with molecular imaging and targeted radionuclide therapy, this project has the potential to significantly endow these “living” drugs with novel attributes to increase their therapeutic potency and safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Mucosal Associated Invariant T (MAIT) cells are an abundant population of T cell in humans. Presently, we know very little about the function of MAIT cells, their role in protecting humans from microbial infection, or how they may cause disease (e.g. autoimmunity). This proposal will shed fundamental insight into the nature of the antigens that can activate or inhibit MAIT cell function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Pediatric tuberculosis (TB) continues to pose diagnostic challenges in low- and middle-income countries with high rates of TB disease, due to the fact that children do not produce deep phlegm from the lungs used to detect TB in adults, and because sophisticated methods used in affluent countries are of limited usefulness due to cost, restricted availability, and poor sensitivity in children. Our team will evaluate a new diagnostic approach developed by Dr. Tony Hu at Tulane University that detects cell-free DNA from TB bacteria in a cohort of children with presumptive TV disease and age-matched controls children. We will also determine the correlation between cfDNA and quantitative imaging-based TB scores determined by chest X-ray and/or by lung ultrasound, markers that may combine with cfDNA levels to improve the detection of TB disease in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Live nasal recombinant B. pertussis vaccine against tuberculosis Effective tuberculosis vaccines that block infection and interrupt transmission of Mycobacterium tuberculosis from infected adolescents and adults are likely required to induce protective T cells in the lungs. Our vaccine strategy will advance a live vaccine platform comprised of an attenuated strain of Bordetella pertussis which has demonstrated ability to induce durable and specific mucosal and pulmonary T cell responses. We propose to develop the platform bacterial vector (called B-Tech-Mtb) for intranasal vaccination by expressing and secreting well characterized antigens of M. tuberculosis for induction of Th17 CD4+ and CD8+ T cell responses and test for efficacy in non-human primates after extensive characterization in murine models of infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Criminal justice-oriented policies enacted to protect newborns from prenatal substance exposure are associated with unintended negative consequences for both the mother and infant, suchas lower rates of maternal treatment utilization and higher rates of neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome. Connecticut has implemented a unique policy strategy to support this population through early identification and assessment of mother-infant dyads. This proposed project applies a theory of health services utilization to examine this policy’s effect on three key outcomes: (1) maternal substance use treatment utilization, (2) child safety, and (3) racial disparities in child protective services referrals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disruptions to oxygen homeostasis underlie many devastating human diseases including heart, lung, and cerebrovascular disease, as well as chronic conditions that afflict those living at high altitudes above 2500 meters. Using a combination of controlled-laboratory and semi-wild field studies, my lab will exploit natural variation in populations of the North American Deer Mouse, a species with broad elevational distribution, as a means to dissect the genetic and molecular mechanisms by which natural selection reshapes physiology in the process of adaptation to high altitude. The large-scale and ambitious series of experiments outlined in this proposal will yield new insights into high-altitude biology and medicine and may lead to novel therapeutic targets for diseases in which the disruption of oxygen homeostasis is central to their pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Persons with good brain health at the beginning of old age may be able to protect themselves from the development of dementia. Brain health is typically measured using brain imaging and cognitive tests. We are proposing a new way of capturing brain health – by assessing “sensory- motor” function using measurements of smell, vision, hearing, gait, touch and balance using non-invasive tests. These changes are typically considered part of normal aging, but recent research has shown that these could be early warning signs of dementia. In this study, we will examine how brain health measured using these sensory-motor measures can predict protection from or risk for dementia and increase our understanding of the many genetic and lifestyle, vascular factors that determine sensory-motor brain health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative During the critical search for drugs to treat COVID-19 patients, it’s important to select drugs with maximum antiviral efficacy and minimal side-effects. Using a combination of computer modeling and animal studies, we will test the potential for COVID-19 therapies to cause hearing loss; a side-effect of many drugs not often detected during clinical trials. Our goal is to help develop safer COVID-19 therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol is the most commonly abused substance in the US and Alzheimer’s disease is the most common neurodegenerative disease; recent evidence indicates that alcohol abuse increases the risk for developing Alzheimer’s disease and accelerates disease trajectory. Our novel pilot studies indicated that chronic, intermittent alcohol consumption increased mitochondrial oxidant stress in locus coeruleus axons and increased Alzheimer’s related pathology in a mouse model of Alzheimer’s disease. Our proposal is aimed at understanding the effect of chronic, intermittent alcohol consumption on mitochondria in locus coeruleus neurons and how this impacts neurodegeneration and Alzheimer’s related pathology.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although microglia proliferation plays critical roles in the development of many neurological diseases, its mechanism is largely unknown. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure of blood plasma/serum (P/S) biospecimens to temperatures above their freezing point of -30 °C can dramatically impact clinical research results—a phenomenon that has been shown to produce inordinate numbers of false leads in biomedical research. Well over 100 NIH-sponsored extramural grants employ pre- existing P/S—yet, surprisingly, no criteria for establishing pre-existing sample integrity have been set and no quality thresholds exist that must be met before NIH/NCI (taxpayer) funds are spent on studies involving pre- existing P/S. This project will develop and analytically validate simple plate reader-based assays based on established ex vivo biochemistry that will put the means to assess P/S integrity in the hands of nearly every biomedical research scientist—making it possible for governing bodies to require evidence-based quality control of P/S samples employed in biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental Neuroscience for All will combine online and in-person tools to support authentic research experiences for socio-culturally diverse student teams from both urban and rural schools across the US, who will work with scientists and civic partners to design studies that explore the relationship between our brains and our environment (How is our brain health and wellbeing affected by our environment? Can we help improve how we behave toward our environment by deepening our understanding of how the human brain is wired?). The curriculum, paired with an online collaboration platform and professional development materials, will cover topics that are tightly linked to NIH-funded research (How do environmental factors affect brain health? How might behavioral science contribute to public health policy?). Moreover, the program uses an “open science” and participatory science approach, training the next generation of scientists and citizens to view environmental challenges not just as barriers, but as opportunities for research, innovation, and collaboration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is designed to train Dr. Margaret Flanagan in formal epidemiologic and translational research approaches to enable her to become an independently funded physician-scientist studying dementia and aging. Trans-active response DNA-binding protein 43 (TDP43) has been previously shown to be associated with increased levels of inflammatory markers and may serve as a modulator of inflammation, yet it remains unclear what is detrimental vs. beneficial in the increasingly prevalent disease entity: Limbic predominant age related TDP43 encephalopathy (LATE). Results from this work will provide insight for development of future therapeutic strategies targeting TDP43 associated neuroinflammation.

PHR: UW NATHAN SHOCK CENTER OVERALL - PROJECT NARRATIVE We apply for renewal of the Nathan Shock Center of Excellence in the Basic Biology of Aging at the University of Washington, which has for 25 years provided key resources supporting investigators who study the biology of aging. The overarching goal of this Center is to have a positive impact on the field by accelerating research discovery and providing research support for investigators nationally and internationally, particularly junior investigators in the process of building their own research programs. We will accomplish this goal through six cores that function synergistically together: four Resource Cores with particular expertise in protein (Core C) and metabolite (Core D) phenotypes of aging, invertebrate longevity and healthspan phenotypes (Core E) and artificial intelligence and bioinformatics (Core F), along with a Research Development Core (Core B) that supports external pilot projects and junior faculty studies, and an Administrative and Program Enrichment Core (Core A) that supports administrative management, an external advisory panel, sponsorship and organization of national meetings and pre-meetings, courses, workshops and seminars, and, in coordination with other Nathan Shock Centers, a Geropathology Research initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early caregiving adversity is strongly linked to the emergence of psychopathology but the neurodevelopmental mechanisms remain elusive. The short-term goal of my research is to determine how adaptations in midline cortico-subcortical circuitry following early adversity represent the affective semantic knowledge learned during early caregiving experiences. In the long term, my findings will fuel investigations into the developmental neurocomputational mechanisms of affective semantic memory that are linked to differential risk and resilience for psychopathology in adversity-exposed children and adolescents, identifying novel strategies to intervene when these adaptations are no longer beneficial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An understudied region of the hippocampal formation—the subiculum—has a poorly-defined, but necessary, role in memory retrieval. Subicular atrophy is one of the earliest biomarkers for Alzheimer’s disease, and is robustly associated with cognitive impairment. This proposal seeks to advance our understanding of this neglected region, determine what role it may play in the coordination of brain-wide activity, and generate critical insights into neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Older adults with cancer are at risk for severe negative outcomes related to chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) during treatment with chemotherapy due to poor self-management. Early reinforcement of standard education and reframing preconceived beliefs about the ability of CINV to be successfully managed through serious games will increase self-care behaviors and improve patient outcomes. The purpose of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of a serious game intervention in reducing CINV severity and healthcare use and increasing functioning and quality of life in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy alcohol drinking during adolescence is known to disturb brain development and functioning and increase risk of drinking problems in adulthood, but the extent of the lingering effects of youthful drinking on adult functioning remains unclear. The goal of NCANDA-A (Adulthood) is to determine how adolescent alcohol-related disruption of normal brain growth patterns of structure, related brain function, and psychiatric health affects brain functioning in emerging adulthood. Determining which affected processes remain impaired and which escape alcohol's untoward effects will specify how a youthful-drinking history influences quality of life in adulthood, information obtained only from longitudinal study as proposed by NCANDA-A.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cochlear implants (CIs) are the standard treatment for adults with moderate to profound sensorineural hearing loss who no longer benefit from hearing aids. This project enhances the interpretation and application of a new CI-specific quality of life measure so functional abilities can be tracked over time with the goal of improving hearing loss treatments for adults with moderate to profound hearing loss. This is directly relevant to the NIH’s mission as it seeks and applies knowledge to enhance human life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Sepsis is a devastating illness with high mortality. Most studies have investigated inflammation in sepsis, although many people are prone to immune suppression with impaired ability to fight infections. We have discovered a new model that may explain immune suppression in sepsis that led us to propose characterizing a protein that restores immune function. This discovery fulfills an unmet need in this critical illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  The bark of Galbulimima sp. features in the traditional medicine and ritual of Papua New Guinea, but the psychoactive principles have not been identified. This proposal discloses new biomolecular targets of the Galbulimima alkaloids, preliminary pharmacological data that demonstrates rapid brain penetration and a chemical platform to enable broad experimental interrogation. These studies will allow the exploration of a broad but remote area of complex natural product space and translation to new therapeutics based on natural remedies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite decades of major advances in the ability to study the brain processes that control behavior, we have not yet reached the goal of translating this new knowledge into breakthroughs in treating psychiatric illness. Progress has been limited by the fact that few researchers have a combined understanding of psychiatric illness as it appears in humans and how it is studied in laboratory models, which limits effective communication across disciplines and translation of discoveries into treatments. This McLean Hospital training program is designed to ensure that postdoctoral trainees develop a sophisticated understanding of both psychiatry and neuroscience by utilizing specialized mentorship teams with expertise that covers both disciplines.
PROJECT_TERMS: Neurosciences;Psychiatry;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training to Enhance Alignment of Psychiatry and Neuroscience

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In this study, we will investigate the roles of programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) and its ligand, PD-1, in ADPKD. We will address two main concerns in PKD field, including, 1) whether and how cystic epithelial cells escape immune attacks in cyst microenvironment in which T cells and macrophages are increased; and 2) whether and how PKD mutant cystic renal epithelial cells affects the adjacent cell function during cyst initiation and progression. Accomplishing this study will lead to a better understanding of the mechanism of immune surveillance in renal cyst formation and the roles of cystic cell exosomes in regulating immunosuppression and other cell-to-cell communication, which will provide novel therapeutic strategy for ADPKD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will discover novel mechanisms controlling muscle ribosome production and hypertrophy. These data will define the molecular targets through which ribosomal production can be stimulated to promote muscle growth. The outcomes of this study provide the translational framework to prevent muscle loss and weakness associated with aging, cancer and other chronic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Inhibitory neurons are essential elements of any circuit and defects in inhibitory function can lead to neurological disorders and mental illnesses. The CA3 region of the hippocampus is a central brain region for computing learning and memory, yet there are very few studies investigating how inhibitory neurons regulate CA3 function. Our proposal will determine how the activity of different types of GABA neurons regulate CA3 pyramidal cell activity, learning, and memory in mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacteria become progressively resistant to all existing antibiotics, rendering them obsolete. Gram-negative bacteria are among the most nefarious human pathogens that have evolved a host of resistance mechanisms. These are among the most difficult pathogens to treat clinically. I describe our work on the bulgecin class of compounds, which sensitize Gram-negative bacteria to the action of b-lactam antibiotics, a process referred to as potentiation. I disclose a strategy in discovery of a suitable bulgecin analog and a b-latam antibiotic that would fight infections by Gram-negative bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will significantly contribute to the field of HIV prevention by providing insight into how the power of social media and trans women social influencers can be used to deliver PrEP information to affect knowledge, perceptions and potential uptake of PrEP. Using trans women focused PrEP materials developed in a previous study, we will identify and train trans women social influencers who will provide those messages through an Instagram-based intervention called SIS (Sisters Influencing Sisters) and assess acceptability, feasibility, and promise of efficacy in changing PrEP perceptions and intentions in trans women followers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy alcohol drinking during adolescence is known to disturb brain development and functioning and increase risk of drinking problems in adulthood, but the extent of the lingering effects of youthful drinking on adult functioning remains unclear. The goal of NCANDA-A (Adulthood) is to determine how adolescent alcohol-related disruption of normal brain growth patterns of structure, related brain function, and psychiatric health affects brain functioning in emerging adulthood. Determining which affected processes remain impaired and which escape alcohol's untoward effects will specify how a youthful-drinking history influences quality of life in adulthood, information obtained only from longitudinal study as proposed by NCANDA-A.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Altered metabolism is a feature of colorectal cancer (CRC), although how metabolism contributes to cancer cell survival and resistance to chemotherapy is less understood. In this project we will use novel biochemistry, cellular, and in vivo models to study how a mitochondrial sirtuin pathway regulates CRC metabolism and resistance to chemotherapy. A better understanding of these pathways will provide insight into the role of SIRT4 and de novo nucleotide synthesis in CRC, and may lead to urgently needed precision therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite unprecedented clinical success in the treatment of advanced cancers, immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) therapy can lead to life-/organ-threatening complications, termed immune-related adverse events (irAEs), including arthritis-irAE, colitis-irAE, pneumonitis-irAE, etc. To date, mechanisms and signs that underpin the development of irAEs have not been elucidated; thus, highlighting an urgent need to recognize these toxicities early on and provide an appropriate and timely treatment without compromising anti-tumor immunity in cancer patients. The proposed research will help to identify and evaluate unique and shared mechanistic biomarkers of arthritis-irAE, colitis-irAE, and pneumonitis-irAE, as well as establish the most optimal therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Doctors use combinations of antibiotics to try to kill bacteria that are resistant to all available individual antibiotics, but these combinations are only sporadically effective and it is unclear when and why they work. We have discovered a paradigm-shifting, scientific basis underlying the efficacy of combinations that now facilitates the tailored selection of antibiotic cocktails to kill individual bacterial isolates, including those resistant to all available drugs and thought to be untreatable. In this proposal we will broadly validate our combination approach across a wide range of antibiotics and multiple bacterial species, potentially revolutionizing combination therapy and having a major translational impact on patient survival in the era of increasing antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative / Public Relevance Statement Almost 300,000 patients undergo cardiac surgery in the US each year, and up to 30% develop cardiac surgery- associated acute kidney injury (CSA-AKI), increasing mortality by up to 10-fold and adding $10-40K to hospital expenditures per case. Beyond patient and surgical baseline characteristics, intraoperative and early postoperative ICU processes of care vary widely across hospitals and remain a critically understudied data source for developing a precision understanding of factors contributing to CSA-AKI. We will (i) identify modifiable intraoperative and early postoperative practices associated with reduced risk of CSA-AKI; (ii) estimate the most effective strategy for reducing CSA-AKI, comparing individualized care, standardized care, and usual care, and (iii) disseminate and assess the effect of precision feedback on CSA-AKI and relevant processes of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative BRAF and MEK inhibitor therapies are often potent against melanoma, but patients nearly always eventually develop drug resistance. We have identified S6K1, an understudied drug target, as a potential broad-use counter-resistance therapy, as it can block most known resistance mechanisms. In this proposal, we will cement a role of S6K1 as a key drug target in melanoma by conducting extensive drug testing, examining its correlation with patient outcomes, and exploring the mechanisms of how S6K1 drives drug resistance.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Roughly 6 million people with a disability experience transportation difficulties as a result of the lack of accessible transportation, scheduling complications, high costs and limited availability for nonmedical purposes. According to the US Department of Transportation, some of the most common strategies to compensate include reducing day-to-day travel, asking others for rides, limiting travel to daytime and giving up driving. As a result, there is a significant demand for more accessible transportation options. Unfortunately, acquiring a personal accessible vehicle is financially difficult due to the extensive cost of the modifications that are necessary for power wheelchairs to fit, specifically. Although such modifications are able to be performed today, the convertibility of future electric vehicles raise additional design challenges due to the location of the batteries and electrical components.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Early initiators of buprenorphine, a leading treatment for opioid use disorder, are at high risk for early relapse, likely due to dysfunction within craving and cognitive control neuronal networks. This project will test a non- invasive brain stimulation technique, transcranial Direct Current Stimulation, to reduce craving in buprenorphine recipients. If the FMRI provides validation of tDCS-related changes in these neuronal networks as well as clinical efficacy, then this neuromodulation intervention may be an important adjuvant treatment in clinical care of those entering buprenorphine care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL - NARRATIVE COVID-19 is a world-wide health problem caused by SARS-CoV-2 viral infection that starts in the lung but can also affect the heart, and brain. Our Program teams will join forces to better understand the mechanism of organ damage and reveal ways to prevent it by combining efforts of three Projects supported by four Cores. Working will simultaneously, synergistically and collaboratively complement, expedite and enhance the understanding of the mechanism of COVID-19-mediated damage in different organs to identify novel drug targets that can limit the severity of COVID-19 and the development of long-term sequalae.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Persons with functional disabilities overwhelmingly prefer to remain at home. Home and Community-Based Services (HCBS) are an important support to help Veterans age in place, but government reports reveal HCBS access barriers for qualifying Veterans and show 50% of Veterans referred to HCBS do not use services within 12 months. We do not understand how supply constraints such as lack of access versus demand constraints such as preferences affect HCBS use nationally, nor the consequences of use patterns for Veteran-centered outcomes. This rigorous mixed methods study will illuminate multi-level drivers of the largest VA HCBS, homemaker home health aide services (H/HHA). We will also estimate the average treatment effect of H/HHA on Veteran-centered outcomes and total VA costs. This IIR will inform future scalability of H/HHA by obtaining perspectives from multiple parties about suboptimal use and use implementation mapping with our operational partners to recommend actionable change to the H/HHA benefit.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS, UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF
PHR: By the year 2037, Veterans’ use of Community Nursing Homes will increase 80% above 2017 levels, and corresponding expenditures will increase approximately 150%. Medical Foster Home (MFH) care is potentially less expensive. VA planning regarding MFH retention and expansion requires understanding the cost implications of MFH care. Because program coordinators are essential to MFH operations, to provide a cost saving alternative to institutional care, it is important to understand coordinator impact on efficiency of operations. This project will determine the impact of coordinator effort and experience on MFH Veteran direct healthcare costs as well as ED visits and hospitalizations. Additionally, to be a high reliability organization, the VA emphasizes the development of a patient safety culture among its facilities. This project will determine whether a patient safety culture moderates the impact of coordinators on program efficiency and will inform decisions regarding program coordinator coverage and training as impacted by patient safety culture.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Drug manufacturers regularly introduce novel, resource-intensive treatments. There is a critical need and opportunity to optimize treatment with established medications to maximize their benefit and provide high- quality care considering competing VHA resources and Veterans’ needs. This challenge is exemplified in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), a costly and debilitating lifelong disease with rising resource needs. IBD represents an ideal proof-of-concept and real-world example on which to conduct research to address: 1. Patient-centered treatment optimization by putting VA Data to Work for Veterans, 2. Pre- implementation strategies for adoption, and 3. Optimal approaches to healthcare utilization (e.g., access to care) using the VA as a Learning Healthcare System–all of which are VA HSR&D Priorities, updated 3/2023. This work will serve as a template for positioning Artificial Intelligence (AI)/Machine Learning (ML)-enabled decision support strategies (AEDS) at the point of care to improve health outcomes and access for Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Individuals with paralysis represent a significant portion of the Veterans patient base. Paralysis reduces the ability to perform tasks of everyday living and can result in secondary health impacts (bone density loss and muscle atrophy) and a withdrawal from work and social activities. Powered exoskeletons are wearable robots that enable individuals with paralysis to walk again and exercise their paralyzed limbs. Although exoskeletons are safe for use in rehabilitative or home environments with trained caregivers, this CDA-1 proposal aims to explore falling with an exoskeleton and to reconfigure them into lower joint impact configurations to reduce potential injury to users if a fall should occur. Developing these features will amplify the health benefits of exoskeletons being prescribed for Veterans with paralysis by allowing more widespread and spontaneous use to encourage users to strengthen their muscles, improve their overall health, return to work, and become more actively engaged within their communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current proposal examines how exposure to prescription opioids during pregnancy affects postpartum mental health and motivation for drug rewards. Oxytocin and dopamine signaling interactions are an at-risk substrate for the pharmacological actions of opioids during pregnancy. Using a combination of behavioral, neuroeconomic, optogenetic, and electrophysiological methods, this project seeks to reveal a causal link between prescription opioid use during pregnancy and postpartum opioid abuse risk, one of the main preventable causes of pregnancy-related deaths in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Biofilms are a great risk to human health and since exopolysaccharide plays a major role in biofilms, understanding the regulation of its synthesis is a major goal of this project. Specifically, we will study the regulation of exopolysaccharide synthesis in the oral bacterium, Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, which is a major agent associated with Localized Aggressive Periodontitis. This disease primarily affects young adolescents of African American ancestry.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Over 1 million U.S. military Veterans identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, non-binary, queer/questioning, and other sexual/gender minority identities (LGBTQ+). This is a growing group of Veterans in the Veterans Health Administration (VHA). LGBTQ+ Veterans have disproportionate risk of mental health concerns, such as depression and suicide. Little is known about the best ways to implement treatments that are designed to reduce mental health risk in LGBTQ+ individuals. This study would contribute to scientific knowledge about methods to include health equity in planning how to implement evidence-based mental health interventions for LGBTQ+ Veterans. This study would also contribute to scientific knowledge about how implementation of evidence-based, LGBTQ-affirmative mental health treatments can improve access to mental health care as well as depression and suicidality among LGBTQ+ Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food allergy exerts substantial impact on affected individuals, their families, and society, including lifestyle limitations and reductions in quality of life. This application from the Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC), will address the following goals: (1) establish the VUMC CoFAR CRC, which will rapidly implement and execute single site and multi-center clinical trials, with high quality and fidelity, focused on the prevention and management of patients with food allergy, supplemented by studies to better elucidate the mechanisms underlying food allergies; (2) develop and conduct a consortium-wide, multi-center, clinical trial to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of once weekly peanut feeding (low weekly peanut protein dose) versus thrice weekly peanut feedings (standard weekly peanut protein dose) in the prevention of peanut allergy in infants at high risk for the development of peanut allergy; and (3) to better understand the alpha-gal syndrome (AGS), specifically why some patients in tick-endemic areas develop clinically evident AGS after a bite, while others do not, and why the clinical expression of AGS is variable amongst patients and changes over time.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maintaining functional status, or the ability to perform daily activities, is central to older adults’ quality of life, health, and ability to remain independent. Identifying functional impairments is essential for clinicians to provide optimal care to older adults, and on a population level, understanding function can help anticipate service needs. Yet uptake of standardized measurement of functional status into patient care has been slow and inconsistent due to the burden posed by current tools. The purpose of the proposed QUERI Partnered Evaluation Initiative is to implement and evaluate a patient-centered, low-burden intervention to improve measurement of functional status in VA primary care settings nationally. We hypothesize that implementing this intervention will increase identification and improve management of functional impairment among older Veterans while providing key data to inform VHA strategic planning related to long-term services and supports.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Proteoforms play key roles in human health and disease and are effective markers for differentiating cell types and heterogeneous cell populations. The proposed research develops a suite of high-throughput technologies for enhanced proteoform profiling of tissue-contained single cells particularly rare cells. This proposal will uncover novel molecular signatures for tissue-resident innate immune cells and expand our knowledge on their roles to furnish novel therapeutic strategies in relevant diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: This project is relevant to all aspects of VA healthcare for it will test the feasibility and acceptability of a novel Relational Playbook combined with a leadership coaching implementation strategy for frontline managers to cultivate supportive learning environments. This work will inform national efforts to enhance employee well- being due to crisis levels of employee burnout and turnover. The Playbook consists of research-based re- sources and 50 evidence-based practices for teams, including how to assess team well-being, address difficult relationships, and implement hiring best practices. We will pilot the Playbook with 1:1 virtual leadership coach- ing to inspire nurse managers to improve their team culture. We will conduct a mixed methods process evalua- tion to inform a pragmatic adaptive effectiveness trial. We expect this study to demonstrate the Playbook com- bined with coaching is a feasible and acceptable approach to create supportive learning environments that im- prove employee well-being and address factors contributing to employee burnout and turnover.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: GLUCOSE BINDS RBPs TO REGULATE EPIDERMAL HOMEOSTASIS  Project Narrative The maintenance of epithelial tissue is orchestrated by an interplay of regulatory factors that control transcription, RNA processing, translation and protein modification that together balance the decisions to divide, differentiate or enter senescence. Breakdowns in this regulatory system lead to skin diseases, such as psoriasis or cancer. In this proposal, we aim to elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which glucose regulates the activity of RNA- binding proteins and their interacting targets in the context of epidermal differentiation, with the ultimate goal of developing new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of skin diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Schizophrenia (SZ) is a chronic mental disease in which specific clinical domains [e.g., negative symptoms (the lack of motivation and inability to feel pleasure) and social cognitive deficits] are particularly least responsive to treatment, making patients’ prognosis and functionality even more devastating. Based on promising pilot studies in our group, we hypothesize a significant contribution of the olfactory system in these clinical domains. We will elucidate the mechanism of how the pathology of the olfactory epithelium alters the olfactory system and, in turn, higher brain function in animal models, and then we will validate the notion in patients with early-stage SZ.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiplex molecular panels have facilitated the diagnosis of patients presenting with acute diarrhea and enabled the rapid detection of diarrheagenic E. coli which were previously overlooked by conventional clinical laboratory methods. Enteropathogenic (EPEC) and enteroaggregative (EAEC) E. coli are now among the most common pathogens detected by these panels. Yet, although both are established as causes of diarrhea in infants living in developing countries, little is known about their clinical relevance in adult patients living in high-income countries. The proposed research will examine the clinical features, epidemiology, and antimicrobial resistance of EPEC/EAEC infections in U.S. adults to better understand their importance and to inform strategies for their prevention and management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although treatment-related sexual dysfunction is one of the most prevalent and distressing side effects for young adult female cancer survivors, help for sexual dysfunction remains largely unavailable. To address this pressing need, we propose to test SHAREonline, a synchronous online educational intervention delivered by a trained presenter. SHAREonline has the potential to improve sexual function and quality of life for thousands of young adult survivors by delivering sexual health rehabilitation in a format that is brief, efficient and easily accessible.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Oropharyngeal cancer (OPC) incidence in the Veteran population is increasing at a rate 3 times that of the general US population and survival lags that of the US population by >20% due to a disproportionate burden of aggressive, treatment resistant disease. These factors combine to make rapid development of precision oncology approaches to OPC a categorical imperative for the VHA. In the current proposal we will utilize machine learning approaches to develop the Artificial Intelligence for Risk Stratification of Oropharyngeal Carcinoma (AIROC) algorithm which will predict chemo-radiation response in patients with OPC with a sensitivity and specificity greater than 95% using clinically generated data readily available across the VHA that can be easily deployed across VHA facilities for utilization in clinical practice and planned clinical trials for this deadly disease.

PHR: OVERALL COMPONENT – PROJECT NARRATIVE The Rare and Atypical Diabetes Network (RADIANT) enrolls and deeply characterizes individuals with rare and atypical forms of diabetes. Whole-genome sequencing could help identify new genetic variants and metabolomics and transcriptomics analysis novel pathogenic mechanisms and biomarkers for atypical forms of the disease. Its ultimate goal is to enable a more precise, etiologically based clinical classification of diabetes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Veterans are at higher risk than non-Veterans of falling ill with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). As we await a cure for ALS in the future, we need more treatments now. We have shown that pairing electrical stimulation over the cervical spinal cord synchronized with magnetic stimulation over the brain can temporarily strengthen weakened nerve circuits between the brain and hand muscles in people with ALS. The current proposal will take the next step of customizing this intervention for each individual, then applying it repetitively in an attempt to achieve direct clinical benefit on hand strength and function. We will compare the effects of two-week programs of hand exercise versus paired brain-spinal stimulation versus the combination of exercise and stimulation. Not only will this project improve understanding of paired brain-spinal cord stimulation in ALS, but its eligibility criteria will also be more inclusive than most ALS studies, giving more Veterans an opportunity to participate in research aimed at treating this service-connected condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The overall objective of the grant is to understand how the melanoma glycome, which is the repertoire of cellular glycans and glycan-binding proteins, impacts metastatic progression. Our proposed studies seek to investigate whether a newly-described glycome pathway in metastatic melanoma cells is critical for melanoma metastasis and a potential target for effective anti-metastatic therapy. These findings will help illuminate the value of novel human melanoma glycome features as clinical biomarkers for diagnosing melanoma development or for prognosticating clinical outcome and treatment strategies.
